<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">John F. Kennedy</h1> <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div> <div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"JFK", "John Kennedy", and "Jack Kennedy" redirect here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/JFK_(disambiguation)" title="JFK (disambiguation)">JFK (disambiguation)</a>, <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/John_Kennedy_(disambiguation)" title="John Kennedy (disambiguation)">John Kennedy (disambiguation)</a>, and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Jack_Kennedy_(disambiguation)" title="Jack Kennedy (disambiguation)">Jack Kennedy (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">35th President of the United States</div>

//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/American_Defense_Service_Medal_ribbon.svg/46px-American_Defense_Service_Medal_ribbon.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a> <a href="/wiki/American_Defense_Service_Medal" title="American Defense Service Medal">American Defense Service Medal</a><br/><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:American_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg"><img alt="American Campaign Medal ribbon.svg" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="279" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="6" title="American Campaign Medal">American Campaign Medal</a><br/><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg"><img alt="Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal ribbon.svg" href="/wiki/Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal" title="Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal">Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal</a> (with 3 <a href="/wiki/Service_star" title="Service star">service stars</a>)<br/><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg"><img alt="World War II Victory Medal ribbon.svg" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="29" data-file-width="106" decoding="async" height="6" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg/23px-World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg.png" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg/46px-World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a> <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_Victory_Medal_(United_States)" title="World War II Victory Medal (United States)">World War II Victory</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_misc_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_misc-1">[1]</a></sup></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks vcard hlist" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%;border: 4px double #d69d36;"><tbody><tr><th style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em;font-size: 110%; padding: 0; line-height: 150%;"><table><tbody><tr>
<td style="background: #002466; vertical-align:middle; padding:5px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy,_White_House_photo_portrait,_looking_up.jpg"><img alt="John F. <hr/>
<p><img alt="" data-file-height="2425" data-file-width="2424" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/100px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/150px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg/200px-Seal_of_the_President_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="100"/>
</p>
<a href="/wiki/List_of_personal_coats_of_arms_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States" title="List of personal coats of arms of Presidents of the United States"><img alt="Coat of Arms of John F. Kennedy.svg" data-file-height="588" data-file-width="395" decoding="async" height="60" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Coat_of_Arms_of_John_F._Kennedy.svg/40px-Coat_of_Arms_of_John_F._Kennedy.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Coat_of_Arms_of_John_F._Kennedy.svg/60px-Coat_of_Arms_of_John_F._Kennedy.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Coat_of_Arms_of_John_F._Kennedy.svg/80px-Coat_of_Arms_of_John_F._Kennedy.svg.png 2x" width="40"/></a></td>
</tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;text-align:center;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:JFK_series" title="Template:JFK series"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:JFK_series" title="Template talk:JFK series"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:JFK_series&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>John Fitzgerald "Jack" Kennedy</b> (May 29, 1917 – November 22, 1963), commonly referred to by his initials <b>JFK</b>, was an American politician and journalist who served as the 35th <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">president of the United States</a> from January 1961 until <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Assassination of John F. Kennedy">his assassination</a> in November 1963. He served at the height of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, and the majority of his presidency dealt with managing relations with the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>. A member of the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic Party</a>, Kennedy represented <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts" title="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._House_of_Representatives" title="U.S. House of Representatives">U.S. House of Representatives</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Senate" title="U.S. Senate">Senate</a> prior to becoming president.
</p><p>Kennedy was born in <a href="/wiki/Brookline,_Massachusetts" title="Brookline, Massachusetts">Brookline, Massachusetts</a>, the second child of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_P._Kennedy_Sr." title="Joseph P. Kennedy Sr.">Joseph P. Kennedy Sr.</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rose_Kennedy" title="Rose Kennedy">Rose Kennedy</a>. He graduated from <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard University</a> in 1940 and joined the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Naval_Reserve" title="U.S. Naval Reserve">U.S. Naval Reserve</a> the following year. During <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, he commanded a series of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PT_boats" title="PT boats">PT boats</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_War" title="Pacific War">Pacific theater</a> and earned the <a href="/wiki/Navy_and_Marine_Corps_Medal" title="Navy and Marine Corps Medal">Navy and Marine Corps Medal</a> for his service. After the war, Kennedy represented the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/11th_congressional_district_of_Massachusetts" title="11th congressional district of Massachusetts">11th congressional district of Massachusetts</a> in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1947 to 1953. He was subsequently elected to the U.S. Senate and served as the junior Senator from Massachusetts from 1953 to 1960. While in the Senate, he published his book entitled <i><a href="/wiki/Profiles_in_Courage" title="Profiles in Courage">Profiles in Courage</a></i>, which won a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize_for_Biography" title="Pulitzer Prize for Biography">Pulitzer Prize for Biography</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/1960_United_States_presidential_election" title="1960 United States presidential election">1960 presidential election</a>, Kennedy narrowly defeated <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republican</a> opponent <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a>, who was the incumbent vice president. At age 43, he became the second-youngest man to serve as president (after <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Theodore Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a>), the youngest man to be elected as U.S. president, as well as the only <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" title="Roman Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> to occupy that office. He was also the first president to have served in the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy" title="United States Navy">U.S. Navy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy's time in office was marked by high tensions with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_states" title="Communist states">communist states</a> in the Cold War. He increased the number of American military advisers in <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South Vietnam</a> by a factor of 18 over President <a href="/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower" title="Dwight D. Eisenhower">Dwight D. Eisenhower</a>. In April 1961, he authorized a failed joint-CIA attempt to overthrow the <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuban</a> government of <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Castro" title="Fidel Castro">Fidel Castro</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Pigs_Invasion" title="Bay of Pigs Invasion">Bay of Pigs Invasion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> He subsequently rejected <a href="/wiki/Operation_Northwoods" title="Operation Northwoods">Operation Northwoods</a> plans by the Joint Chiefs of Staff to orchestrate <a href="/wiki/False_flag" title="False flag">false flag</a> attacks on American soil in order to gain public approval for a war against Cuba. In October 1962, U.S. spy planes discovered that Soviet missile bases had been deployed in Cuba; the resulting period of tensions, termed the <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis" title="Cuban Missile Crisis">Cuban Missile Crisis</a>, nearly resulted in the breakout of a global thermonuclear conflict. Domestically, Kennedy presided over the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Peace_Corps" title="Peace Corps">Peace Corps</a> and supported the <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights_movement" title="Civil rights movement">civil rights movement</a>, but was only somewhat successful in passing his <a href="/wiki/New_Frontier" title="New Frontier">New Frontier</a> domestic policies.
</p><p>On November 22, 1963, Kennedy <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Assassination of John F. Kennedy">was assassinated</a> in <a href="/wiki/Dallas" title="Dallas">Dallas</a>, Texas. Pursuant to the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Succession_Act" title="Presidential Succession Act">Presidential Succession Act</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States" title="Vice President of the United States">Vice President</a> <a href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Lyndon B. Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a> was sworn in as president later that day. <a href="/wiki/Marxism" title="Marxism">Marxist</a> <a href="/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald" title="Lee Harvey Oswald">Lee Harvey Oswald</a> was arrested for the <a href="/wiki/State_crime" title="State crime">state crime</a>, but he was never prosecuted due to his killing by <a href="/wiki/Jack_Ruby" title="Jack Ruby">Jack Ruby</a> two days later; Ruby was sentenced to death and died while the sentence was on appeal in 1967. Both the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">FBI</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Warren_Commission" title="Warren Commission">Warren Commission</a> officially concluded that Oswald had acted alone in the assassination, but various groups challenged the findings of the Warren Report and believed that Kennedy was the victim of a <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_assassination_conspiracy_theories" title="John F. Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories">conspiracy</a>. After Kennedy's death, Congress enacted many of his proposals, including the <a href="/wiki/Civil_Rights_Act_of_1964" title="Civil Rights Act of 1964">Civil Rights</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Revenue_Act_of_1964" title="Revenue Act of 1964">Revenue Acts</a> of 1964. Kennedy continues to rank highly in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Historians%27_polls_of_U.S._presidents" title="Historians' polls of U.S. presidents">historians' polls of U.S. presidents</a> and with the general public. His average approval rating of 70% is the highest of any president in <a href="/wiki/Gallup_(company)" title="Gallup (company)">Gallup</a>'s history of systematically measuring job approval.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r872693506">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div class="toc" id="toc"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

</li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_education">Early life and education</span></h2>
<p>John Fitzgerald Kennedy was born on May 29, 1917, at <a href="/wiki/John_Fitzgerald_Kennedy_National_Historic_Site" title="John Fitzgerald Kennedy National Historic Site">83 Beals Street</a> in suburban <a href="/wiki/Brookline,_Massachusetts" title="Brookline, Massachusetts">Brookline, Massachusetts</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek200320_5-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek200320-5">[5]</a></sup> to businessman/politician <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joseph_P._Kennedy,_Sr." title="Joseph P. Kennedy, Sr.">Joseph Patrick "Joe" Kennedy</a> and philanthropist/socialite <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rose_Elizabeth_Fitzgerald_Kennedy" title="Rose Elizabeth Fitzgerald Kennedy">Rose Elizabeth Fitzgerald Kennedy</a>. His paternal grandfather <a href="/wiki/P._J._Kennedy" title="P. J. Kennedy">P. J. Kennedy</a> was a member of the <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_General_Court" title="Massachusetts General Court">Massachusetts state legislature</a>. His maternal grandfather and namesake <a href="/wiki/John_F._Fitzgerald" title="John F. Fitzgerald">John F. Fitzgerald</a> served as a U.S. Congressman and was elected to two terms as <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_Boston" title="Mayor of Boston">Mayor of Boston</a>. All four of his grandparents were children of Irish immigrants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_misc_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_misc-1">[1]</a></sup> Kennedy had an elder brother, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_P._Kennedy_Jr." title="Joseph P. Kennedy Jr.">Joseph Jr.</a>, and seven younger siblings: <a href="/wiki/Rosemary_Kennedy" title="Rosemary Kennedy">Rosemary</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kathleen_Kennedy_Cavendish" title="Kathleen Kennedy Cavendish">Kathleen "Kick"</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eunice_Kennedy_Shriver" title="Eunice Kennedy Shriver">Eunice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Patricia_Kennedy_Lawford" title="Patricia Kennedy Lawford">Patricia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy" title="Robert F. Kennedy">Robert "Bobby"</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jean_Kennedy_Smith" title="Jean Kennedy Smith">Jean</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ted_Kennedy" title="Ted Kennedy">Edward "Ted"</a>. As of  2019,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=John_F._Kennedy&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> he has been the only Catholic U.S. President.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Kennedy lived in Brookline for the first ten years of his life and attended the local <a href="/wiki/St._Aidan%27s_Church_(Brookline,_Massachusetts)" title="St. Aidan's Church (Brookline, Massachusetts)">St. Aidan's Church</a>, where he was baptized on June 19, 1917.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> He was educated at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edward_Devotion_School" title="Edward Devotion School">Edward Devotion School</a> in Brookline, the <a href="/wiki/Noble_and_Greenough_School" title="Noble and Greenough School">Noble and Greenough Lower School</a> in nearby <a href="/wiki/Dedham,_Massachusetts" title="Dedham, Massachusetts">Dedham, Massachusetts</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Dexter_School" title="Dexter School">Dexter School</a> (also in Brookline) through the 4th grade. His father's business had kept him away from the family for long stretches of time, and his ventures were concentrated on <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a> and Hollywood. In September 1927, the family moved from Brookline to <a href="/wiki/Riverdale,_Bronx" title="Riverdale, Bronx">Riverdale, Bronx</a>, New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien200521_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien200521-8">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-John_F._Kennedy:_Early_Years_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-John_F._Kennedy:_Early_Years-9">[9]</a></sup> Young John attended the lower campus of <a href="/wiki/Riverdale_Country_School" title="Riverdale Country School">Riverdale Country School</a>, a private school for boys, from 5th to 7th grade. Two years later, the family moved to suburban <a href="/wiki/Bronxville,_New_York" title="Bronxville, New York">Bronxville, New York</a>, where Kennedy was a member of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boy_Scout" title="Boy Scout">Boy Scout</a> Troop 2 and attended <a href="/wiki/Church_of_St._Joseph_(Bronxville,_New_York)" title="Church of St. Joseph (Bronxville, New York)">St. Joseph's Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_misc_1-2"><a href="#cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_misc-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> The Kennedy family spent summers and early autumns<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kennedy37_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kennedy37-11">[11]</a></sup> at <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_Compound" title="Kennedy Compound">their home</a> (rented in 1926, then purchased in 1929)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/Hyannis_Port,_Massachusetts" title="Hyannis Port, Massachusetts">Hyannis Port, Massachusetts</a>, and Christmas and Easter holidays at their winter retreat in <a href="/wiki/Palm_Beach,_Florida" title="Palm Beach, Florida">Palm Beach, Florida</a>, later purchased in 1933. In September 1930, Kennedy—then 13 years old—attended the <a href="/wiki/Canterbury_School_(Connecticut)" title="Canterbury School (Connecticut)">Canterbury School</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_Milford,_Connecticut" title="New Milford, Connecticut">New Milford, Connecticut</a>, for 8th grade. In April 1931, he had an <a href="/wiki/Appendectomy" title="Appendectomy">appendectomy</a>, after which he withdrew from Canterbury and recuperated at home.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek200334_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek200334-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 1931, Kennedy started attending <a href="/wiki/Choate_Rosemary_Hall" title="Choate Rosemary Hall">Choate</a>, a prestigious boarding school in <a href="/wiki/Wallingford,_Connecticut" title="Wallingford, Connecticut">Wallingford, Connecticut</a>, for 9th through 12th grade. His older brother Joe Jr. had already been at Choate for two years and was a football player and leading student. He spent his first years at Choate in his older brother's shadow, and compensated with rebellious behavior that attracted a coterie. They carried out their most notorious stunt by exploding a toilet seat with a powerful firecracker. In the ensuing chapel assembly, the strict headmaster, George St. John, brandished the toilet seat and spoke of certain "muckers" who would "spit in our sea". The defiant Kennedy took the cue and named his group "The Muckers Club", which included roommate and lifelong friend <a href="/wiki/Lem_Billings" title="Lem Billings">Kirk LeMoyne "Lem" Billings</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKenney200011_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKenney200011-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p><p>During his years at Choate, Kennedy was beset by health problems that culminated with his emergency hospitalization in 1934 at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yale%E2%80%93New_Haven_Hospital" title="Yale–New Haven Hospital">New Haven Hospital</a>, where doctors thought he might have had leukemia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dallek_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dallek-15">[15]</a></sup> In June 1934, he was admitted to the <a href="/wiki/Mayo_Clinic" title="Mayo Clinic">Mayo Clinic</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rochester,_Minnesota" title="Rochester, Minnesota">Rochester, Minnesota</a>; the ultimate diagnosis there was <a href="/wiki/Colitis" title="Colitis">colitis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dallek_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-Dallek-15">[15]</a></sup> Kennedy graduated from Choate in June of the following year, finishing 64th in a class of 112 students.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-John_F._Kennedy:_Early_Years_9-1"><a href="#cite_note-John_F._Kennedy:_Early_Years-9">[9]</a></sup> He had been the business manager of the school yearbook and was voted the "most likely to succeed".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKenney200011_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKenney200011-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BrooklineMA_JFKHouse.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="680" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/BrooklineMA_JFKHouse.jpg/250px-BrooklineMA_JFKHouse.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/BrooklineMA_JFKHouse.jpg/375px-BrooklineMA_JFKHouse.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/BrooklineMA_JFKHouse.jpg/500px-BrooklineMA_JFKHouse.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BrooklineMA_JFKHouse.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy's birthplace in Brookline, Massachusetts</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TheKennedyFamily1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="602" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/TheKennedyFamily1.jpg/250px-TheKennedyFamily1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/TheKennedyFamily1.jpg/375px-TheKennedyFamily1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/TheKennedyFamily1.jpg/500px-TheKennedyFamily1.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TheKennedyFamily1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Kennedy family at <a href="/wiki/Hyannis_Port,_Massachusetts" title="Hyannis Port, Massachusetts">Hyannis Port, Massachusetts</a>, in 1931 with Jack at top left in the white shirt. <a href="/wiki/Ted_Kennedy" title="Ted Kennedy">Ted</a> was born the following year.</div></div></div>
<p>In September 1935, Kennedy made his first trip abroad when he traveled to London with his parents and his sister Kathleen. He intended to study under <a href="/wiki/Harold_Laski" title="Harold Laski">Harold Laski</a> at the <a href="/wiki/London_School_of_Economics" title="London School of Economics">London School of Economics</a> (LSE), as his older brother had done. Ill-health forced his return to the United States in October of that year, when he enrolled late and attended <a href="/wiki/Princeton_University" title="Princeton University">Princeton University</a> but had to leave after two months due to a gastrointestinal illness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> He was then hospitalized for observation at <a href="/wiki/Brigham_and_Women%27s_Hospital" title="Brigham and Women's Hospital">Peter Bent Brigham Hospital</a> in Boston. He <a href="/wiki/Convalescence" title="Convalescence">convalesced</a> further at the family winter home in Palm Beach, then spent the spring of 1936 working as a ranch hand on the 40,000-acre Jay Six cattle ranch outside <a href="/wiki/Benson,_Arizona" title="Benson, Arizona">Benson, Arizona</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek200342_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek200342-17">[17]</a></sup> It is reported that ranchman <a href="/wiki/Jack_Speiden" title="Jack Speiden">Jack Speiden</a> worked both brothers "very hard".<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-The_"House_That_Jack_Built":_JFK_And_His_Late_Brother_Built_Adobe_Shack_For_Arizona_Rancher_18-0'><a href='#cite_note-The_"House_That_Jack_Built":_JFK_And_His_Late_Brother_Built_Adobe_Shack_For_Arizona_Rancher-18'>[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Civilian_Conservation_Corps_in_Southern_Arizona:_Jack_and_Joe_Kennedy_in_Arizona_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Civilian_Conservation_Corps_in_Southern_Arizona:_Jack_and_Joe_Kennedy_in_Arizona-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 1936, Kennedy enrolled at <a href="/wiki/Harvard_College" title="Harvard College">Harvard College</a> and his application essay stated: "The reasons that I have for wishing to go to Harvard are several. I feel that Harvard can give me a better background and a better liberal education than any other university. I have always wanted to go there, as I have felt that it is not just another college, but is a university with something definite to offer. Then too, I would like to go to the same college as my father. To be a 'Harvard man' is an enviable distinction, and one that I sincerely hope I shall attain."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> He produced that year's annual "Freshman Smoker", called by a reviewer "an elaborate entertainment, which included in its cast outstanding personalities of the radio, screen and sports world."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harvard_Crimson_1937_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harvard_Crimson_1937-21">[21]</a></sup> He tried out for the football, golf, and swimming teams and earned a spot on the varsity swimming team.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonovan20017_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonovan20017-22">[22]</a></sup> Kennedy also sailed in the <a href="/wiki/Star_(keelboat)" title="Star (keelboat)">Star class</a> and won the 1936 Nantucket Sound Star Championship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> In July 1937, Kennedy sailed to France—taking his convertible—and spent ten weeks driving through Europe with Billings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek200349_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek200349-24">[24]</a></sup> In June 1938, Kennedy sailed overseas with his father and older brother to work at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Embassy,_London" title="U.S. Embassy, London">American embassy in London</a>, where his father was President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>'s U.S. Ambassador to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Court_of_St._James%27s" title="Court of St. James's">Court of St. James's</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek200354_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek200354-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1939, Kennedy toured Europe, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>, and the Middle East in preparation for his Harvard senior honors thesis. He then went to <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovakia" title="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a> and Germany before returning to London on September 1, 1939, the day that <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">Germany invaded Poland</a> to mark the beginning of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. Two days later, the family was in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_House_of_Commons" title="British House of Commons">House of Commons</a> for speeches endorsing the United Kingdom's declaration of war on Germany. Kennedy was sent as his father's representative to help with arrangements for American survivors of the <a href="/wiki/SS_Athenia" title="SS Athenia">SS <i>Athenia</i></a> before flying back to the U.S. from <a href="/wiki/Foynes" title="Foynes">Foynes, Ireland</a>, to <a href="/wiki/Port_Washington,_New_York" title="Port Washington, New York">Port Washington, New York</a>, on his first transatlantic flight.
</p><p>When Kennedy was an upperclassman at Harvard, he began to take his studies more seriously and developed an interest in political philosophy. He made the <a href="/wiki/Dean%27s_List" title="Dean's List">Dean's List</a> in his junior year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harvard_Presidents_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harvard_Presidents-26">[26]</a></sup> In 1940, Kennedy completed his thesis, "Appeasement in Munich", about British participation in the <a href="/wiki/Munich_Agreement" title="Munich Agreement">Munich Agreement</a>. The thesis eventually became a bestseller under the title <i><a href="/wiki/Why_England_Slept" title="Why England Slept">Why England Slept</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek200361–66_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek200361–66-27">[27]</a></sup> In addition to addressing Britain's failure to strengthen its military in the lead-up to World War II, the book also called for an <a href="/wiki/Special_Relationship" title="Special Relationship">Anglo-American alliance</a> against the rising totalitarian powers. While Kennedy became increasingly supportive of U.S. intervention in World War II, his father's isolationist beliefs resulted in the latter's dismissal as ambassador to the United Kingdom, creating a split between the Kennedy and Roosevelt families.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201215–17_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201215–17-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1940, Kennedy graduated <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cum_laude" title="Cum laude">cum laude</a></i> from Harvard College with a <a href="/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts" title="Bachelor of Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> in government, concentrating on <a href="/wiki/International_relations" title="International relations">international affairs</a>. That fall, he enrolled at the <a href="/wiki/Stanford_Graduate_School_of_Business" title="Stanford Graduate School of Business">Stanford Graduate School of Business</a> and audited classes there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKenney200018_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKenney200018-29">[29]</a></sup> In early 1941, Kennedy left and helped his father write a memoir of his time as an American ambassador. He then traveled throughout South America; his itinerary included Colombia, Ecuador and Peru.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek200368_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek200368-30">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKenney200021_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKenney200021-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="U.S._Navy_Reserve_.281941.E2.80.931945.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="U.S._Navy_Reserve_(1941–1945)">U.S. Navy Reserve (1941–1945)</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Motor_Torpedo_Boat_PT-109" title="Motor Torpedo Boat PT-109">Motor Torpedo Boat PT-109</a></div>
<p>In 1940, Kennedy attempted to enter the army's <a href="/wiki/Officer_Candidate_School_(United_States_Army)" title="Officer Candidate School (United States Army)">Officer Candidate School</a>, but was medically disqualified due to his chronic lower back problems. He exercised for months to straighten his back. On September 24, 1941, with the help of the director of the <a href="/wiki/Office_of_Naval_Intelligence" title="Office of Naval Intelligence">Office of Naval Intelligence</a> (ONI)—who was the former naval <a href="/wiki/Attach%C3%A9" title="Attaché">attaché</a> to Joseph Kennedy—Kennedy joined the United States Naval Reserve. He was commissioned an <a href="/wiki/Ensign_(rank)" title="Ensign (rank)">ensign</a> on October 26, 1941,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VT_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-VT-32">[32]</a></sup> and joined the staff of the Office of Naval Intelligence in Washington, D.C.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maritimequest.com_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-maritimequest.com-33">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-history.navy.mil_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-history.navy.mil-34">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBallard200212,_36_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBallard200212,_36-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PT-109_crew.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="446" data-file-width="735" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/PT-109_crew.jpg/220px-PT-109_crew.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/PT-109_crew.jpg/330px-PT-109_crew.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/PT-109_crew.jpg/440px-PT-109_crew.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PT-109_crew.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_(junior_grade)" title="Lieutenant (junior grade)">Lieutenant (junior grade)</a> Kennedy (standing at right) with his <i>PT-109</i> crew, 1943</div></div></div>
<p>In January 1942, Kennedy was assigned to the ONI field office at Headquarters, Sixth Naval District, in Charleston, South Carolina.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-history.navy.mil_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-history.navy.mil-34">[34]</a></sup> He attended the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Naval_Reserve_Officer_Training_Corps" title="Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps">Naval Reserve Officer Training School</a> at <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_University" title="Northwestern University">Northwestern University</a> in Chicago, Illinois, from July 27 to September 27 <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maritimequest.com_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-maritimequest.com-33">[33]</a></sup> and then voluntarily entered the <a href="/wiki/Motor_Torpedo_Boat_Squadrons_Training_Center" title="Motor Torpedo Boat Squadrons Training Center">Motor Torpedo Boat Squadrons Training Center</a> in <a href="/wiki/Melville,_Rhode_Island" title="Melville, Rhode Island">Melville, Rhode Island</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-history.navy.mil_34-2"><a href="#cite_note-history.navy.mil-34">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonovan200119,_20_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonovan200119,_20-36">[36]</a></sup> On October 10, he was promoted to <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant_(junior_grade)" title="Lieutenant (junior grade)">lieutenant junior grade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-history.navy.mil_34-3"><a href="#cite_note-history.navy.mil-34">[34]</a></sup> In early November, Kennedy was still mourning the death of his close, childhood friend, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Marine_Corps" title="U.S. Marine Corps">Marine Corps</a> Second Lieutenant George Houk Mead Jr., who had been killed in action at <a href="/wiki/Guadalcanal" title="Guadalcanal">Guadalcanal</a> that August and posthumously awarded the <a href="/wiki/Navy_Cross" title="Navy Cross">Navy Cross</a> for his bravery. Accompanied by a female acquaintance from a wealthy <a href="/wiki/Newport,_Rhode_Island" title="Newport, Rhode Island">Newport</a> family, the couple had stopped in <a href="/wiki/Middletown,_Rhode_Island" title="Middletown, Rhode Island">Middletown, Rhode Island</a> at the cemetery where the decorated, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Navy" title="U.S. Navy">naval</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spy" title="Spy">spy</a>, Commander <a href="/wiki/Hugo_W._Koehler" title="Hugo W. Koehler">Hugo W. Koehler</a>, USN, had been buried the previous year. Ambling around the plots near the tiny <a href="/wiki/St._Columba%27s_Chapel_(Middletown,_Rhode_Island)" title="St. Columba's Chapel (Middletown, Rhode Island)">St. Columba's chapel</a>, Kennedy paused over Koehler's white granite cross grave marker and pondered his own mortality, hoping out loud that when his time came, he would not have to die without religion. "But these things can't be faked," he added. "There's no bluffing."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> Two decades later, Kennedy and Koehler's stepson, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Senator" title="U.S. Senator">U.S. Senator</a> <a href="/wiki/Claiborne_Pell" title="Claiborne Pell">Claiborne Pell</a> had become good friends and political allies, although they had been acquaintances since the mid-1930s during their "<a href="/wiki/Salad_days" title="Salad days">salad days</a>" on the same Newport <a href="/wiki/Debutante" title="Debutante">debutante</a> party "circuit" and when Pell had dated Kathleen ("Kick") Kennedy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> Kennedy completed his training on December 2 and was assigned to Motor Torpedo Squadron FOUR.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maritimequest.com_33-2"><a href="#cite_note-maritimequest.com-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>His first command was <i>PT-101</i> from December 7, 1942, until February 23, 1943:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-history.navy.mil_34-4"><a href="#cite_note-history.navy.mil-34">[34]</a></sup> It was a <a href="/wiki/PT_boat" title="PT boat">patrol torpedo (PT) boat</a> used for training while Kennedy was an instructor at Melville.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonovan200120_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonovan200120-39">[39]</a></sup> He then led three Huckins PT boats—<i>PT-98</i>, <i>PT-99</i>, and <i>PT-101</i>, which were being relocated from MTBRON 4 in Melville, Rhode Island, back to Jacksonville, Florida, and the new MTBRON 14 (formed February 17, 1943). During the trip south, he was hospitalized briefly in Jacksonville after diving into the cold water to unfoul a propeller. Thereafter, Kennedy was assigned duty in <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a> and later in the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_War" title="Pacific War">Pacific theater</a>, where he eventually commanded two more PT boats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Commanding_the_PT-109">Commanding the <i>PT-109</i></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lt._John_F._Kennedy_aboard_the_PT-109.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1094" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="245" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Lt._John_F._Kennedy_aboard_the_PT-109.jpg/170px-Lt._John_F._Kennedy_aboard_the_PT-109.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Lt._John_F._Kennedy_aboard_the_PT-109.jpg/255px-Lt._John_F._Kennedy_aboard_the_PT-109.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Lt._John_F._Kennedy_aboard_the_PT-109.jpg/340px-Lt._John_F._Kennedy_aboard_the_PT-109.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lt._John_F._Kennedy_aboard_the_PT-109.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy on his navy patrol boat, the <a href="/wiki/Motor_Torpedo_Boat_PT-109" title="Motor Torpedo Boat PT-109"><i>PT-109</i></a>, 1943</div></div></div>
<p>In April 1943, Kennedy was assigned to Motor Torpedo Squadron TWO.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maritimequest.com_33-3"><a href="#cite_note-maritimequest.com-33">[33]</a></sup> On April 24, he took command of <i><a href="/wiki/Motor_Torpedo_Boat_PT-109" title="Motor Torpedo Boat PT-109">PT-109</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> which was based at the time on <a href="/wiki/Tulagi" title="Tulagi">Tulagi Island</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands" title="Solomon Islands">Solomons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-history.navy.mil_34-5"><a href="#cite_note-history.navy.mil-34">[34]</a></sup> On the night of August 1–2, <i>PT-109</i> was on its 31st mission with a total of fourteen other PT's ordered to block or repel four Japanese destroyers and float planes carrying food, supplies, and 900 Japanese soldiers to the Vila Plantation garrison on the southern tip of the Solomon's <a href="/wiki/Kolombangara" title="Kolombangara">Kolombangara Island</a>.  Intelligence had been sent to Kennedy's base commander, Commander Thomas G. Warfield expecting the arrival of the large Japanese Naval force that would pass on the evening of August 1.  Of the 24 torpedoes fired that night by eight of the American PT's, not one hit the Japanese convoy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonovan200199,_100_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonovan200199,_100-42">[42]</a></sup> On that dark and moonless night, Kennedy spotted a Japanese destroyer heading North on its return from the base of Kolombangara around 2:00 a.m., and attempted to turn to attack, when <i>PT-109</i> was rammed suddenly at an angle and cut in half by the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_destroyer_Amagiri_(1930)" title="Japanese destroyer Amagiri (1930)">destroyer <i>Amagiri</i></a>, costing two <i>PT-109</i> crew members<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> their lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonovan2001106_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonovan2001106-44">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-history.navy.mil_34-6"><a href="#cite_note-history.navy.mil-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy gathered around the wreckage his surviving ten crew members to vote on whether to "fight or surrender". Kennedy stated: "There's nothing in the book about a situation like this. A lot of you men have families and some of you have children. What do you want to do? I have nothing to lose." Shunning surrender, around 2:00 p.m. on August 2, the men swam towards Plum Pudding island 3.5 miles (5.6 km) southwest of the remains of the <i>PT-109</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-history.navy.mil_34-7"><a href="#cite_note-history.navy.mil-34">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonovan2001106–107,_119_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonovan2001106–107,_119-45">[45]</a></sup> Despite re-injuring his back in the collision, Kennedy towed a badly burned crewman through the water to the island with a life jacket strap clenched between his teeth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonovan2001106–107,_124_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonovan2001106–107,_124-46">[46]</a></sup> Kennedy made an additional two-mile swim the night of August 2, 1943, to Ferguson Passage to attempt to hail a passing American PT boat to expedite his crew's rescue and attempted to make the trip on a subsequent night, in a damaged canoe found on Naru Island where he had swum with Ensign George Ross to look for food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoyle201566-106,_134–139_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoyle201566-106,_134–139-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 4, he and Lenny Thom assisted his injured and hungry crew on a demanding swim 3.75 miles (6.04 km) southeast to Olasana Island, which was visible to the crew from their desolate home on Plum Pudding Island. They swam against a strong current, and once again Kennedy towed the badly burned motor machinist "Pappy" MacMahon by his life vest. The somewhat larger Olasana Island had ripe coconut trees, but still no fresh water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-48">[48]</a></sup> On the following day, August 5, Kennedy and Ensign George Ross made the one hour swim to Naru Island, an additional distance of about .5 miles (0.80 km) southwest, in search of help and food. Kennedy and Ross found a small canoe, packages of crackers, candy and a fifty-gallon drum of drinkable water left by the Japanese, which Kennedy paddled another half mile back to Olasana in the acquired canoe to provide his hungry crew. Lieutenant "Bud" Liebenow, a friend and former tentmate of Kennedy's, rescued Kennedy and his crew on Olasana Island on August 8, 1943 aboard his ship, the <i>PT-157</i>, with the help of coast watcher Lieutenant Reginald Evans and several native coast watchers, particularly <a href="/wiki/Biuku_Gasa_and_Eroni_Kumana" title="Biuku Gasa and Eroni Kumana">Biuku Gasa and Eroni Kumana</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoyle2015143–148_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoyle2015143–148-49">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Commanding_the_PT-59">Commanding the <i>PT-59</i></span></h3>
<p>Taking only a month to recover, on September 1, 1943, Kennedy returned to duty and took command of the <i><a href="/wiki/Motor_Torpedo_Boat_PT-59" title="Motor Torpedo Boat PT-59">PT-59</a></i>, first removing the torpedo tubes and depth charges and refitting her in one month into a heavily armed gunboat bristling with two large automatic 40 cal and ten automatic 50 caliber guns. The plan was to attach one gunboat to each PT boat section to add gun range and power against barges and shore batteries which the <i>59</i> encountered on several occasions in mid October through mid November.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoyle2015181,_187_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoyle2015181,_187-53">[53]</a></sup> On October 8, Kennedy was promoted to full lieutenant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoyle2015182_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoyle2015182-54">[54]</a></sup> On November 2, Kennedy's <i>PT-59</i> took part with two other PT's in the successful rescue of 40-50 marines.  The <i>59</i> acted as a shield from shore fire and protected them as they escaped on two rescue landing craft at the base of the Warrior River at <a href="/wiki/Raid_on_Choiseul" title="Raid on Choiseul">Choiseul Island</a>, taking ten marines aboard and delivering them to safety.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonovan2001172–184_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonovan2001172–184-55">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDonovan2001189_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonovan2001189-56">[56]</a></sup> Under doctor's orders, Kennedy was relieved of his command of <i>PT-59</i> on November 18, and sent to the hospital on Tulagi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoyle2015193_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoyle2015193-57">[57]</a></sup> From there he returned to the United States in early January 1944. After receiving treatment for his back injury, he was released from active duty in late 1944.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy was hospitalized at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chelsea_Naval_Hospital" title="Chelsea Naval Hospital">Chelsea Naval Hospital</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chelsea,_Massachusetts" title="Chelsea, Massachusetts">Chelsea, Massachusetts</a> from May to December 1944.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maritimequest.com_33-4"><a href="#cite_note-maritimequest.com-33">[33]</a></sup> On June 12, he was presented the Navy and Marine Corps Medal for his heroic actions on August 1–2, 1943, and the Purple Heart Medal for his back injury while on <i>PT-109</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sptimes.com_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-sptimes.com-59">[59]</a></sup>  Beginning in January 1945, Kennedy spent three more months recovering from his back injury at <a href="/wiki/Castle_Hot_Springs_(Arizona)" title="Castle Hot Springs (Arizona)">Castle Hot Springs</a>, a resort and temporary military hospital in Arizona.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005179,_180_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005179,_180-60">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-peoriaaz.gov_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-peoriaaz.gov-61">[61]</a></sup> After the war, Kennedy felt that the medal he had received for heroism was not a combat award and asked that he be reconsidered for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Silver_Star_Medal" title="Silver Star Medal">Silver Star Medal</a> for which he had been recommended initially. His father also requested the Silver Star, which is awarded for gallantry in action, for his son. In 1950, The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Department_of_the_Navy" title="Department of the Navy">Department of the Navy</a> offered Kennedy a <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Star_Medal" title="Bronze Star Medal">Bronze Star Medal</a> in recognition of his meritorious service, which he declined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> Kennedy's two original medals are currently on display at the <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Presidential_Library_and_Museum" title="John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum">John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 12, 1944, Kennedy's older brother, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joseph_P._Kennedy,_Jr." title="Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr.">Joe Jr.</a>, a navy pilot, was killed while volunteering for a special and hazardous air mission. His <a href="/wiki/Operation_Aphrodite" title="Operation Aphrodite">explosive-laden plane</a> blew up when the plane's bombs detonated prematurely while the aircraft was flying over the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 1, 1945, Kennedy retired from the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy_Reserve" title="United States Navy Reserve">Navy Reserve</a> on physical disability and was honorably discharged with the full rank of <a href="/wiki/Lieutenant" title="Lieutenant">lieutenant</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sptimes.com_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-sptimes.com-59">[59]</a></sup> When later asked how he became a war hero, Kennedy joked: "It was easy. They cut my <a href="/wiki/PT_boat" title="PT boat">PT boat</a> in half."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek200398_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek200398-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_awards">Military awards</span></h3>
<p>Kennedy's military decorations and awards include the Navy and Marine Corps Medal; Purple Heart Medal; <a href="/wiki/American_Defense_Service_Medal" title="American Defense Service Medal">American Defense Service Medal</a>; <a href="/wiki/American_Campaign_Medal" title="American Campaign Medal">American Campaign Medal</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal" title="Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal">Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal</a> with three <a href="/wiki/Service_star" title="Service star">​<span class="frac nowrap"><sup>3</sup>⁄<sub>16</sub></span>" bronze stars</a>; and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_War_II_Victory_Medal" title="World War II Victory Medal">World War II Victory Medal</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_misc_1-3"><a href="#cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_misc-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p>
<table style="margin: 1em auto;">
<tbody><tr>

<td><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:American_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="279" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/American_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg/103px-American_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/American_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg/155px-American_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/American_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg/206px-American_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg.png 2x" width="103"/></a>
</td>
<td><div style="position:relative; width:103px; border:none; line-height:1.5em; display:-moz-inline-stack; display:inline-block; zoom:1; *display:inline;"><div style="position:relative; display:inline-block;"><div style="position: absolute; left: 13px; top: 5px; padding: 0;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg" title="Bronze service star"><img alt="Bronze star" data-file-height="144" data-file-width="146" decoding="async" height="18" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg/18px-Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg/27px-Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg/36px-Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg.png 2x" width="18"/></a></div><div style="position: absolute; left: 43px; top: 5px; padding: 0;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg" title="Bronze service star"><img alt="Bronze star" data-file-height="144" data-file-width="146" decoding="async" height="18" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg/18px-Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg/27px-Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg/36px-Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg.png 2x" width="18"/></a></div><div style="position: absolute; left: 73px; top: 5px; padding: 0;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg" title="Bronze service star"><img alt="Bronze star" data-file-height="144" data-file-width="146" decoding="async" height="18" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg/18px-Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg/27px-Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg/36px-Bronze-service-star-3d-vector.svg.png 2x" width="18"/></a></div><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="279" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg/103px-Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg/155px-Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg/206px-Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal_ribbon.svg.png 2x" width="103"/></a></div></div>
</td>
<td><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="29" data-file-width="106" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg/103px-World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg/155px-World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg/206px-World_War_II_Victory_Medal_ribbon.svg.png 2x" width="103"/></a>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto; text-align: center;">
<tbody><tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Navy_and_Marine_Corps_Medal" title="Navy and Marine Corps Medal">Navy and Marine Corps Medal</a>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Purple_Heart" title="Purple Heart">Purple Heart</a>
</td>

</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/American_Campaign_Medal" title="American Campaign Medal">American Campaign Medal</a>
</td>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asiatic-Pacific_Campaign_Medal" title="Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal">Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal</a><br/>with three <a href="/wiki/Service_star" title="Service star">stars</a>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/World_War_II_Victory_Medal_(United_States)" title="World War II Victory Medal (United States)">World War II Victory Medal</a>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Navy_and_Marine_Corps_Medal_citation">Navy and Marine Corps Medal citation</span></h4>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303468">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>For extremely heroic conduct as Commanding Officer of Motor Torpedo Boat 109 following the collision and sinking of that vessel in the Pacific War area on August 1–2, 1943. Unmindful of personal danger, Lieutenant (then <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lieutenant,_Junior_Grade" title="Lieutenant, Junior Grade">Lieutenant, Junior Grade</a>) Kennedy unhesitatingly braved the difficulties and hazards of darkness to direct rescue operations, swimming many hours to secure aid and food after he had succeeded in getting his crew ashore. His outstanding courage, endurance and leadership contributed to the saving of several lives and were in keeping with the highest traditions of the United States Naval Service.</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><a href="/wiki/James_Forrestal" title="James Forrestal">James Forrestal</a>, Secretary of the Navy<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup></cite></div>
</blockquote>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Journalism">Journalism</span></h2>
<p>In April 1945, Kennedy's father, who was a friend of <a href="/wiki/William_Randolph_Hearst" title="William Randolph Hearst">William Randolph Hearst</a>, arranged a position for his son as a special correspondent for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hearst_Newspapers" title="Hearst Newspapers">Hearst Newspapers</a>; the assignment kept Kennedy's name in the public eye and "expose[d] him to journalism as a possible career."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005180_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005180-67">[67]</a></sup> He worked as a correspondent that May, covering the <a href="/wiki/Potsdam_Conference" title="Potsdam Conference">Potsdam Conference</a> and other events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003104_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003104-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Congressional_career_.281947.E2.80.931960.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Congressional_career_(1947–1960)">Congressional career (1947–1960)</span></h2>
<p>JFK's elder brother Joe had been the <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_family" title="Kennedy family">family's political standard-bearer</a> and had been tapped by their father to seek the Presidency. Joe's death during the war in 1944 changed that course and the task now fell to the second eldest of the Kennedy siblings – John F. Kennedy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003118_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003118-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="House_of_Representatives_.281947.E2.80.931953.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="House_of_Representatives_(1947–1953)">House of Representatives (1947–1953)</span></h3>
<p>At the urging of Kennedy's father, U.S. Representative <a href="/wiki/James_Michael_Curley" title="James Michael Curley">James Michael Curley</a> vacated his seat in the strongly Democratic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/11th_congressional_district_of_Massachusetts" title="11th congressional district of Massachusetts">11th congressional district of Massachusetts</a> to become mayor of Boston in 1946. With his father financing and running his campaign, Kennedy won the Democratic primary with 12 percent of the vote, defeating ten other candidates. Though Republicans took control of the House in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections,_1946" title="United States House of Representatives elections, 1946">1946 elections</a>, Kennedy defeated his Republican opponent in the general election, taking 73 percent of the vote. Along with <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Joseph_McCarthy" title="Joseph McCarthy">Joseph McCarthy</a>, Kennedy was one of several World War II veterans first elected to Congress that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201224–26_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201224–26-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>He served in the House for six years, joining the influential <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_Education_and_the_Workforce" title="United States House Committee on Education and the Workforce">Education and Labor Committee</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_Veterans%27_Affairs" title="United States House Committee on Veterans' Affairs">Veterans' Affairs Committee</a>. He concentrated his attention on international affairs, supporting the <a href="/wiki/Truman_Doctrine" title="Truman Doctrine">Truman Doctrine</a> as the appropriate response to the emerging <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>. He also supported <a href="/wiki/Public_housing" title="Public housing">public housing</a> and opposed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labor_Management_Relations_Act_of_1947" title="Labor Management Relations Act of 1947">Labor Management Relations Act of 1947</a>, which restricted the power of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labor_union" title="Labor union">labor unions</a>. Though not as vocal an anticommunist as McCarthy, Congressman Kennedy supported the <a href="/wiki/Immigration_and_Nationality_Act_of_1952" title="Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952">Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952</a>, which required Communists to register with the government, and he deplored the "<a href="/wiki/Loss_of_China" title="Loss of China">Loss of China</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201226–29_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201226–29-71">[71]</a></sup> Having served as a Boy Scout during his childhood, Kennedy was active in the <a href="/wiki/Scouting_in_Massachusetts" title="Scouting in Massachusetts">Boston Council</a> from 1946 to 1955: as District Vice Chairman, member of the Executive Board, Vice-President, as well as a National Council Representative.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Senate_.281953.E2.80.931960.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Senate_(1953–1960)">Senate (1953–1960)</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/1952_United_States_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts" title="1952 United States Senate election in Massachusetts">1952 United States Senate election in Massachusetts</a> and <a href="/wiki/1958_United_States_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts" title="1958 United States Senate election in Massachusetts">1958 United States Senate election in Massachusetts</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1952_US_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts_results_by_municipality.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1300" data-file-width="2100" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/1952_US_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts_results_by_municipality.svg/240px-1952_US_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts_results_by_municipality.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/1952_US_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts_results_by_municipality.svg/360px-1952_US_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts_results_by_municipality.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/1952_US_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts_results_by_municipality.svg/480px-1952_US_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts_results_by_municipality.svg.png 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1952_US_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts_results_by_municipality.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Results of the 1952 U.S. Senate election in Massachusetts</div></div></div>
<p>As early as 1949, Kennedy began preparing to run for the Senate in <a href="/wiki/1952_United_States_Senate_election_in_Massachusetts" title="1952 United States Senate election in Massachusetts">1952</a> against Republican three-term incumbent <a href="/wiki/Henry_Cabot_Lodge_Jr." title="Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.">Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.</a> with the campaign slogan "Kennedy Will Do <i>More</i> for Massachusetts".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005254_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005254-74">[74]</a></sup> Joseph Kennedy again financed and managed his son's candidacy, while John Kennedy's younger brother <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Robert_Kennedy" title="Robert Kennedy">Robert Kennedy</a> emerged as an important member of the campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201229–31_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201229–31-75">[75]</a></sup> In the presidential election, General <a href="/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower" title="Dwight D. Eisenhower">Dwight D. Eisenhower</a> carried Massachusetts by a margin of 208,000 votes, but Kennedy defeated Lodge by 70,000 votes for the Senate seat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-John_F._Kennedy_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-John_F._Kennedy-76">[76]</a></sup> The following year, he married <a href="/wiki/Jacqueline_Kennedy_Onassis" title="Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis">Jacqueline Bouvier</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKenney200029_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKenney200029-77">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_after_spinal_surgery_cph.3c33052.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3528" data-file-width="2778" decoding="async" height="216" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/John_F._Kennedy_after_spinal_surgery_cph.3c33052.jpg/170px-John_F._Kennedy_after_spinal_surgery_cph.3c33052.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/John_F._Kennedy_after_spinal_surgery_cph.3c33052.jpg/255px-John_F._Kennedy_after_spinal_surgery_cph.3c33052.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/John_F._Kennedy_after_spinal_surgery_cph.3c33052.jpg/340px-John_F._Kennedy_after_spinal_surgery_cph.3c33052.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_after_spinal_surgery_cph.3c33052.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy lying on a gurney following spinal surgery, accompanied by Jackie, December 1954</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_nominates_Adlai_Stevenson_1956_(cropped).JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="651" data-file-width="650" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/John_F._Kennedy_nominates_Adlai_Stevenson_1956_%28cropped%29.JPG/170px-John_F._Kennedy_nominates_Adlai_Stevenson_1956_%28cropped%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/John_F._Kennedy_nominates_Adlai_Stevenson_1956_%28cropped%29.JPG/255px-John_F._Kennedy_nominates_Adlai_Stevenson_1956_%28cropped%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/John_F._Kennedy_nominates_Adlai_Stevenson_1956_%28cropped%29.JPG/340px-John_F._Kennedy_nominates_Adlai_Stevenson_1956_%28cropped%29.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_nominates_Adlai_Stevenson_1956_(cropped).JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy endorsing <a href="/wiki/Adlai_Stevenson_II" title="Adlai Stevenson II">Adlai Stevenson II</a> for the presidential nomination at the <a href="/wiki/1956_Democratic_National_Convention" title="1956 Democratic National Convention">1956 Democratic National Convention</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a></div></div></div>
<p>Kennedy underwent several spinal operations over the next two years. Often absent from the Senate, he was at times critically ill and received Catholic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anointing_of_the_Sick" title="Anointing of the Sick">last rites</a>. During his convalescence in 1956, he published <i><a href="/wiki/Profiles_in_Courage" title="Profiles in Courage">Profiles in Courage</a></i>, a book about U.S. senators who risked their careers for their personal beliefs, for which he won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize_for_Biography" title="Pulitzer Prize for Biography">Pulitzer Prize for Biography</a> in 1957.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jean3_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jean3-78">[78]</a></sup> Rumors that this work was co-written by his close adviser and <a href="/wiki/Speechwriter" title="Speechwriter">speechwriter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ted_Sorensen" title="Ted Sorensen">Ted Sorensen</a>, were confirmed in Sorensen's 2008 autobiography.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the <a href="/wiki/1956_Democratic_National_Convention" title="1956 Democratic National Convention">1956 Democratic National Convention</a>, Senator Kennedy gave the nominating speech for the party's presidential nominee, <a href="/wiki/Adlai_Stevenson_II" title="Adlai Stevenson II">Adlai Stevenson II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201234–35_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201234–35-80">[80]</a></sup> Stevenson let the convention select the Vice Presidential nominee. Kennedy finished second in the balloting, losing to Senator <a href="/wiki/Estes_Kefauver" title="Estes Kefauver">Estes Kefauver</a> of Tennessee but receiving national exposure as a result.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>One of the matters demanding Kennedy's attention in the Senate was President Eisenhower's bill for the <a href="/wiki/Civil_Rights_Act_of_1957" title="Civil Rights Act of 1957">Civil Rights Act of 1957</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005370_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005370-82">[82]</a></sup> Kennedy cast a procedural vote on this, which was considered by some as an appeasement of Southern Democratic opponents of the bill.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005370_82-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005370-82">[82]</a></sup> Kennedy did vote for Title III of the act, which would have given the Attorney General powers to enjoin, but Majority Leader <a href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Lyndon B. Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a> agreed to let the provision die as a compromise measure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005370,_371_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005370,_371-83">[83]</a></sup> Kennedy also voted for Title IV, termed the "Jury Trial Amendment". Many civil rights advocates at the time criticized that vote as one which would weaken the act.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005372_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005372-84">[84]</a></sup> A final compromise bill, which Kennedy supported, was passed in September 1957.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005374_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005374-85">[85]</a></sup> The following year, Kennedy authored <i><a href="/wiki/A_Nation_of_Immigrants" title="A Nation of Immigrants">A Nation of Immigrants</a></i> (later published in 1964), which analyzed the importance of immigration in the country's history as well as proposals to re-evaluate <a href="/wiki/Immigration_law" title="Immigration law">immigration law</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_Jack_Paar_Tonight_Show_1959.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="556" data-file-width="745" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/John_F._Kennedy_Jack_Paar_Tonight_Show_1959.JPG/220px-John_F._Kennedy_Jack_Paar_Tonight_Show_1959.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/John_F._Kennedy_Jack_Paar_Tonight_Show_1959.JPG/330px-John_F._Kennedy_Jack_Paar_Tonight_Show_1959.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/John_F._Kennedy_Jack_Paar_Tonight_Show_1959.JPG/440px-John_F._Kennedy_Jack_Paar_Tonight_Show_1959.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_Jack_Paar_Tonight_Show_1959.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Jack_Paar" title="Jack Paar">Jack Paar</a> interviews Senator Kennedy on <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tonight_Show" title="The Tonight Show">The Tonight Show</a></i> (1959)</div></div></div>
<p>In 1958, Kennedy was re-elected to a second term in the Senate, defeating his Republican opponent, Boston lawyer Vincent J. Celeste, by a wide margin of 874,608 votes; this represented the largest ever margin in Massachusetts politics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-John_F._Kennedy_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-John_F._Kennedy-76">[76]</a></sup> It was during his re-election campaign that Kennedy's press secretary at the time, <a href="/wiki/Robert_E._Thompson" title="Robert E. Thompson">Robert E. Thompson</a>, put together a film entitled <i>The U.S. Senator John F. Kennedy Story</i>, which exhibited a day in the life of the Senator and showcased his family life as well as the inner workings of his office. It was the most comprehensive film produced about Kennedy up to that time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> In the aftermath of his re-election, Kennedy began preparing to run for president in 1960.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201235–36_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201235–36-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>While Kennedy's father was a strong supporter of Senator Joseph McCarthy, McCarthy was also a friend of the Kennedy family. Bobby Kennedy worked for McCarthy's subcommittee, and McCarthy dated Kennedy sister Patricia. In 1954, the Senate voted to censure McCarthy, and Kennedy drafted a speech supporting the censure. However, it was not delivered because Kennedy was hospitalized at the time. The speech had the potential of putting Kennedy in the position of participating procedurally by "pairing" his vote against that of another senator. Although Kennedy never indicated how he would have voted, the episode damaged his support among members of the <a href="/wiki/Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States" title="Modern liberalism in the United States">liberal</a> community, including <a href="/wiki/Eleanor_Roosevelt" title="Eleanor Roosevelt">Eleanor Roosevelt</a>, in the 1956 and 1960 elections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005274–79,_394–99_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005274–79,_394–99-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="1960_presidential_election">1960 presidential election</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/1960_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries" title="1960 Democratic Party presidential primaries">1960 Democratic Party presidential primaries</a> and <a href="/wiki/1960_United_States_presidential_election" title="1960 United States presidential election">1960 United States presidential election</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jfk-appleton.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="470" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Jfk-appleton.jpg/220px-Jfk-appleton.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Jfk-appleton.jpg/330px-Jfk-appleton.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Jfk-appleton.jpg/440px-Jfk-appleton.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jfk-appleton.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy campaigns with his wife Jacqueline in <a href="/wiki/Appleton,_Wisconsin" title="Appleton, Wisconsin">Appleton, Wisconsin</a>, March 1960</div></div></div>
<p>On January 2, 1960, Kennedy announced his candidacy for the <a href="/wiki/1960_Democratic_Party_presidential_primaries" title="1960 Democratic Party presidential primaries">Democratic presidential nomination</a>. Though some questioned Kennedy's youth and experience, his charisma and eloquence earned him numerous supporters. His greatest obstacle to winning the nomination may have been his religion. Many Americans held <a href="/wiki/Anti-Catholicism_in_the_United_States" title="Anti-Catholicism in the United States">anti-Catholic attitudes</a>, but Kennedy's vocal support of the <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_church_and_state_in_the_United_States" title="Separation of church and state in the United States">separation of church and state</a> helped defuse the situation. His religion also helped him win a devoted following among many Catholic voters. Kennedy faced several potential challengers for the Democratic nomination, including Senate Majority Leader <a href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson" title="Lyndon B. Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adlai_Stevenson_II" title="Adlai Stevenson II">Adlai Stevenson II</a>, and Senator <a href="/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey" title="Hubert Humphrey">Hubert Humphrey</a>.
