Kennedy traveled extensively to build his support among Democratic elites and voters. At the time, party officials controlled most of the delegates, but several states also held primaries, and Kennedy sought to win several primaries to boost his chances of winning the nomination. In his first major test, Kennedy won the Wisconsin primary, effectively ending Humphrey's hopes of winning the presidency. Nonetheless, Kennedy and Humphrey faced each other in a competitive West Virginia primary in which Kennedy could not benefit from a Catholic bloc, as he had in Wisconsin. Kennedy won the West Virginia primary, impressing many in the party, but at the start of the <a href="/wiki/1960_Democratic_National_Convention" title="1960 Democratic National Convention">1960 Democratic National Convention</a>, it was unclear as to whether he would win the nomination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201238–45_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201238–45-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kennedy_Nixon_Debat_(1960).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="810" data-file-width="1194" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Kennedy_Nixon_Debat_%281960%29.jpg/220px-Kennedy_Nixon_Debat_%281960%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Kennedy_Nixon_Debat_%281960%29.jpg/330px-Kennedy_Nixon_Debat_%281960%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Kennedy_Nixon_Debat_%281960%29.jpg/440px-Kennedy_Nixon_Debat_%281960%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kennedy_Nixon_Debat_(1960).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy and Richard Nixon participate in the nation's first televised <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election_debates#1960_Kennedy–Nixon_debates" title="United States presidential election debates">presidential debate</a>, Washington, D.C., 1960</div></div></div>
<p>When Kennedy entered the convention, he had the most delegates, but not enough to ensure that he would win the nomination. Stevenson—the 1952 and 1956 presidential nominee—remained very popular in the party, while Johnson also hoped to win the nomination with the support from party leaders. Kennedy's candidacy also faced opposition from former president <a href="/wiki/Harry_S._Truman" title="Harry S. Truman">Harry S. Truman</a>, who was concerned about Kennedy's lack of experience. Kennedy knew that a second ballot could give the nomination to Johnson or someone else, and his well-organized campaign was able to earn the support of just enough delegates to win the presidential nomination on the first ballot.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201245–47_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201245–47-91">[91]</a></sup> Kennedy ignored the opposition of his brother, who wanted him to choose labor leader <a href="/wiki/Walter_Reuther" title="Walter Reuther">Walter Reuther</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> and other liberal supporters when he <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_vice_presidential_candidate_selection,_1960" title="Democratic Party vice presidential candidate selection, 1960">chose Johnson</a> as his vice presidential nominee. He believed that the Texas Senator could help him win support from the <a href="/wiki/Southern_United_States" title="Southern United States">South</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201247_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201247-93">[93]</a></sup> The choice infuriated many in labor. AFL-CIO President <a href="/wiki/George_Meany" title="George Meany">George Meany</a> called Johnson "the arch foe of labor," while Illinois AFL-CIO President <a href="/wiki/Reuben_G._Soderstrom" title="Reuben G. Soderstrom">Reuben Soderstrom</a> asserted Kennedy had "made chumps out of leaders of the American labor movement."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> In accepting the presidential nomination, Kennedy gave his well-known "<a href="/wiki/New_Frontier" title="New Frontier">New Frontier</a>" speech, saying, "For the problems are not all solved and the battles are not all won—and we stand today on the edge of a New Frontier. ... But the New Frontier of which I speak is not a set of promises—it is a set of challenges. It sums up not what I intend to offer the American people, but what I intend to ask of them."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_Accepting_Dem_Nom_Pres_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_Accepting_Dem_Nom_Pres-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Eisenhower_and_Kennedy.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="911" data-file-width="1165" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Eisenhower_and_Kennedy.jpg/220px-Eisenhower_and_Kennedy.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Eisenhower_and_Kennedy.jpg/330px-Eisenhower_and_Kennedy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Eisenhower_and_Kennedy.jpg/440px-Eisenhower_and_Kennedy.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Eisenhower_and_Kennedy.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Outgoing President <a href="/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower" title="Dwight D. Eisenhower">Dwight D. Eisenhower</a> meets with President-elect John F. Kennedy on December 6, 1960</div></div></div>
<p>At the start of the fall general election campaign, Republican nominee and incumbent vice president Richard Nixon held a six-point lead in the polls.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201249_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrinkley201249-97">[97]</a></sup> Major issues included how to get the economy moving again, Kennedy's Roman Catholicism, the <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Revolution" title="Cuban Revolution">Cuban Revolution</a>, and whether the space and missile programs of the Soviet Union had surpassed those of the U.S. To address fears that his being Catholic would impact his decision-making, he famously told the Greater Houston Ministerial Association on September 12, 1960: "I am not the Catholic candidate for president. I am the Democratic Party candidate for president who also happens to be a Catholic. I do not speak for my Church on public matters – and the Church does not speak for me."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> Kennedy questioned rhetorically whether one-quarter of Americans were relegated to second-class citizenship just because they were Catholic, and once stated that "[n]o one asked me my religion [serving the Navy] in the South Pacific."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199315_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199315-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between September and October, Kennedy squared off against Nixon in the first televised <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._presidential_election_debates" title="U.S. presidential election debates">presidential debates</a> in U.S. history. During these programs, Nixon had an injured leg, "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Five_o%27clock_shadow" title="Five o'clock shadow">five o'clock shadow</a>", and was perspiring, making him look tense and uncomfortable. Conversely, Kennedy wore makeup and appeared relaxed, which helped the large television audience to view him as the winner. On average radio listeners thought that Nixon had won or that the debates were a draw.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> The debates are now considered a milestone in American political history—the point at which the medium of television began to play a dominant role in politics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jean3_78-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jean3-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege1960.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="1020" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/ElectoralCollege1960.svg/280px-ElectoralCollege1960.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/ElectoralCollege1960.svg/420px-ElectoralCollege1960.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/ElectoralCollege1960.svg/560px-ElectoralCollege1960.svg.png 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ElectoralCollege1960.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1960 electoral vote results</div></div></div>
<p>Kennedy's campaign gained momentum after the first debate, and he pulled slightly ahead of Nixon in most polls. On Election Day, Kennedy defeated Nixon in one of the closest presidential elections of the 20th century. In the national popular vote, <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_elections_in_which_the_winner_lost_the_popular_vote#1960_Alabama_results_ambiguity" title="United States presidential elections in which the winner lost the popular vote">by most accounts</a>, Kennedy led Nixon by just two-tenths of one percent (49.7% to 49.5%), while in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electoral_College_(United_States)" title="Electoral College (United States)">Electoral College</a>, he won 303 votes to Nixon's 219 (269 were needed to win).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDudleyShiraev200883_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDudleyShiraev200883-101">[101]</a></sup> Fourteen electors from Mississippi and Alabama refused to support Kennedy because of his support for the <a href="/wiki/Civil_rights_movement" title="Civil rights movement">civil rights movement</a>; they voted for Senator <a href="/wiki/Harry_F._Byrd" title="Harry F. Byrd">Harry F. Byrd</a> of Virginia, as did an elector from Oklahoma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDudleyShiraev200883_101-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDudleyShiraev200883-101">[101]</a></sup> Kennedy became the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_the_United_States_by_age" title="List of Presidents of the United States by age">youngest person</a> (43) ever elected to the presidency, though <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt" title="Theodore Roosevelt">Theodore Roosevelt</a> was a year younger at 42 when he automatically assumed the office after <a href="/wiki/William_McKinley" title="William McKinley">William McKinley</a>'s assassination in 1901.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199321_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199321-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Presidency_.281961.E2.80.931963.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidency_(1961–1963)">Presidency (1961–1963)</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Presidency of John F. Kennedy">Presidency of John F. Kennedy</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide to this subject, see <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_presidency_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Timeline of the presidency of John F. Kennedy">Timeline of the presidency of John F. Kennedy</a>.</div>
<table class="mbox-small plainlinks sistersitebox" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="430" data-file-width="410" decoding="async" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/57px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/76px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" width="38"/></td>
<td class="mbox-text plainlist"><a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a> has original text related to this article:
<div style="margin-left: 10px;"><b><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy%27s_Inaugural_Address" title="wikisource:John F. Kennedy's Inaugural Address">John F. Kennedy's Inaugural Address</a></b></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jfk_inauguration.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="552" data-file-width="550" decoding="async" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Jfk_inauguration.jpg/220px-Jfk_inauguration.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Jfk_inauguration.jpg/330px-Jfk_inauguration.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Jfk_inauguration.jpg/440px-Jfk_inauguration.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jfk_inauguration.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>John F. Kennedy takes the <a href="/wiki/Oath_of_office_of_the_President_of_the_United_States" title="Oath of office of the President of the United States">Presidential oath of office</a> administered by <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_United_States" title="Chief Justice of the United States">Chief Justice</a> <a href="/wiki/Earl_Warren" title="Earl Warren">Earl Warren</a> on January 20, 1961, at <a href="/wiki/United_States_Capitol" title="United States Capitol">the Capitol</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>John F. Kennedy was sworn in as the 35th president at noon on January 20, 1961. In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inaugural_address_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Inaugural address of John F. Kennedy">his inaugural address</a>, he spoke of the need for all Americans to be active citizens, famously saying: "Ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country." He asked the nations of the world to join together to fight what he called the "common enemies of man: tyranny, poverty, disease, and war itself."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_Inaugural_Address_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_Inaugural_Address-103">[103]</a></sup> He added:
</p>
<blockquote><p>"All this will not be finished in the first one hundred days. Nor will it be finished in the first one thousand days, nor in the life of this Administration, nor even perhaps in our lifetime on this planet. But let us begin." In closing, he expanded on his desire for greater internationalism: "Finally, whether you are citizens of America or citizens of the world, ask of us here the same high standards of strength and sacrifice which we ask of you."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_Inaugural_Address_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_Inaugural_Address-103">[103]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>The address reflected Kennedy's confidence that his administration would chart a historically significant course in both domestic policy and foreign affairs. The contrast between this optimistic vision and the pressures of managing daily political realities at home and abroad would be one of the main tensions running through the early years of his administration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKempe201152_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKempe201152-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFKRiceUniversity.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="374" data-file-width="550" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/JFKRiceUniversity.jpg/240px-JFKRiceUniversity.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/JFKRiceUniversity.jpg/360px-JFKRiceUniversity.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/JFKRiceUniversity.jpg/480px-JFKRiceUniversity.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFKRiceUniversity.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>John F. Kennedy speaking at <a href="/wiki/Rice_University" title="Rice University">Rice University</a> in Houston on September 12, 1962. Lyndon Johnson can be seen behind him.</div></div></div>
<p>Kennedy brought to the White House a contrast in organization compared to the decision-making structure of former-General Eisenhower, and he wasted no time in scrapping Eisenhower's methods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199322_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199322-105">[105]</a></sup> Kennedy preferred the organizational structure of a wheel with all the spokes leading to the president. He was ready and willing to make the increased number of quick decisions required in such an environment. He selected a mixture of experienced and inexperienced people to serve in his cabinet. "We can learn our jobs together", he stated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199323,_25_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199323,_25-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>Much to the chagrin of his economic advisors, who wanted him to reduce taxes, Kennedy quickly agreed to a balanced budget pledge. This was needed in exchange for votes to expand the membership of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_Rules" title="United States House Committee on Rules">House Rules Committee</a> in order to give the Democrats a majority in setting the legislative agenda.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199356_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199356-107">[107]</a></sup> Kennedy focused on immediate and specific issues facing the administration, and quickly voiced his impatience with pondering of deeper meanings. <a href="/wiki/Deputy_National_Security_Advisor_(United_States)" title="Deputy National Security Advisor (United States)">Deputy National Security Advisor</a> <a href="/wiki/Walt_Whitman_Rostow" title="Walt Whitman Rostow">Walt Whitman Rostow</a> once began a diatribe about the growth of communism, and Kennedy abruptly cut him off, asking, "What do you want me to do about that today?"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199366_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199366-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy approved <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense" title="United States Secretary of Defense">Defense Secretary</a> <a href="/wiki/Robert_McNamara" title="Robert McNamara">Robert McNamara</a>'s controversial decision to award the contract for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-111" title="F-111">F-111</a> TFX (Tactical Fighter Experimental) fighter-bomber to <a href="/wiki/General_Dynamics" title="General Dynamics">General Dynamics</a> (the choice of the civilian Defense department) over <a href="/wiki/Boeing" title="Boeing">Boeing</a> (the choice of the military).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> At the request of Senator <a href="/wiki/Henry_M._Jackson" title="Henry M. Jackson">Henry Jackson</a>, Senator <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Little_McClellan" title="John Little McClellan">John McClellan</a> held 46 days of mostly closed-door hearings before the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Senate_Homeland_Security_Permanent_Subcommittee_on_Investigations" title="United States Senate Homeland Security Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations">Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations</a> investigating the TFX contract from February to November 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the summer of 1962, Kennedy had a secret taping system set up in the White House, most likely to aid his future memoir. It recorded many conversations with Kennedy and his Cabinet members, including those in relation to the "Cuban Missile Crisis".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_policy">Foreign policy</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_John_F._Kennedy_administration" title="Foreign policy of the John F. Kennedy administration">Foreign policy of the John F. Kennedy administration</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:US_President_John_Kennedy_Presidential_Trips.PNG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="625" data-file-width="1425" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/US_President_John_Kennedy_Presidential_Trips.PNG/330px-US_President_John_Kennedy_Presidential_Trips.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/US_President_John_Kennedy_Presidential_Trips.PNG/495px-US_President_John_Kennedy_Presidential_Trips.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/US_President_John_Kennedy_Presidential_Trips.PNG/660px-US_President_John_Kennedy_Presidential_Trips.PNG 2x" width="330"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:US_President_John_Kennedy_Presidential_Trips.PNG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Foreign trips of John F. Kennedy during his presidency</div></div></div>
<p>President Kennedy's foreign policy was dominated by American confrontations with the Soviet Union, manifested by proxy contests in the early stage of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>. In 1961, he anxiously anticipated a summit with <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Premier of the Soviet Union">Soviet Premier</a> <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a>. He started off on the wrong foot by reacting aggressively to a routine Khrushchev speech on Cold War confrontation in early 1961. The speech was intended for domestic audiences in the Soviet Union, but Kennedy interpreted it as a personal challenge. His mistake helped raise tensions going into the <a href="/wiki/Vienna_summit" title="Vienna summit">Vienna summit</a> of June 1961.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKempe201176–78_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKempe201176–78-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the way to the summit, Kennedy stopped in Paris to meet <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a>, who advised him to ignore Khrushchev's abrasive style. The French president feared the United States' presumed influence in Europe. Nevertheless, de Gaulle was quite impressed with the young president and his family. Kennedy picked up on this in his speech in Paris, saying that he would be remembered as "the man who accompanied Jackie Kennedy to Paris."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993145_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993145-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFKWHP-KN-C19113.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="996" decoding="async" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/JFKWHP-KN-C19113.jpg/220px-JFKWHP-KN-C19113.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/JFKWHP-KN-C19113.jpg/330px-JFKWHP-KN-C19113.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/JFKWHP-KN-C19113.jpg/440px-JFKWHP-KN-C19113.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFKWHP-KN-C19113.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Kekkonens from <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a> visited the United States and met John F. Kennedy in 1961. From left: President <a href="/wiki/Urho_Kekkonen" title="Urho Kekkonen">Urho Kekkonen</a>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Sylvi_Kekkonen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Sylvi Kekkonen (page does not exist)">Sylvi Kekkonen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jacqueline_Kennedy_Onassis" title="Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis">Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis</a> and John F. Kennedy.</div></div></div>
<p>On June 4, 1961, the president met with Khrushchev in Vienna and left the meetings angry and disappointed that he had allowed the premier to bully him, despite the warnings he had received. Khrushchev, for his part, was impressed with the president's intelligence, but thought him weak. Kennedy did succeed in conveying the bottom line to Khrushchev on the most sensitive issue before them, a proposed treaty between Moscow and <a href="/wiki/East_Berlin" title="East Berlin">East Berlin</a>. He made it clear that any treaty interfering with U.S access rights in <a href="/wiki/West_Berlin" title="West Berlin">West Berlin</a> would be regarded as an act of war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993161–171_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993161–171-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p><p>Shortly after the president returned home, the U.S.S.R. announced its plan to sign a treaty with East Berlin, abrogating any third-party occupation rights in either sector of the city. Depressed and angry, Kennedy assumed that his only option was to prepare the country for nuclear war, which he personally thought had a one-in-five chance of occurring.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993175_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993175-115">[115]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_John_F._Kennedy_Meets_with_the_President_of_the_Republic_of_Ghana,_Osagyefo_Dr._Kwame_Nkrumah_(JFKWHP-AR6409-B).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="787" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/President_John_F._Kennedy_Meets_with_the_President_of_the_Republic_of_Ghana%2C_Osagyefo_Dr._Kwame_Nkrumah_%28JFKWHP-AR6409-B%29.jpg/220px-President_John_F._Kennedy_Meets_with_the_President_of_the_Republic_of_Ghana%2C_Osagyefo_Dr._Kwame_Nkrumah_%28JFKWHP-AR6409-B%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/President_John_F._Kennedy_Meets_with_the_President_of_the_Republic_of_Ghana%2C_Osagyefo_Dr._Kwame_Nkrumah_%28JFKWHP-AR6409-B%29.jpg/330px-President_John_F._Kennedy_Meets_with_the_President_of_the_Republic_of_Ghana%2C_Osagyefo_Dr._Kwame_Nkrumah_%28JFKWHP-AR6409-B%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/President_John_F._Kennedy_Meets_with_the_President_of_the_Republic_of_Ghana%2C_Osagyefo_Dr._Kwame_Nkrumah_%28JFKWHP-AR6409-B%29.jpg/440px-President_John_F._Kennedy_Meets_with_the_President_of_the_Republic_of_Ghana%2C_Osagyefo_Dr._Kwame_Nkrumah_%28JFKWHP-AR6409-B%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_John_F._Kennedy_Meets_with_the_President_of_the_Republic_of_Ghana,_Osagyefo_Dr._Kwame_Nkrumah_(JFKWHP-AR6409-B).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy with <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah" title="Kwame Nkrumah">Kwame Nkrumah</a>, the first head of an independent <a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a>, March 1961</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_and_Amintore_Fanfani.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="462" data-file-width="738" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/John_F._Kennedy_and_Amintore_Fanfani.jpg/220px-John_F._Kennedy_and_Amintore_Fanfani.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/John_F._Kennedy_and_Amintore_Fanfani.jpg/330px-John_F._Kennedy_and_Amintore_Fanfani.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/John_F._Kennedy_and_Amintore_Fanfani.jpg/440px-John_F._Kennedy_and_Amintore_Fanfani.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_and_Amintore_Fanfani.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy with the Italian Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Amintore_Fanfani" title="Amintore Fanfani">Amintore Fanfani</a>, at the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a>, in 1963</div></div></div>
<p>In the weeks immediately following the Vienna summit, more than 20,000 people fled from East Berlin to the western sector, reacting to statements from the USSR. Kennedy began intensive meetings on the Berlin issue, where <a href="/wiki/Dean_Acheson" title="Dean Acheson">Dean Acheson</a> took the lead in recommending a military buildup alongside NATO allies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993185_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993185-116">[116]</a></sup> In a July 1961 speech, Kennedy announced his decision to add $3.25 billion (equivalent to $27.25 billion in 2018) to the defense budget, along with over 200,000 additional troops, stating that an attack on West Berlin would be taken as an attack on the U.S. The speech received an 85% approval rating.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993201_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993201-117">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>A month later, both the Soviet Union and East Berlin began blocking any further passage of East Berliners into West Berlin and erected barbed wire fences across the city, which were quickly upgraded to the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Wall" title="Berlin Wall">Berlin Wall</a>. Kennedy's initial reaction was to ignore this, as long as free access from West to East Berlin continued. This course was altered when West Berliners had lost confidence in the defense of their position by the United States. Kennedy sent Vice President Johnson, along with a host of military personnel, in convoy through West Germany, including Soviet-armed checkpoints, to demonstrate the continued commitment of the U.S. to West Berlin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993213_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993213-118">[118]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy gave a speech at <a href="/wiki/Saint_Anselm_College" title="Saint Anselm College">Saint Anselm College</a> on May 5, 1960, regarding America's conduct in the emerging Cold War. The address detailed how the American foreign policy should be conducted towards African nations, noting a hint of support for modern African nationalism by saying, "For we, too, founded a new nation on revolt from colonial rule."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_Saint_Anselm's_College_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_Saint_Anselm's_College-119">[119]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuba_and_the_Bay_of_Pigs_Invasion">Cuba and the Bay of Pigs Invasion</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Pigs_Invasion" title="Bay of Pigs Invasion">Bay of Pigs Invasion</a></div>
<p>The Eisenhower administration had created a plan to overthrow <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Castro" title="Fidel Castro">Fidel Castro</a>'s regime in Cuba. Led by the <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">Central Intelligence Agency</a> (CIA), with help from the U.S. military, the plan was for an invasion of Cuba by a counter-revolutionary insurgency composed of U.S.-trained, anti-Castro Cuban exiles<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002233,_238_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002233,_238-120">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> led by CIA paramilitary officers. The intention was to invade Cuba and instigate an uprising among the Cuban people, hoping to remove Castro from power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199369–73_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199369–73-122">[122]</a></sup> Kennedy approved the final invasion plan on April 4, 1961.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_and_Vice_President_Johnson_prior_to_ceremony.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="607" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/President_Kennedy_and_Vice_President_Johnson_prior_to_ceremony.jpg/220px-President_Kennedy_and_Vice_President_Johnson_prior_to_ceremony.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/President_Kennedy_and_Vice_President_Johnson_prior_to_ceremony.jpg/330px-President_Kennedy_and_Vice_President_Johnson_prior_to_ceremony.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/President_Kennedy_and_Vice_President_Johnson_prior_to_ceremony.jpg/440px-President_Kennedy_and_Vice_President_Johnson_prior_to_ceremony.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_and_Vice_President_Johnson_prior_to_ceremony.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The President and Vice President take a leisurely stroll on the White House grounds</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Pigs_Invasion" title="Bay of Pigs Invasion">Bay of Pigs Invasion</a> began on April 17, 1961. Fifteen hundred U.S.-trained Cubans, dubbed <a href="/wiki/Brigade_2506" title="Brigade 2506">Brigade 2506</a>, landed on the island. No U.S. air support was provided. <a href="/wiki/Central_Intelligence_Agency" title="Central Intelligence Agency">CIA</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Director_of_the_CIA" title="Director of the CIA">director</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Allen_Welsh_Dulles" title="Allen Welsh Dulles">Allen Dulles</a> later stated that they thought the president would authorize any action that was needed for success once the troops were on the ground.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199371,_673_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199371,_673-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>By April 19, 1961, the Cuban government had captured or killed the invading exiles, and Kennedy was forced to negotiate for the release of the 1,189 survivors. Twenty months later, Cuba released the captured exiles in exchange for $53 million worth of food and medicine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002268–294,_838–839_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002268–294,_838–839-124">[124]</a></sup> The incident made Castro feel wary of the U.S. and led him to believe that another invasion would take place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>Biographer <a href="/wiki/Richard_Reeves_(American_writer)" title="Richard Reeves (American writer)">Richard Reeves</a> said that Kennedy focused primarily on the political repercussions of the plan rather than military considerations. When it proved unsuccessful, he was convinced that the plan was a setup to make him look bad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199395–97_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199395–97-126">[126]</a></sup> He took responsibility for the failure, saying, "We got a big kick in the leg and we deserved it. But maybe we'll learn something from it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002290,_295_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002290,_295-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>In late 1961, the White House formed the Special Group (Augmented), headed by Robert Kennedy and including <a href="/wiki/Edward_Lansdale" title="Edward Lansdale">Edward Lansdale</a>, Secretary <a href="/wiki/Robert_McNamara" title="Robert McNamara">Robert McNamara</a>, and others. The group's objective—to overthrow Castro via espionage, sabotage, and other covert tactics—was never pursued.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993264_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993264-128">[128]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuban_Missile_Crisis">Cuban Missile Crisis</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis" title="Cuban Missile Crisis">Cuban Missile Crisis</a></div>
<table class="mbox-small noprint" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="mbox-image"><div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><img alt="" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div></div></td>
<td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="line-height:1.1em"><div class="haudio">
<div style="padding:4px 0"><a href="/wiki/File:John_F_Kennedy_Address_on_the_Buildup_of_Arms_in_Cuba.ogg" title="File:John F Kennedy Address on the Buildup of Arms in Cuba.ogg">Address on the Buildup of Arms in Cuba</a></div>
<div><div class="mediaContainer" style="width:220px"><audio class="kskin" controls="" data-durationhint="1056.3485034014" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="John_F_Kennedy_Address_on_the_Buildup_of_Arms_in_Cuba.ogg" data-startoffset="0" id="mwe_player_0" preload="none" style="width:220px"><source data-bandwidth="37761" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (38 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a9/John_F_Kennedy_Address_on_the_Buildup_of_Arms_in_Cuba.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="104672" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/a9/John_F_Kennedy_Address_on_the_Buildup_of_Arms_in_Cuba.ogg/John_F_Kennedy_Address_on_the_Buildup_of_Arms_in_Cuba.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/><track data-dir="ltr" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="TimedText:John_F_Kennedy_Address_on_the_Buildup_of_Arms_in_Cuba.ogg.en.srt" kind="subtitles" label="English (en) subtitles" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=TimedText:John_F_Kennedy_Address_on_the_Buildup_of_Arms_in_Cuba.ogg.en.srt&amp;action=raw&amp;ctype=text%2Fx-srt" srclang="en" type="text/x-srt"/></audio></div></div>
<div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0">Kennedy addressing the nation on October 22, 1962, about the buildup of arms on Cuba</div></div></td></tr>
<tr><td class="mbox-text" colspan="2" style="line-height:1.1em"><hr/><span class="selfreference"><i>Problems playing this file? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="mbox-small plainlinks sistersitebox" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="430" data-file-width="410" decoding="async" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/57px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/76px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" width="38"/></td>
<td class="mbox-text plainlist"><a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a> has original text related to this article:
<div style="margin-left: 10px;"><b><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis" title="wikisource:Cuban Missile Crisis">Cuban Missile Crisis</a></b></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>On October 14, 1962, CIA <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_U-2" title="Lockheed U-2">U-2</a> spy planes took photographs of the Soviets' construction of intermediate-range ballistic missile sites in Cuba. The photos were shown to Kennedy on October 16; a consensus was reached that the missiles were offensive in nature and thus posed an immediate nuclear threat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993345_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993345-129">[129]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy faced a dilemma: if the U.S. attacked the sites, it might lead to <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_warfare" title="Nuclear warfare">nuclear war</a> with the U.S.S.R., but if the U.S. did nothing, it would be faced with the increased threat from close-range nuclear weapons. The U.S. would also appear to the world as less committed to the defense of the hemisphere. On a personal level, Kennedy needed to show resolve in reaction to Khrushchev, especially after the Vienna summit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993245_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993245-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_Kennedy,_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="590" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/John_Kennedy%2C_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg/220px-John_Kennedy%2C_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/John_Kennedy%2C_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg/330px-John_Kennedy%2C_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/John_Kennedy%2C_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg/440px-John_Kennedy%2C_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_Kennedy,_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Soviet Premier <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> and Kennedy confer in <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Vienna</a>, 1961</div></div></div>
<p>More than a third of <a href="/wiki/United_States_National_Security_Council" title="United States National Security Council">U.S. National Security Council</a> (NSC) members favored an unannounced air assault on the missile sites, but for some of them this conjured up an image of "<a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a> in reverse".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993387_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993387-131">[131]</a></sup> There was also some concern from the international community (asked in confidence), that the assault plan was an overreaction in light of the fact that Eisenhower had placed <a href="/wiki/PGM-19_Jupiter" title="PGM-19 Jupiter">PGM-19 Jupiter</a> missiles in Italy and Turkey in 1958. It also could not be assured that the assault would be 100% effective.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993388_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993388-132">[132]</a></sup> In concurrence with a majority-vote of the NSC, Kennedy decided on a naval quarantine. On October 22, he dispatched a message to Khrushchev and announced the decision on TV.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993389_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993389-133">[133]</a></sup>
</p><p>The U.S. Navy would stop and inspect all Soviet ships arriving off Cuba, beginning October 24. The <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a> gave unanimous support to the removal of the missiles. The president exchanged two sets of letters with Khrushchev, to no avail.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993390_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993390-134">[134]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> (UN) Secretary General <a href="/wiki/U_Thant" title="U Thant">U Thant</a> requested both parties to reverse their decisions and enter a cooling-off period. Khrushchev agreed, but Kennedy didn't.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993403_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993403-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>One Soviet-flagged ship was stopped and boarded. On October 28, Khrushchev agreed to dismantle the missile sites, subject to UN inspections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993426_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993426-136">[136]</a></sup> The U.S. publicly promised never to invade Cuba and privately agreed to remove its Jupiter missiles from Italy and Turkey, which were by then obsolete and had been supplanted by submarines equipped with <a href="/wiki/UGM-27_Polaris" title="UGM-27 Polaris">UGM-27 Polaris</a> missiles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKenney2000184–186_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKenney2000184–186-137">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>This crisis brought the world closer to nuclear war than at any point before or after. In the end, "the humanity" of the two men prevailed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKenney2000189_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKenney2000189-138">[138]</a></sup> The crisis improved the image of American willpower and the president's credibility. Kennedy's approval rating increased from 66% to 77% immediately thereafter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993425_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993425-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Latin_America_and_communism">Latin America and communism</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_John_F._Kennedy_administration#Latin_America" title="Foreign policy of the John F. Kennedy administration">Foreign policy of the John F. Kennedy administration § Latin America</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alessandri-Kennedy(2).JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="663" data-file-width="982" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Alessandri-Kennedy%282%29.JPG/220px-Alessandri-Kennedy%282%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Alessandri-Kennedy%282%29.JPG/330px-Alessandri-Kennedy%282%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Alessandri-Kennedy%282%29.JPG/440px-Alessandri-Kennedy%282%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Alessandri-Kennedy(2).JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy with Chilean President <a href="/wiki/Jorge_Alessandri" title="Jorge Alessandri">Jorge Alessandri</a>, on an official visit in December 1962</div></div></div>
<p>Believing that "those who make peaceful revolution impossible, will make violent revolution inevitable,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> Kennedy sought to contain the perceived threat of communism in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> by establishing the <a href="/wiki/Alliance_for_Progress" title="Alliance for Progress">Alliance for Progress</a>, which sent aid to some countries and sought greater <a href="/wiki/Human_rights" title="Human rights">human rights</a> standards in the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002788,_789_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002788,_789-142">[142]</a></sup> He worked closely with <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Puerto_Rico" title="Governor of Puerto Rico">Puerto Rican Governor</a> <a href="/wiki/Luis_Mu%C3%B1oz_Mar%C3%ADn" title="Luis Muñoz Marín">Luis Muñoz Marín</a> for the development of the Alliance of Progress, and began working towards <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico" title="Puerto Rico">Puerto Rico</a>'s autonomy.
</p><p>The Eisenhower administration, through the CIA, had begun formulating plans to assassinate Castro in Cuba and <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Trujillo" title="Rafael Trujillo">Rafael Trujillo</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">Dominican Republic</a>. When President Kennedy took office, he privately instructed the CIA that any plan must include plausible deniability by the U.S. His public position was in opposition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993140–142_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993140–142-143">[143]</a></sup> In June 1961, the Dominican Republic's leader was assassinated; in the days following, Undersecretary of State <a href="/wiki/Chester_Bowles" title="Chester Bowles">Chester Bowles</a> led a cautious reaction by the nation. Robert Kennedy, who saw an opportunity for the U.S., called Bowles "a gutless bastard" to his face.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993152_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993152-144">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Peace_Corps">Peace Corps</span></h4>
<table class="mbox-small noprint" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="mbox-image"><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:92px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Executive_Order_10924_from_NARA.jpg"><img alt="Physical text copy of the Executive Order establishing the Peace Corps" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1260" data-file-width="774" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Executive_Order_10924_from_NARA.jpg/90px-Executive_Order_10924_from_NARA.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Executive_Order_10924_from_NARA.jpg/135px-Executive_Order_10924_from_NARA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Executive_Order_10924_from_NARA.jpg/180px-Executive_Order_10924_from_NARA.jpg 2x" width="90"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Executive_Order_10924_from_NARA.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Executive Order 10924</div></div></div></td>
<td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="line-height:1.1em"><div class="haudio">
<div style="padding:4px 0"><a href="/wiki/File:JFK_Establishment_of_the_Peace_Corps_edit.ogg" title="File:JFK Establishment of the Peace Corps edit.ogg">Establishment of the Peace Corps</a></div>
<div><div class="mediaContainer" style="width:220px"><audio class="kskin" controls="" data-durationhint="82.337959183673" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="JFK_Establishment_of_the_Peace_Corps_edit.ogg" data-startoffset="0" id="mwe_player_1" preload="none" style="width:220px"><source data-bandwidth="71292" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (71 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/56/JFK_Establishment_of_the_Peace_Corps_edit.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="135424" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/56/JFK_Establishment_of_the_Peace_Corps_edit.ogg/JFK_Establishment_of_the_Peace_Corps_edit.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/></audio></div></div>
<div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0">John F. Kennedy's announcement of the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Peace_Corps" title="Peace Corps">Peace Corps</a></div></div></td></tr>
<tr><td class="mbox-text" colspan="2" style="line-height:1.1em"><hr/><span class="selfreference"><i>Problems playing this file? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In one of his first presidential acts, Kennedy asked Congress to create the <a href="/wiki/Peace_Corps" title="Peace Corps">Peace Corps</a>. His brother-in-law, <a href="/wiki/Sargent_Shriver" title="Sargent Shriver">Sargent Shriver</a>, was its first director.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003338–339_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003338–339-145">[145]</a></sup> Through this program, Americans volunteered to help developing nations in fields like education, farming, health care, and construction. The organization grew to 5,000 members by March 1963 and 10,000 the year after.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002606–607_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002606–607-146">[146]</a></sup> Since 1961, over 200,000 Americans have joined the Peace Corps, representing 139 different countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Southeast_Asia">Southeast Asia</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Laotian_Civil_War" title="Laotian Civil War">Laotian Civil War</a>, <a href="/wiki/1963_South_Vietnamese_coup" title="1963 South Vietnamese coup">1963 South Vietnamese coup</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arrest_and_assassination_of_Ngo_Dinh_Diem" title="Arrest and assassination of Ngo Dinh Diem">Arrest and assassination of Ngo Dinh Diem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reaction_to_the_1963_South_Vietnamese_coup" title="Reaction to the 1963 South Vietnamese coup">Reaction to the 1963 South Vietnamese coup</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cable_243" title="Cable 243">Cable 243</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_crisis" title="Buddhist crisis">Buddhist crisis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%ADch_Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_%C4%90%E1%BB%A9c" title="Thích Quảng Đức">Thích Quảng Đức</a>, <a href="/wiki/X%C3%A1_L%E1%BB%A3i_Pagoda_raids" title="Xá Lợi Pagoda raids">Xá Lợi Pagoda raids</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Krulak_Mendenhall_mission" title="Krulak Mendenhall mission">Krulak Mendenhall mission</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/McNamara_Taylor_mission" title="McNamara Taylor mission">McNamara Taylor mission</a></div>
<p>When briefing Kennedy, Eisenhower emphasized that the communist threat in Southeast Asia required priority; Eisenhower considered <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a> to be "the cork in the bottle" regarding the regional threat. In March 1961, Kennedy voiced a change in policy from supporting a "free" Laos to a "neutral" Laos, indicating privately that <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, and not Laos, should be deemed America's tripwire for communism's spread in the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199375_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199375-149">[149]</a></sup> In May, he dispatched Lyndon Johnson to meet with South Vietnamese President <a href="/wiki/Ngo_Dinh_Diem" title="Ngo Dinh Diem">Ngo Dinh Diem</a>. Johnson assured Diem more aid to mold a fighting force that could resist the communists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKarnow1991230,_268_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKarnow1991230,_268-150">[150]</a></sup> Kennedy announced a change of policy from support to partnership with Diem to defeat of communism in <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South Vietnam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993119_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993119-151">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>During his presidency, Kennedy continued policies that provided political, economic, and military support to the South Vietnamese government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDunniganNofi1999257_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunniganNofi1999257-152">[152]</a></sup> In late 1961, the <a href="/wiki/Viet_Cong" title="Viet Cong">Viet Cong</a> began assuming a predominant presence, initially seizing the provincial capital of Phuoc Vinh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993240_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993240-153">[153]</a></sup> Kennedy increased the number of military advisors and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Special_Forces" title="U.S. Special Forces">special forces</a> in the area, from 11,000 in 1962 to 16,000 by late 1963, but he was reluctant to order a full-scale deployment of troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993242_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993242-154">[154]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> A year and three months later on March 8, 1965, his successor, President Lyndon Johnson, committed the first combat troops to Vietnam and greatly escalated U.S. involvement, with forces reaching 184,000 that year and 536,000 in 1968.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>In late 1961, President Kennedy sent <a href="/wiki/Roger_Hilsman" title="Roger Hilsman">Roger Hilsman</a>, then director of the State Department's <a href="/wiki/Bureau_of_Intelligence_and_Research" title="Bureau of Intelligence and Research">Bureau of Intelligence and Research</a>, to assess the situation in Vietnam. There, Hilsman met <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sir_Robert_Thompson" title="Sir Robert Thompson">Sir Robert Thompson</a>, head of the British Advisory Mission to South Vietnam, and the <a href="/wiki/Strategic_Hamlet_Program" title="Strategic Hamlet Program">Strategic Hamlet Program</a> was formed. It was approved by Kennedy and South Vietnam President <a href="/wiki/Ngo_Dinh_Diem" title="Ngo Dinh Diem">Ngo Dinh Diem</a>. It was implemented in early 1962 and involved some forced relocation, village internment, and segregation of rural South Vietnamese into new communities where the peasantry would be isolated from Communist insurgents. It was hoped that these new communities would provide security for the peasants and strengthen the tie between them and the central government. By November 1963, the program waned and officially ended in 1964.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETucker20111070_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETucker20111070-157">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 1962, Kennedy formally authorized escalated involvement when he signed the National Security Action Memorandum – "Subversive Insurgency (War of Liberation)".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993281_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993281-158">[158]</a></sup> "<a href="/wiki/Operation_Ranch_Hand" title="Operation Ranch Hand">Operation Ranch Hand</a>", a large-scale aerial defoliation effort, began on the roadsides of South Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993259_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993259-159">[159]</a></sup> Depending on which assessment Kennedy accepted (Department of Defense or State), there had been zero or modest progress in countering the increase in communist aggression in return for an expanded U.S. involvement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993283_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993283-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_and_Harold_Holt.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="319" data-file-width="425" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/John_F._Kennedy_and_Harold_Holt.jpg/220px-John_F._Kennedy_and_Harold_Holt.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/John_F._Kennedy_and_Harold_Holt.jpg/330px-John_F._Kennedy_and_Harold_Holt.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1e/John_F._Kennedy_and_Harold_Holt.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_and_Harold_Holt.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy with future <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Australia" title="Prime Minister of Australia">Australian Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Harold_Holt" title="Harold Holt">Harold Holt</a> in <a href="/wiki/Oval_Office" title="Oval Office">the Oval Office</a> in 1963</div></div></div>
<p>In April 1963, Kennedy assessed the situation in Vietnam, saying, "We don't have a prayer of staying in Vietnam. Those people hate us. They are going to throw our asses out of there at any point. But I can't give up that territory to the communists and get the American people to re-elect me."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993484_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993484-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>On August 21, just as the new U.S. Ambassador <a href="/wiki/Henry_Cabot_Lodge_Jr." title="Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.">Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.</a> arrived, Diem and his brother <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ngo_Dinh_Nhu" title="Ngo Dinh Nhu">Ngo Dinh Nhu</a> ordered South Vietnam forces, funded and trained by the CIA, to quell Buddhist demonstrations. The crackdowns heightened expectations of a <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d'état">coup d'état</a> to remove Diem with (or perhaps by) his brother, Nhu.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993558_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993558-162">[162]</a></sup> Lodge was instructed to try getting Diem and Nhu to step down and leave the country. Diem would not listen to Lodge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993559_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993559-163">[163]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cable_243" title="Cable 243">Cable 243</a> (DEPTEL 243) followed, dated August 24, declaring that Washington would no longer tolerate Nhu's actions, and Lodge was ordered to pressure Diem to remove Nhu.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993562–563_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993562–563-164">[164]</a></sup> Lodge concluded that the only option was to get the South Vietnamese generals to overthrow Diem and Nhu.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993573_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993573-165">[165]</a></sup> At week's end, orders were sent to Saigon and throughout Washington to "destroy all coup cables".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993577_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993577-166">[166]</a></sup> At the same time, the first formal anti-Vietnam war sentiment was expressed by U.S. clergy from the Ministers' Vietnam Committee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993560_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993560-167">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>A White House meeting in September was indicative of the different ongoing appraisals; the president was given updated assessments after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Krulak_Mendenhall_mission" title="Krulak Mendenhall mission">personal inspections on the ground</a> by the Departments of Defense (General <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victor_Krulak" title="Victor Krulak">Victor Krulak</a>) and State (<a href="/wiki/Joseph_Mendenhall" title="Joseph Mendenhall">Joseph Mendenhall</a>). Krulak said that the military fight against the communists was progressing and being won, while Mendenhall stated that the country was civilly being lost to any U.S. influence. Kennedy reacted, asking, "Did you two gentlemen visit the same country?" The president was unaware that both men were at such odds that they had not spoken to each other on the return flight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993595_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993595-168">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 1963, the president appointed Defense Secretary McNamara and General <a href="/wiki/Maxwell_D._Taylor" title="Maxwell D. Taylor">Maxwell D. Taylor</a> to a Vietnamese mission in another effort to synchronize the information and formulation of policy. The objective of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/McNamara_Taylor_mission" title="McNamara Taylor mission">McNamara Taylor mission</a> "emphasized the importance of getting to the bottom of the differences in reporting from U.S. representatives in Vietnam."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993602_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993602-169">[169]</a></sup> In meetings with McNamara, Taylor, and Lodge, Diem again refused to agree to governing measures, helping to dispel McNamara's previous optimism about Diem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993609_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993609-170">[170]</a></sup> Taylor and McNamara were enlightened by Vietnam's vice president, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nguyen_Ngoc_Tho" title="Nguyen Ngoc Tho">Nguyen Ngoc Tho</a> (choice of many to succeed Diem), who in detailed terms obliterated Taylor's information that the military was succeeding in the countryside.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993610_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993610-171">[171]</a></sup> At Kennedy's insistence, the mission report contained a recommended schedule for troop withdrawals: 1,000 by year's end and complete withdrawal in 1965, something the NSC considered to be a "strategic fantasy".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993613_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993613-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>In late October, intelligence wires again reported that a coup against the Diem government was afoot. The source, Vietnamese General <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Duong_Van_Minh" title="Duong Van Minh">Duong Van Minh</a> (also known as "Big Minh"), wanted to know the U.S. position. Kennedy instructed Lodge to offer covert assistance to the coup, excluding assassination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993617_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993617-173">[173]</a></sup> On November 1, 1963, South Vietnamese generals, led by "Big Minh", <a href="/wiki/1963_South_Vietnamese_coup" title="1963 South Vietnamese coup">overthrew the Diem government</a>, arresting <a href="/wiki/Arrest_and_assassination_of_Ngo_Dinh_Diem" title="Arrest and assassination of Ngo Dinh Diem">and then killing Diem and Nhu</a>. Kennedy was shocked by the deaths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993650_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993650-174">[174]</a></sup>
</p><p>News of the coup led to renewed confidence initially—both in America and in South Vietnam—that the war might be won.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993651_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993651-175">[175]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/McGeorge_Bundy" title="McGeorge Bundy">McGeorge Bundy</a> drafted a National Security Action Memo to present to Kennedy upon his return from Dallas. It reiterated the resolve to fight communism in Vietnam, with increasing military and economic aid and expansion of operations into Laos and Cambodia. Before leaving for Dallas, Kennedy told <a href="/wiki/Michael_Forrestal" title="Michael Forrestal">Michael Forrestal</a> that "after the first of the year ... [he wanted] an in depth study of every possible option, including how to get out of there ... to review this whole thing from the bottom to the top." When asked what he thought the president meant, Forrestal said, "it was devil's advocate stuff."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993660_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993660-176">[176]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_American_University_Commencement_Address_June_10,_1963.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2562" data-file-width="2632" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/President_Kennedy_American_University_Commencement_Address_June_10%2C_1963.jpg/170px-President_Kennedy_American_University_Commencement_Address_June_10%2C_1963.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/President_Kennedy_American_University_Commencement_Address_June_10%2C_1963.jpg/255px-President_Kennedy_American_University_Commencement_Address_June_10%2C_1963.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/President_Kennedy_American_University_Commencement_Address_June_10%2C_1963.jpg/340px-President_Kennedy_American_University_Commencement_Address_June_10%2C_1963.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_American_University_Commencement_Address_June_10,_1963.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy delivers the <a href="/wiki/Commencement_speech" title="Commencement speech">commencement speech</a> at <a href="/wiki/American_University" title="American University">American University</a>, June 10, 1963</div></div></div>
<p>Historians disagree on whether Vietnam would have escalated if Kennedy not been assassinated and had won re-election in 1964.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> Fueling the debate were statements made by Secretary of Defense McNamara in the film "<a href="/wiki/The_Fog_of_War" title="The Fog of War">The Fog of War</a>" that Kennedy was strongly considering pulling the United States out of Vietnam after the 1964 election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> The film also contains a tape recording of Lyndon Johnson stating that Kennedy was planning to withdraw, a position in which Johnson disagreed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBlightLang2005276_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlightLang2005276-179">[179]</a></sup> Kennedy had signed National Security Action Memorandum (NSAM) 263, dated October 11, which ordered the withdrawal of 1,000 military personnel by year's end, and the bulk of them out by 1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSAM_263_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-NSAM_263-180">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003680_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003680-181">[181]</a></sup> Such an action would have been a policy reversal, but Kennedy was moving in a less hawkish direction since his speech on world peace at <a href="/wiki/American_University" title="American University">American University</a> on June 10, 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AmUniv_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-AmUniv-182">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the time of Kennedy's death, no final policy decision was made to Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatthews2011393,_394_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatthews2011393,_394-183">[183]</a></sup> In 2008, Theodore Sorensen wrote, "I would like to believe that Kennedy would have found a way to withdraw all American instructors and advisors [from Vietnam]. But ... I do not believe he knew in his last weeks what he was going to do."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESorensen1966359_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESorensen1966359-184">[184]</a></sup> Sorensen added that, in his opinion, Vietnam "was the only foreign policy problem handed off by JFK to his successor in no better, and possibly worse, shape than it was when he inherited it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESorensen1966359_184-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESorensen1966359-184">[184]</a></sup> U.S. involvement in the region escalated until his successor Lyndon Johnson directly deployed regular U.S. military forces for fighting the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKarnow1991339,_343_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKarnow1991339,_343-185">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup> After Kennedy's assassination, President Johnson signed NSAM 273 on November 26, 1963. It reversed Kennedy's decision to withdraw 1,000 troops, and reaffirmed the policy of assistance to the South Vietnamese.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="American_University_speech">American University speech</span></h4>
<table class="mbox-small noprint" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;">

<td class="mbox-image"><div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><img alt="" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div></div></td>

<table class="mbox-small plainlinks sistersitebox" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="430" data-file-width="410" decoding="async" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/57px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/76px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" width="38"/></td>
<td class="mbox-text plainlist"><a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a> has original text related to this article:
<div style="margin-left: 10px;"><b><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/A_Strategy_of_Peace" title="wikisource:A Strategy of Peace">A Strategy of Peace</a></b></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>On June 10, 1963, Kennedy, at the high point of his rhetorical powers,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> delivered the <a href="/wiki/American_University_speech" title="American University speech">commencement address at American University</a> in Washington, D.C. Also known as "A Strategy of Peace", not only did the President outline a plan to curb nuclear arms, but he also "laid out a hopeful, yet realistic route for world peace at a time when the U.S. and Soviet Union faced the potential for an escalating nuclear arms race."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> The President wished:
</p>
<blockquote><p>to discuss a topic on which too often ignorance abounds and the truth is too rarely perceived—yet it is the most important topic on earth: world peace ... I speak of peace because of the new face of war ... in an age when a singular nuclear weapon contains ten times the explosive force delivered by all the allied forces in the Second World War ... an age when the deadly poisons produced by a nuclear exchange would be carried by wind and air and soil and seed to the far corners of the globe and to generations yet unborn ... I speak of peace, therefore, as the necessary rational end of rational men ... world peace, like community peace, does not require that each man love his neighbor—it requires only that they live together in mutual tolerance ... our problems are man-made—therefore they can be solved by man. And man can be as big as he wants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993513–514_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993513–514-191">[191]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>The president also made two announcements— 1.) that the Soviets had expressed a desire to negotiate a nuclear test ban treaty, and 2.) that the U.S had postponed planned atmospheric tests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993514_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993514-192">[192]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="West_Berlin_speech">West Berlin speech</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFKBerlinSpeech.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="224" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/JFKBerlinSpeech.jpg/170px-JFKBerlinSpeech.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/JFKBerlinSpeech.jpg/255px-JFKBerlinSpeech.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3a/JFKBerlinSpeech.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFKBerlinSpeech.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy delivering his speech in <a href="/wiki/West_Berlin" title="West Berlin">West Berlin</a></div></div></div>
<table class="mbox-small noprint" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;">
<tbody><tr>
<td class="mbox-image"><div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" decoding="async" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Audio-input-microphone.svg/50px-Audio-input-microphone.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Audio-input-microphone.svg/75px-Audio-input-microphone.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Audio-input-microphone.svg/100px-Audio-input-microphone.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div></div></td>
<td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="line-height:1.1em"><div class="haudio">
<div style="padding:4px 0"><a href="/wiki/File:Ich_bin_ein_Berliner_Speech_(June_26,_1963)_John_Fitzgerald_Kennedy_trimmed.theora.ogv" title="File:Ich bin ein Berliner Speech (June 26, 1963) John Fitzgerald Kennedy trimmed.theora.ogv"><i>Ich bin ein Berliner</i> (I am a Berliner) speech</a></div>

<div style="padding:4px 0"><a href="/wiki/File:Jfk_berlin_address_high.ogg" title="File:Jfk berlin address high.ogg"><i>Ich bin ein Berliner</i> (I am a Berliner) speech (audio)</a></div>
<div><div class="mediaContainer" style="width:220px"><audio class="kskin" controls="" data-durationhint="561.83002267574" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Jfk_berlin_address_high.ogg" data-startoffset="0" id="mwe_player_5" preload="none" style="width:220px"><source data-bandwidth="123496" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/3/3a/Jfk_berlin_address_high.ogg/Jfk_berlin_address_high.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/><source data-bandwidth="129454" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (129 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3a/Jfk_berlin_address_high.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><track data-dir="ltr" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="TimedText:Jfk_berlin_address_high.ogg.en.srt" kind="subtitles" label="English (en) subtitles" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=TimedText:Jfk_berlin_address_high.ogg.en.srt&amp;action=raw&amp;ctype=text%2Fx-srt" srclang="en" type="text/x-srt"/></audio></div></div>
<div class="description" style="padding:2px 0 0 0">Audio-only version (duration 9:22)</div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<table class="mbox-small plainlinks sistersitebox" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000">
<tbody><tr>
