<td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="430" data-file-width="410" decoding="async" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/38px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/57px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/76px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" width="38"/></td>
<td class="mbox-text plainlist"><a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a> has original text related to this article:
<div style="margin-left: 10px;"><b><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Ich_bin_ein_Berliner" title="wikisource:Ich bin ein Berliner">JFK's Ich bin ein Berliner speech</a></b></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In 1963, Germany was enduring a time of particular vulnerability due to Soviet aggression to the east as well as the impending retirement of West German Chancellor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adenauer" title="Adenauer">Adenauer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993534_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993534-193">[193]</a></sup> At the same time, French President Charles de Gaulle was trying to build a Franco-West German counterweight to the American and Soviet spheres of influence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> To Kennedy's eyes, this Franco-German cooperation seemed directed against <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>'s influence in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>On June 26, President Kennedy gave a public speech in <a href="/wiki/West_Berlin" title="West Berlin">West Berlin</a>. He reiterated the American commitment to Germany and criticized communism, and was met with an ecstatic response from a massive audience.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003624_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003624-198">[198]</a></sup> Kennedy used the construction of the Berlin Wall as an example of the failures of communism: "Freedom has many difficulties, and democracy is not perfect. But we have never had to put a wall up to keep our people in, to prevent them from leaving us." The speech is known for its famous phrase <i>"<a href="/wiki/Ich_bin_ein_Berliner" title="Ich bin ein Berliner">Ich bin ein Berliner</a>"</i> ("I am a citizen of Berlin"). A million people were on the street for the speech.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003624_198-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003624-198">[198]</a></sup> Kennedy remarked to Ted Sorensen afterwards: "We'll never have another day like this one, as long as we live."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993537_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993537-199">[199]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Tear_down_this_wall!" title="Tear down this wall!">Tear down this wall!</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Israel">Israel</span></h4>
<p>In 1960, Kennedy stated, "Israel will endure and flourish. It is the child of hope and the home of the brave. It can neither be broken by adversity nor demoralized by success. It carries the shield of democracy and it honors the sword of freedom."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup>
</p><p>Subsequently, as president, Kennedy initiated the creation of security ties with Israel, and he is credited as the founder of the US-Israeli military alliance (which would be continued under subsequent presidents). Kennedy ended the arms embargo that the Eisenhower and Truman administrations had enforced on Israel. Describing the protection of Israel as a moral and national commitment, he was the first to introduce the concept of a "special relationship" (as he described it to <a href="/wiki/Golda_Meir" title="Golda Meir">Golda Meir</a>) between the US and Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kennedy-Golda_Meir.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1824" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="258" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Kennedy-Golda_Meir.jpg/170px-Kennedy-Golda_Meir.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Kennedy-Golda_Meir.jpg/255px-Kennedy-Golda_Meir.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Kennedy-Golda_Meir.jpg/340px-Kennedy-Golda_Meir.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kennedy-Golda_Meir.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_Affairs_Minister_of_Israel" title="Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel">Israeli Foreign Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Golda_Meir" title="Golda Meir">Golda Meir</a>, December 27, 1962</div></div></div>
<p>Kennedy extended the first informal security guarantees to Israel in 1962 and, beginning in 1963, was the first US president to allow the sale to Israel of advanced US weaponry (the <a href="/wiki/MIM-23_Hawk" title="MIM-23 Hawk">MIM-23 Hawk</a>) as well as to provide diplomatic support for Israeli policies, which were opposed by Arab neighbors; those policies included Israel's water project on the <a href="/wiki/Jordan_River" title="Jordan River">Jordan River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p>As result of this newly created security alliance, Kennedy also encountered tensions with the Israeli government over the production of nuclear materials in <a href="/wiki/Dimona" title="Dimona">Dimona</a>, which he believed could instigate a nuclear arms-race in the Middle East. After the existence of a nuclear plant was initially denied by the Israeli government, <a href="/wiki/David_Ben-Gurion" title="David Ben-Gurion">David Ben-Gurion</a> stated in a speech to the Israeli <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a> on December 21, 1960, that the purpose of the nuclear plant at <a href="/wiki/Beersheba" title="Beersheba">Beersheba</a> was for "research in problems of arid zones and desert flora and fauna."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESalt2008201_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESalt2008201-203">[203]</a></sup> When Ben-Gurion met with Kennedy in New York, he claimed that Dimona was being developed to provide nuclear power for desalinization and other peaceful purposes "for the time being."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESalt2008201_203-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESalt2008201-203">[203]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a May 1963 letter to Ben-Gurion, Kennedy wrote that he was skeptical and stated that American support to Israel could be in jeopardy if reliable information on the Israeli nuclear program was not forthcoming, Ben-Gurion repeated previous reassurances that Dimona was being developed for peaceful purposes. The Israeli government resisted American pressure to open its nuclear facilities to <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a> (IAEA) inspections. In 1962, the US and Israeli governments had agreed to an annual inspection regime. A science attaché at the embassy in Tel Aviv concluded that parts of the Dimona facility had been shut down temporarily to mislead American scientists when they visited.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESalt2008202_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESalt2008202-204">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Seymour_Hersh" title="Seymour Hersh">Seymour Hersh</a>, the Israelis set up false control rooms to show the Americans. Israeli lobbyist Abe Feinberg stated: "It was part of my job to tip them off that Kennedy was insisting on [an inspection]."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESalt2008202_204-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESalt2008202-204">[204]</a></sup> Hersh contends that the inspections were conducted in such a way that it "guaranteed that the whole procedure would be little more than a whitewash, as the president and his senior advisors had to understand: the American inspection team would have to schedule its visits well in advance, and with the full acquiescence of Israel."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marc_Trachtenberg" title="Marc Trachtenberg">Marc Trachtenberg</a> argued that "[a]lthough [he was] well aware of what the Israelis were doing, Kennedy chose to take this as satisfactory evidence of Israeli compliance with America's non-proliferation policy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> The American who led the inspection team stated that the essential goal of the inspections was to find "ways to not reach the point of taking action against Israel's nuclear weapons program."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rodger_Davies" title="Rodger Davies">Rodger Davies</a>, the director of the State Department's Office of Near Eastern Affairs, concluded in March 1965 that Israel was developing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons" title="Nuclear weapons">nuclear weapons</a>. He reported that Israel's target date for achieving nuclear capability was 1968–1969.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESalt2008203_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESalt2008203-208">[208]</a></sup> On May 1, 1968, Undersecretary of State <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Katzenbach" title="Nicholas Katzenbach">Nicholas Katzenbach</a> told President Johnson that Dimona was producing enough plutonium to produce two bombs a year. The State Department argued that if Israel wanted arms, it should accept international supervision of its nuclear program.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESalt2008202_204-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESalt2008202-204">[204]</a></sup> Dimona was never placed under IAEA safeguards. Attempts to write Israeli adherence to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_Non-Proliferation_Treaty" title="Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty">Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty</a> (NPT) into contracts for the supply of U.S. weapons continued throughout 1968.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESalt2008201–205_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESalt2008201–205-209">[209]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Iraq">Iraq</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_John_F._Kennedy_administration#Iraq" title="Foreign policy of the John F. Kennedy administration">Foreign policy of the John F. Kennedy administration § Iraq</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kennedy_with_Shah_of_Iran,_1961.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="991" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Kennedy_with_Shah_of_Iran%2C_1961.jpg/220px-Kennedy_with_Shah_of_Iran%2C_1961.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Kennedy_with_Shah_of_Iran%2C_1961.jpg/330px-Kennedy_with_Shah_of_Iran%2C_1961.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Kennedy_with_Shah_of_Iran%2C_1961.jpg/440px-Kennedy_with_Shah_of_Iran%2C_1961.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kennedy_with_Shah_of_Iran,_1961.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi" title="Mohammad Reza Pahlavi">Mohammad Reza Pahlavi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shah" title="Shah">Shah</a> of <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>, Kennedy, and <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense" title="United States Secretary of Defense">U.S. Defense Secretary</a> <a href="/wiki/Robert_McNamara" title="Robert McNamara">Robert McNamara</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_Room_(White_House)" title="Cabinet Room (White House)">White House Cabinet Room</a> on April 13, 1962</div></div></div>
<p>Relations between the United States and Iraq became strained following the overthrow of the Iraqi monarchy on July 14, 1958, which resulted in the declaration of a republican government led by Brigadier <a href="/wiki/Abd_al-Karim_Qasim" title="Abd al-Karim Qasim">Abd al-Karim Qasim</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibson20153-5_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibson20153-5-210">[210]</a></sup> On June 25, 1961, Qasim mobilized troops along the border between Iraq and <a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>, declaring the latter nation "an indivisible part of Iraq" and causing a short-lived "Kuwait Crisis". The United Kingdom—which had just granted Kuwait independence on June 19, and whose economy was heavily dependent on Kuwaiti oil—responded on July 1 by dispatching 5,000 troops to the country to deter an Iraqi invasion. At the same time, Kennedy dispatched a U.S. Navy task force to <a href="/wiki/Bahrain" title="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>, and the UK (at the urging of the Kennedy administration) brought the dispute to United Nations Security Council, where the proposed resolution was vetoed by the Soviet Union. The situation was resolved in October, when the British troops were withdrawn and replaced by a 4,000-strong <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> force.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibson201536_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibson201536-211">[211]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 1961, Qasim's government passed Public Law 80, which restricted the British- and American-owned <a href="/wiki/Iraq_Petroleum_Company" title="Iraq Petroleum Company">Iraq Petroleum Company</a> (IPC)'s <a href="/wiki/Concession_(contract)" title="Concession (contract)">concessionary holding</a> to those areas in which oil was actually being produced, effectively expropriating 99.5% of the IPC concession. U.S. officials were alarmed by the expropriation as well as the recent Soviet veto of an Egyptian-sponsored UN resolution requesting the admittance of Kuwait as UN member state, which they believed were connected. Senior National Security Council adviser <a href="/wiki/Robert_Komer" title="Robert Komer">Robert Komer</a> worried that if the IPC ceased production in response, Qasim might "grab Kuwait" (thus achieving a "stranglehold" on Middle Eastern oil production) or "throw himself into Russian arms." Komer also made note of widespread rumors that a nationalist coup against Qasim could be imminent, and had the potential to "get Iraq back on [a] more neutral keel."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibson201537,_40-42_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibson201537,_40-42-212">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 1962, the State Department issued new guidelines on Iraq that were intended to increase American influence there. Meanwhile, Kennedy instructed the CIA—under the direction of <a href="/wiki/Archibald_Bulloch_Roosevelt_Jr." title="Archibald Bulloch Roosevelt Jr.">Archibald Bulloch Roosevelt Jr.</a>—to begin making preparations for a military coup against Qasim.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibson201543-45_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibson201543-45-213">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p>The anti-imperialist and anti-communist <a href="/wiki/Arab_Socialist_Ba%27ath_Party_%E2%80%93_Iraq_Region" title="Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Iraq Region">Iraqi Ba'ath Party</a> <a href="/wiki/Ramadan_Revolution" title="Ramadan Revolution">overthrew and executed Qasim in a violent coup</a> on February 8, 1963. While there have been persistent rumors that the CIA orchestrated the coup, declassified documents and the testimony of former CIA officers indicate that there was no direct American involvement, although the CIA was actively seeking a suitable replacement for Qasim within the Iraqi military and had been informed of an earlier Ba'athist coup plot.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibson201545,_57-58_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibson201545,_57-58-214">[214]</a></sup> The Kennedy administration was pleased with the outcome and ultimately approved a $55-million arms deal for Iraq.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibson201560-61,_80_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibson201560-61,_80-215">[215]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ireland">Ireland</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFK-John_Barry_Memorial.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="508" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/JFK-John_Barry_Memorial.jpg/220px-JFK-John_Barry_Memorial.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/JFK-John_Barry_Memorial.jpg/330px-JFK-John_Barry_Memorial.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/JFK-John_Barry_Memorial.jpg/440px-JFK-John_Barry_Memorial.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFK-John_Barry_Memorial.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>John F. Kennedy visiting the John Barry Memorial at Crescent Quay in Wexford, Ireland</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President%27s_Trip_to_Europe-_Motorcade_in_Dublin._President_Kennedy,_motorcade,_spectators._Dublin,_Ireland_-_NARA_-_194227.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2015" data-file-width="2963" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/President%27s_Trip_to_Europe-_Motorcade_in_Dublin._President_Kennedy%2C_motorcade%2C_spectators._Dublin%2C_Ireland_-_NARA_-_194227.jpg/220px-President%27s_Trip_to_Europe-_Motorcade_in_Dublin._President_Kennedy%2C_motorcade%2C_spectators._Dublin%2C_Ireland_-_NARA_-_194227.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/President%27s_Trip_to_Europe-_Motorcade_in_Dublin._President_Kennedy%2C_motorcade%2C_spectators._Dublin%2C_Ireland_-_NARA_-_194227.jpg/330px-President%27s_Trip_to_Europe-_Motorcade_in_Dublin._President_Kennedy%2C_motorcade%2C_spectators._Dublin%2C_Ireland_-_NARA_-_194227.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/President%27s_Trip_to_Europe-_Motorcade_in_Dublin._President_Kennedy%2C_motorcade%2C_spectators._Dublin%2C_Ireland_-_NARA_-_194227.jpg/440px-President%27s_Trip_to_Europe-_Motorcade_in_Dublin._President_Kennedy%2C_motorcade%2C_spectators._Dublin%2C_Ireland_-_NARA_-_194227.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President%27s_Trip_to_Europe-_Motorcade_in_Dublin._President_Kennedy,_motorcade,_spectators._Dublin,_Ireland_-_NARA_-_194227.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President Kennedy in motorcade in Patrick Street, <a href="/wiki/Cork_(city)" title="Cork (city)">Cork</a>, in Ireland on June 28, 1963</div></div></div>
<p>During his four-day visit to his ancestral home of Ireland in June 1963,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> Kennedy accepted a grant of <a href="/wiki/Achievement_(heraldry)" title="Achievement (heraldry)">armorial bearings</a> from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chief_Herald_of_Ireland" title="Chief Herald of Ireland">Chief Herald of Ireland</a> and received honorary degrees from the <a href="/wiki/National_University_of_Ireland" title="National University of Ireland">National University of Ireland</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trinity_College,_Dublin" title="Trinity College, Dublin">Trinity College, Dublin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESorensen1966656_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESorensen1966656-217">[217]</a></sup> He visited the cottage at Dunganstown, near <a href="/wiki/New_Ross" title="New Ross">New Ross</a>, <a href="/wiki/County_Wexford" title="County Wexford">County Wexford</a>, where his ancestors had lived before emigrating to America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_1963_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_1963-218">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy also was the first foreign leader to address the <a href="/wiki/Oireachtas" title="Oireachtas">Houses of the Oireachtas</a> (the Irish parliament).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> On December 22, 2006, the Irish <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Justice_and_Equality" title="Department of Justice and Equality">Department of Justice</a> released declassified police documents indicating that security was heightened as Kennedy was the subject of three death threats during this visit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cowell_2006_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cowell_2006-220">[220]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Nuclear_Test_Ban_Treaty">Nuclear Test Ban Treaty</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Partial_Nuclear_Test_Ban_Treaty" title="Partial Nuclear Test Ban Treaty">Partial Nuclear Test Ban Treaty</a></div>
<p>Troubled by the long-term dangers of <a href="/wiki/Radioactive_contamination" title="Radioactive contamination">radioactive contamination</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_proliferation" title="Nuclear proliferation">nuclear weapons proliferation</a>, Kennedy and Khrushchev agreed to negotiate a nuclear test ban treaty, originally conceived in Adlai Stevenson's 1956 presidential campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993552_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993552-221">[221]</a></sup> In their Vienna summit meeting in June 1961, Khrushchev and Kennedy both reached an informal understanding against nuclear testing, but the Soviet Union began testing nuclear weapons that September. In response, the United States conducted tests five days later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993227_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993227-222">[222]</a></sup> Shortly afterwards, new U.S. satellites began delivering images which made it clear that the Soviets were substantially behind the U.S. in the arms race.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993229_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993229-223">[223]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the greater nuclear strength of the U.S. was of little value as long as the U.S.S.R. perceived itself to be at parity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993243_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993243-224">[224]</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 1963, Kennedy sent <a href="/wiki/W._Averell_Harriman" title="W. Averell Harriman">W. Averell Harriman</a> to Moscow to negotiate a treaty with the Soviets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993542_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993542-225">[225]</a></sup> The introductory sessions included Khrushchev, who later delegated Soviet representation to <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Gromyko" title="Andrei Gromyko">Andrei Gromyko</a>. It quickly became clear that a comprehensive test ban would not be implemented, due largely to the reluctance of the Soviets to allow inspections that would verify compliance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993548_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993548-226">[226]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ultimately, the United States, the United Kingdom, and the Soviet Union were the initial signatories to a limited treaty, which prohibited atomic testing on the ground, in the atmosphere, or underwater, but not underground. The U.S. Senate ratified this and Kennedy signed it into law in October 1963. France was quick to declare that it was free to continue developing and testing its nuclear defenses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993550_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993550-227">[227]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Domestic_policy">Domestic policy</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fort_Worth_rally,_22_November_1963.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="532" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Fort_Worth_rally%2C_22_November_1963.jpg/220px-Fort_Worth_rally%2C_22_November_1963.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Fort_Worth_rally%2C_22_November_1963.jpg/330px-Fort_Worth_rally%2C_22_November_1963.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Fort_Worth_rally%2C_22_November_1963.jpg/440px-Fort_Worth_rally%2C_22_November_1963.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fort_Worth_rally,_22_November_1963.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President Kennedy in <a href="/wiki/Fort_Worth,_Texas" title="Fort Worth, Texas">Fort Worth, Texas</a>, on Friday morning, November 22, 1963</div></div></div>
<p>Kennedy called his domestic program the "New Frontier". It ambitiously promised federal funding for education, medical care for the elderly, economic aid to rural regions, and government intervention to halt the recession. He also promised an end to <a href="/wiki/Racial_discrimination" title="Racial discrimination">racial discrimination</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jaikumar_2011_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jaikumar_2011-228">[228]</a></sup> although his agenda, which included the endorsement of the <a href="/wiki/Voter_Education_Project" title="Voter Education Project">Voter Education Project</a> (VEP) in 1962, produced little progress in areas such as Mississippi, where the "VEP concluded that discrimination was so entrenched".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his 1963 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_of_the_Union_address" title="State of the Union address">State of the Union address</a>, he proposed substantial tax reform and a reduction in income tax rates from the current range of 20–90% to a range of 14–65% as well as a reduction in the corporate tax rates from 52 to 47%. Kennedy added that the top rate should be set at 70% if certain deductions were not eliminated for high income earners.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jaikumar_2011_228-1"><a href="#cite_note-Jaikumar_2011-228">[228]</a></sup> Congress did not act until 1964, a year after his death, when the top individual rate was lowered to 70%, and the top corporate rate was set at 48%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup>
</p><p>To the <a href="/wiki/Economic_Club_of_New_York" title="Economic Club of New York">Economic Club of New York</a>, he spoke in 1963 of "... the paradoxical truth that tax rates are too high and revenues too low; and the soundest way to raise revenue in the long term is to lower rates now."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993453_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993453-232">[232]</a></sup> Congress passed few of Kennedy's major programs during his lifetime, but did vote them through in 1964 and 1965 under his successor Johnson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarnes20078_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarnes20078-233">[233]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h4>
<p>Kennedy ended a period of tight fiscal policies, loosening monetary policy to keep <a href="/wiki/Interest_rate" title="Interest rate">interest rates</a> down and to encourage growth of the economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrum2000293_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrum2000293-234">[234]</a></sup> He presided over the first government budget to top the $100 billion mark, in 1962, and his first budget in 1961 resulted in the nation's first non-war, non-recession <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government_budget_deficit" title="Government budget deficit">deficit</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrum2000324_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrum2000324-235">[235]</a></sup> The economy, which had been through two recessions in three years and was in one when Kennedy took office, accelerated notably throughout his administration. Despite low inflation and interest rates, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GDP" title="GDP">GDP</a> had grown by an average of only 2.2% per annum during the Eisenhower administration (scarcely more than population growth at the time), and it had declined by 1% during Eisenhower's last twelve months in office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bureau_of_Economic_Analysis_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bureau_of_Economic_Analysis-236">[236]</a></sup>
</p><p>The economy turned around and prospered during Kennedy's years as President. The GDP expanded by an average of 5.5% from early 1961 to late 1963,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bureau_of_Economic_Analysis_236-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bureau_of_Economic_Analysis-236">[236]</a></sup> while inflation remained steady at around 1% and unemployment eased.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GDP_1913_to_2002_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-GDP_1913_to_2002-237">[237]</a></sup> Industrial production rose by 15% and motor vehicle sales increased by 40%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Statistical_Abstract_1964_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Statistical_Abstract_1964-238">[238]</a></sup> This rate of growth in GDP and industry continued until 1969, and has yet to be repeated for such a sustained period of time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bureau_of_Economic_Analysis_236-2"><a href="#cite_note-Bureau_of_Economic_Analysis-236">[236]</a></sup>
</p><p>Attorney General Robert Kennedy took the position that <a href="/wiki/Roger_Blough" title="Roger Blough">steel executives</a> had illegally colluded to fix prices. He stated, "We're going for broke. [...] their expense accounts, where they've been and what they've been doing. [...] the FBI is to interview them all. [...] we can't lose this."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993298_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993298-239">[239]</a></sup> The administration's actions influenced <a href="/wiki/U.S._Steel" title="U.S. Steel">U.S. Steel</a> to rescind the price increase.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Time_1962_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-Time_1962-240">[240]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> wrote that the administration had acted "by naked power, by threats, [and] by agents of the state security police."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005645_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005645-241">[241]</a></sup> Yale law professor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charles_Reich" title="Charles Reich">Charles Reich</a> opined in <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Republic" title="The New Republic">The New Republic</a></i> that the administration had violated civil liberties by calling a grand jury to indict U.S. Steel for collusion so quickly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005645_241-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2005645-241">[241]</a></sup> An editorial in <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> praised Kennedy's actions and said that the steel industry's price increase "imperil[ed] the economic welfare of the country by inviting a tidal wave of inflation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NY_Times_1962_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-NY_Times_1962-242">[242]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the administration's Bureau of Budget reported the price increase would have caused a net gain for the GDP as well as a net budget surplus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993300_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993300-243">[243]</a></sup> The stock market, which had steadily declined since Kennedy's election in 1960, dropped 10% shortly after the administration's action on the steel industry took place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993318–320_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993318–320-244">[244]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Federal_and_military_death_penalty">Federal and military death penalty</span></h4>
<p>During his administration, Kennedy oversaw the last federal execution prior to <i><a href="/wiki/Furman_v._Georgia" title="Furman v. Georgia">Furman v. Georgia</a></i>, a 1972 case that led to a moratorium on federal executions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Victor_Feguer" title="Victor Feguer">Victor Feguer</a> was sentenced to death by an Iowa federal court and was executed on March 15, 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Goldberg_2001_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-Goldberg_2001-246">[246]</a></sup> Kennedy commuted a death sentence imposed by a military court on seaman Jimmie Henderson on February 12, 1962, changing the penalty to life in prison.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Riechmann_2008_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-Riechmann_2008-247">[247]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 22, 1962, Kennedy signed into law HR5143 (PL87-423), which abolished the mandatory death penalty for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_degree_murder_in_the_United_States" title="First degree murder in the United States">first degree murder</a> suspects in the District of Columbia, the only remaining jurisdiction in the United States with such a penalty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_leg_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_leg-248">[248]</a></sup> The death penalty has not been applied in the District of Columbia since 1957, and has now been abolished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_Rights_Movement">Civil Rights Movement</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Thurgood_Marshall_1957-09-17.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5040" data-file-width="3344" decoding="async" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Thurgood_Marshall_1957-09-17.jpg/170px-Thurgood_Marshall_1957-09-17.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Thurgood_Marshall_1957-09-17.jpg/255px-Thurgood_Marshall_1957-09-17.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Thurgood_Marshall_1957-09-17.jpg/340px-Thurgood_Marshall_1957-09-17.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Thurgood_Marshall_1957-09-17.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Thurgood_Marshall" title="Thurgood Marshall">Thurgood Marshall</a>, appointed to the federal bench by Kennedy in May 1961</div></div></div>
<p>The turbulent end of state-sanctioned racial discrimination was one of the most pressing domestic issues of the 1960s. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jim_Crow" title="Jim Crow">Jim Crow</a> <a href="/wiki/Racial_segregation_in_the_United_States" title="Racial segregation in the United States">segregation</a> was the established law in the <a href="/wiki/Deep_South" title="Deep South">Deep South</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grantham_p156_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-Grantham_p156-250">[250]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">U.S. Supreme Court</a> had ruled in 1954 in <i><a href="/wiki/Brown_v._Board_of_Education" title="Brown v. Board of Education">Brown v. Board of Education</a></i> that <a href="/wiki/Racial_segregation" title="Racial segregation">racial segregation</a> in public schools was unconstitutional. Many schools, especially those in southern states, did not obey the Supreme Court's decision. The Court also prohibited segregation at other public facilities (such as buses, restaurants, theaters, courtrooms, bathrooms, and beaches) but it continued nonetheless.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003292–293_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003292–293-251">[251]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy verbally supported <a href="/wiki/Racial_integration" title="Racial integration">racial integration</a> and civil rights; during his 1960 presidential campaign, he telephoned <a href="/wiki/Coretta_Scott_King" title="Coretta Scott King">Coretta Scott King</a>, wife of the Reverend <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">Martin Luther King Jr.</a>, who had been jailed while trying to integrate a department store lunch counter. Robert Kennedy called Georgia governor <a href="/wiki/Ernest_Vandiver" title="Ernest Vandiver">Ernest Vandiver</a> and obtained King's release from prison, which drew additional black support to his brother's candidacy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003292–293_251-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003292–293-251">[251]</a></sup> Upon taking office in 1961, Kennedy postponed promised civil rights legislation he made while campaigning in 1960, recognizing that conservative Southern Democrats controlled congressional legislation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002487_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002487-252">[252]</a></sup> Historian Carl M. Brauer concluded that passing any civil rights legislation in 1961 would have been futile.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002487_252-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002487-252">[252]</a></sup> During his first year in office, Kennedy appointed many blacks to office including his May appointment of civil rights attorney <a href="/wiki/Thurgood_Marshall" title="Thurgood Marshall">Thurgood Marshall</a> to the federal bench. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002490_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002490-253">[253]</a></sup>
</p><p>In his first State of the Union Address in January 1961, President Kennedy said, "The denial of constitutional rights to some of our fellow Americans on account of race – at the ballot box and elsewhere – disturbs the national conscience, and subjects us to the charge of world opinion that our democracy is not equal to the high promise of our heritage."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup> Kennedy believed the grassroots movement for civil rights would anger many Southern whites and make it more difficult to pass civil rights laws in Congress, including anti-poverty legislation, and he distanced himself from it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryant200660,_66_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryant200660,_66-255">[255]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy was concerned with other issues in the early part of his administration, such as the Cold War, Bay of Pigs fiasco, and the situation in Southeast Asia. As articulated by his brother Robert, the administration's early priority was to "keep the president out of this civil rights mess." Civil rights movement participants, mainly those on the front line in the South, viewed Kennedy as lukewarm, <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002490_253-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002490-253">[253]</a></sup> especially concerning the <a href="/wiki/Freedom_Riders" title="Freedom Riders">Freedom Riders</a>, who organized an integrated public transportation effort in the south, and who were repeatedly met with white mob violence, including by law enforcement officers, both federal and state. Kennedy assigned <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_marshal" title="Federal marshal">federal marshals</a> to protect the Freedom Riders rather than using federal troops or uncooperative FBI agents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002490_253-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002490-253">[253]</a></sup> Robert Kennedy, speaking for the president, urged the Freedom Riders to "get off the buses and leave the matter to peaceful settlement in the courts."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993123–126_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993123–126-256">[256]</a></sup> Kennedy feared sending federal troops would stir up "hated memories of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reconstruction_Era" title="Reconstruction Era">Reconstruction</a>" after the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">Civil War</a> among conservative Southern whites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002490_253-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002490-253">[253]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 6, 1961, Kennedy signed <a href="/wiki/Executive_Order_10925" title="Executive Order 10925">Executive Order 10925</a>, which required government contractors to "take affirmative action to ensure that applicants are employed and that employees are treated during employment without regard to their race, creed, color, or national origin."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup> It established the <a href="/wiki/Equal_Employment_Opportunity_Commission#Background" title="Equal Employment Opportunity Commission">President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity</a>. Displeased with Kennedy's pace addressing the issue of segregation, Martin Luther King Jr. and his associates produced a document in 1962 calling on the president to follow in the footsteps of <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a> and use an Executive Order to deliver a blow for Civil Rights as a kind of <a href="/wiki/Second_Emancipation_Proclamation" title="Second Emancipation Proclamation">Second Emancipation Proclamation</a>. Kennedy did not execute the order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kennedyandking1_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-kennedyandking1-258">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 1962, <a href="/wiki/James_Meredith" title="James Meredith">James Meredith</a> enrolled at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Mississippi" title="University of Mississippi">University of Mississippi</a> but was prevented from entering. In response to that, Robert Kennedy, now U.S. Attorney General, sent 400 federal marshals, while President Kennedy reluctantly sent 3,000 troops after the situation on campus turned out violent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryant200671_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryant200671-259">[259]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ole_Miss_riot_of_1962" title="Ole Miss riot of 1962">Ole Miss riot of 1962</a> left two people dead and a dozen others injured, but Meredith did finally enroll for class. Kennedy regretted not sending in troops earlier and he began doubting as to whether the "evils of Reconstruction" of the 1860s and 1870s he had been taught or believed in were true.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002490_253-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002490-253">[253]</a></sup> The instigating subculture at the Old Miss riot, and at many other racially ignited events, was the <a href="/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan" title="Ku Klux Klan">Ku Klux Klan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gitlin_p29_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gitlin_p29-260">[260]</a></sup> On November 20, 1962, Kennedy signed <a href="/wiki/Executive_Order_11063" title="Executive Order 11063">Executive Order 11063</a>, which prohibited racial discrimination in federally supported housing or "related facilities".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003580_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003580-261">[261]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both the President and the Attorney General were concerned about King's ties to suspected Communists <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jack_O%27Dell" title="Jack O'Dell">Jack O'Dell</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stanley_Levison" title="Stanley Levison">Stanley Levison</a>. After the President and his civil rights expert <a href="/wiki/Harris_Wofford" title="Harris Wofford">Harris Wofford</a> pressed King to ask both men to resign from the SCLC, King agreed to ask only O'Dell to resign from the organization and allowed Levison, whom he regarded as a trusted advisor, to remain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kennedyandking2_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-kennedyandking2-262">[262]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 1963, Kennedy related to Martin Luther King Jr. his thoughts on the prospects for civil rights legislation: "If we get into a long fight over this in Congress, it will bottleneck everything else, and we will still get no bill."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993467_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993467-263">[263]</a></sup> Civil rights clashes were on the rise that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[264]</a></sup> Brother Robert and Ted Sorenson pressed Kennedy to take more initiative on the legislative front.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993515_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993515-265">[265]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights,_11_June_1963.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="963" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="279" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights%2C_11_June_1963.jpg/220px-President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights%2C_11_June_1963.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights%2C_11_June_1963.jpg/330px-President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights%2C_11_June_1963.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights%2C_11_June_1963.jpg/440px-President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights%2C_11_June_1963.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights,_11_June_1963.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy's <a href="/wiki/Report_to_the_American_People_on_Civil_Rights" title="Report to the American People on Civil Rights">Report to the American People on Civil Rights</a>, June 11, 1963</div></div></div>
<p>On June 11, 1963, President Kennedy intervened when Alabama Governor <a href="/wiki/George_Wallace" title="George Wallace">George Wallace</a> blocked the <a href="/wiki/Stand_in_the_Schoolhouse_Door" title="Stand in the Schoolhouse Door">doorway</a> to the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Alabama" title="University of Alabama">University of Alabama</a> to stop two African American students, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vivian_Malone" title="Vivian Malone">Vivian Malone</a> and <a href="/wiki/James_Hood" title="James Hood">James Hood</a>, from attending. Wallace moved aside only after being confronted by Deputy Attorney General Nicholas Katzenbach and the Alabama <a href="/wiki/United_States_National_Guard" title="United States National Guard">U.S. National Guard</a>, which had just been federalized by order of the president. That evening Kennedy gave his famous <a href="/wiki/Report_to_the_American_People_on_Civil_Rights" title="Report to the American People on Civil Rights">Report to the American People on Civil Rights</a> on national television and radio, launching his initiative for civil rights legislation—to provide equal access to public schools and other facilities, and greater protection of voting rights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993521–523_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993521–523-266">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[267]</a></sup>
</p><p>His proposals became part of the <a href="/wiki/Civil_Rights_Act_of_1964" title="Civil Rights Act of 1964">Civil Rights Act of 1964</a>. The day ended with the murder of a NAACP leader, <a href="/wiki/Medgar_Evers" title="Medgar Evers">Medgar Evers</a>, in front of his home in Mississippi.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002966_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchlesinger2002966-268">[268]</a></sup> As the president had predicted, the day after his TV speech, and in reaction to it, House Majority leader Carl Albert called to advise him that his two-year signature effort in Congress to combat poverty in Appalachia (Area Redevelopment Administration) had been defeated, primarily by the votes of Southern Democrats and Republicans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993524_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993524-269">[269]</a></sup> When Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. complimented Kennedy on his remarks, Kennedy bitterly replied, "Yes, and look at what happened to area development the very next day in the House." He then added, "But of course, I had to give that speech, and I'm glad that I did."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECohen2016357_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECohen2016357-270">[270]</a></sup> On June 16, <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> published an editorial which argued that while the president had initially "moved too slowly and with little evidence of deep moral commitment" in regards to civil rights he "now demonstrate[d] a genuine sense of urgency about eradicating racial discrimination from our national life."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoduti_Jr.2012206_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoduti_Jr.2012206-271">[271]</a></sup>
</p><p>Earlier, Kennedy had signed the executive order creating the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_Commission_on_the_Status_of_Women" title="Presidential Commission on the Status of Women">Presidential Commission on the Status of Women</a> on December 14, 1961.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-executive_order_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-executive_order-272">[272]</a></sup> Former First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt led the commission. The Commission statistics revealed that women were also experiencing discrimination; its final report, documenting legal and cultural barriers, was issued in October 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993433_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993433-273">[273]</a></sup> Further, on June 10, 1963, Kennedy signed the <a href="/wiki/Equal_Pay_Act_of_1963" title="Equal Pay Act of 1963">Equal Pay Act of 1963</a>, which amended the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fair_Labor_Standards_Act" title="Fair Labor Standards Act">Fair Labor Standards Act</a> and abolished wage disparity based on sex.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Photograph_of_Meeting_with_Leaders_of_the_March_on_Washington_August_28,_1963_-_NARA_-_194276.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2944" data-file-width="2936" decoding="async" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Photograph_of_Meeting_with_Leaders_of_the_March_on_Washington_August_28%2C_1963_-_NARA_-_194276.jpg/220px-Photograph_of_Meeting_with_Leaders_of_the_March_on_Washington_August_28%2C_1963_-_NARA_-_194276.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Photograph_of_Meeting_with_Leaders_of_the_March_on_Washington_August_28%2C_1963_-_NARA_-_194276.jpg/330px-Photograph_of_Meeting_with_Leaders_of_the_March_on_Washington_August_28%2C_1963_-_NARA_-_194276.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Photograph_of_Meeting_with_Leaders_of_the_March_on_Washington_August_28%2C_1963_-_NARA_-_194276.jpg/440px-Photograph_of_Meeting_with_Leaders_of_the_March_on_Washington_August_28%2C_1963_-_NARA_-_194276.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Photograph_of_Meeting_with_Leaders_of_the_March_on_Washington_August_28,_1963_-_NARA_-_194276.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy meets with leaders of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/March_on_Washington" title="March on Washington">March on Washington</a> in the Oval Office, August 28, 1963</div></div></div>
<p>Over a hundred thousand, predominantly African Americans gathered in Washington for the civil rights <a href="/wiki/March_on_Washington_for_Jobs_and_Freedom" title="March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom">March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom</a> on August 28, 1963. Kennedy feared the March would have a negative effect on the prospects for the civil rights bills in Congress, and declined an invitation to speak. He turned over some of the details of the government's involvement to the Dept. of Justice, which channelled hundreds of thousands of dollars to the six sponsors of the March, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Association_for_the_Advancement_of_Colored_People" title="National Association for the Advancement of Colored People">N.A.A.C.P.</a> and Martin Luther King's <a href="/wiki/Southern_Christian_Leadership_Conference" title="Southern Christian Leadership Conference">Southern Christian Leadership Conference</a> (SCLC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993580–584_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993580–584-275">[275]</a></sup>
</p><p>To ensure a peaceful demonstration, the organizers and the president personally edited speeches which were inflammatory and agreed the March would be held on a Wednesday and would be over at 4:00 pm. Thousands of troops were placed on standby. Kennedy watched King's speech on TV and was very impressed. The March was considered a "triumph of managed protest", and not one arrest relating to the demonstration occurred. Afterwards, the March leaders accepted an invitation to the White House to meet with Kennedy and photos were taken. Kennedy felt that the March was a victory for him as well and bolstered the chances for his civil rights bill.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993580–584_275-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993580–584-275">[275]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nevertheless, the struggle was far from over. Three weeks later, <a href="/wiki/16th_Street_Baptist_Church_bombing" title="16th Street Baptist Church bombing">a bomb exploded</a> on Sunday, September 15, at the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham; by the end of the day, four African American children had died in the explosion, and two other children were shot to death in the aftermath.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993599–600_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993599–600-276">[276]</a></sup> Due to this resurgent violence, the civil rights legislation underwent some drastic amendments that critically endangered any prospects for passage of the bill, to the outrage of the president. Kennedy called the congressional leaders to the White House and by the following day the original bill, without the additions, had enough votes to get it out of the House committee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993628–631_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993628–631-277">[277]</a></sup> Gaining Republican support, Senator <a href="/wiki/Everett_Dirksen" title="Everett Dirksen">Everett Dirksen</a> promised the legislation would be brought to a vote preventing a <a href="/wiki/Filibuster_in_the_United_States_Senate" title="Filibuster in the United States Senate">Senate filibuster</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002492_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002492-278">[278]</a></sup> The legislation was enacted by Kennedy's successor President Lyndon B. Johnson, prompted by Kennedy's memory, after his assassination in November, enforcing voting rights, public accommodations, employment, education, and the administration of justice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002492_278-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002492-278">[278]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_liberties">Civil liberties</span></h3>
<p>In February 1962,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kingandkennedy3_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-kingandkennedy3-279">[279]</a></sup> FBI Director <a href="/wiki/J._Edgar_Hoover" title="J. Edgar Hoover">J. Edgar Hoover</a>, who was suspicious of civil-rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. and viewed him as an upstart troublemaker,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-american_public_radio_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-american_public_radio-280">[280]</a></sup> presented the Kennedy Administration with allegations that some of King's close confidants and advisers were communists. Concerned by these allegations, the FBI deployed agents to monitor King in the following months.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kingandkennedy3_279-1"><a href="#cite_note-kingandkennedy3-279">[279]</a></sup> Robert Kennedy and the president also both warned King to discontinue the suspect associations. After the associations continued, Robert Kennedy issued a written directive authorizing the FBI to wiretap King and other leaders of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, King's civil rights organization, in October 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kingandkennedy3_279-2"><a href="#cite_note-kingandkennedy3-279">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although Kennedy only gave written approval for limited wiretapping of King's phones "on a trial basis, for a month or so",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHerst2007372_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHerst2007372-281">[281]</a></sup> Hoover extended the clearance so his men were "unshackled" to look for evidence in any areas of King's life they deemed worthy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHerst2007372–374_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHerst2007372–374-282">[282]</a></sup> The wiretapping continued through June 1966 and was revealed in 1968.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-the_atlantic_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-the_atlantic-283">[283]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Immigration">Immigration</span></h3>
<p>During the 1960 campaign Kennedy proposed an overhaul of American immigration and naturalization laws to ban discrimination based on national origin. He saw this proposal as an extension of his planned civil rights agenda as president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[284]</a></sup> These reforms later became <a href="/wiki/United_States_Code" title="United States Code">law</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Immigration_and_Nationality_Act_of_1965" title="Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965">Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965</a>, which dramatically shifted the source of immigration from Northern and Western European countries towards immigration from Latin America and Asia. The policy change also shifted the emphasis in the selection of immigrants in favor of family reunification. The late-president's brother, Senator <a href="/wiki/Ted_Kennedy" title="Ted Kennedy">Edward Kennedy</a> helped steer the legislation through the Senate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[285]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Native_American_relations">Native American relations</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Kinzua_Dam#Native_Americans" title="Kinzua Dam">Kinzua Dam § Native Americans</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seneca_nation#Kinzua_Dam" title="Seneca nation">Seneca nation § Kinzua Dam</a></div>
<p>Construction of the <a href="/wiki/Kinzua_Dam" title="Kinzua Dam">Kinzua Dam</a> flooded 10,000 acres (4,047 ha) of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seneca_nation" title="Seneca nation">Seneca nation</a> land that they had occupied under the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Canandaigua" title="Treaty of Canandaigua">Treaty of 1794</a>, and forced 600 Seneca to relocate to <a href="/wiki/Salamanca_(town),_New_York" title="Salamanca (town), New York">Salamanca, New York</a>. Kennedy was asked by the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_Liberties_Union" title="American Civil Liberties Union">American Civil Liberties Union</a> to intervene and to halt the project, but he declined, citing a critical need for flood control. He expressed concern about the plight of the Seneca, and directed government agencies to assist in obtaining more land, damages, and assistance to help mitigate their displacement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBilharz200255_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBilharz200255-286">[286]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kennedy_letter_1961_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kennedy_letter_1961-287">[287]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Space_policy">Space policy</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">Space Race</a> and <a href="/wiki/Space_policy_of_the_United_States" title="Space policy of the United States">Space policy of the United States</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Apollo_program" title="Apollo program">Apollo program</a> was conceived early in 1960, during the Eisenhower administration, as a follow-up to <a href="/wiki/Project_Mercury" title="Project Mercury">Project Mercury</a>, to be used as a shuttle to an Earth-orbital <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a>, flights around the Moon, or landing on it. While <a href="/wiki/NASA" title="NASA">NASA</a> went ahead with planning for Apollo, funding for the program was far from certain, given Eisenhower's ambivalent attitude to manned spaceflight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup> As senator, Kennedy had been opposed to the space program and wanted to terminate it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993138_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993138-289">[289]</a></sup>
</p><p>In constructing his Presidential administration, Kennedy elected to retain Eisenhower's last science advisor <a href="/wiki/Jerome_Wiesner" title="Jerome Wiesner">Jerome Wiesner</a> as head of the <a href="/wiki/President%27s_Science_Advisory_Committee" title="President's Science Advisory Committee">President's Science Advisory Committee</a>. Wiesner was strongly opposed to manned space exploration,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENelson2009145_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENelson2009145-290">[290]</a></sup> having issued a report highly critical of Project Mercury.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup> Kennedy was turned down by seventeen candidates for NASA administrator before the post was accepted by <a href="/wiki/James_E._Webb" title="James E. Webb">James E. Webb</a>, an experienced Washington insider who served President Truman as budget director and undersecretary of state. Webb proved to be adept at obtaining the support of Congress, the President, and the American people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENelson2009146_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENelson2009146-293">[293]</a></sup> Kennedy also persuaded Congress to amend the <a href="/wiki/National_Aeronautics_and_Space_Act" title="National Aeronautics and Space Act">National Aeronautics and Space Act</a> to allow him to delegate his chairmanship of the National Aeronautics and Space Council to the Vice President,
<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENelson2009146_293-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENelson2009146-293">[293]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKenney2000115–116_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKenney2000115–116-294">[294]</a></sup> both because of the knowledge of the space program Johnson gained in the Senate working for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_creation_of_NASA" title="The creation of NASA">the creation of NASA</a>, and to help keep the politically savvy Johnson occupied.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENelson2009146_293-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENelson2009146-293">[293]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Kennedy's January 1961 State of the Union address, he had suggested international cooperation in space. Khrushchev declined, as the Soviets did not wish to reveal the status of their rocketry and space capabilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003502_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003502-295">[295]</a></sup> Early in his presidency, Kennedy was poised to dismantle the manned space program, but postponed any decision out of deference to Johnson, who had been a strong supporter of the space program in the Senate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993138_289-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993138-289">[289]</a></sup> Kennedy's advisors speculated that a Moon flight would be prohibitively expensive,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003392_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003392-296">[296]</a></sup> and he was considering plans to dismantle the Apollo program due to its cost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kennedy_Giving_Historic_Speech_to_Congress_-_GPN-2000-001658.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2230" data-file-width="2940" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Kennedy_Giving_Historic_Speech_to_Congress_-_GPN-2000-001658.jpg/220px-Kennedy_Giving_Historic_Speech_to_Congress_-_GPN-2000-001658.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Kennedy_Giving_Historic_Speech_to_Congress_-_GPN-2000-001658.jpg/330px-Kennedy_Giving_Historic_Speech_to_Congress_-_GPN-2000-001658.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Kennedy_Giving_Historic_Speech_to_Congress_-_GPN-2000-001658.jpg/440px-Kennedy_Giving_Historic_Speech_to_Congress_-_GPN-2000-001658.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kennedy_Giving_Historic_Speech_to_Congress_-_GPN-2000-001658.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy proposing a program to Congress that will land men on the Moon, May 1961. Johnson and Sam Rayburn are seated behind him.</div></div></div>
<p>However, this quickly changed on April 12, 1961, when Soviet cosmonaut <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin" title="Yuri Gagarin">Yuri Gagarin</a> became the first person to fly in space, reinforcing American fears about being left behind in a technological competition with the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003393_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003393-298">[298]</a></sup> Kennedy now became eager for the U.S. to take the lead in the <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">Space Race</a>, for reasons of national security and prestige. On April 20, he sent a memo to Johnson, asking him to look into the status of America's space program, and into programs that could offer NASA the opportunity to catch up.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jfkmemo_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-jfkmemo-299">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> After consulting with <a href="/wiki/Wernher_von_Braun" title="Wernher von Braun">Wernher von Braun</a>, Johnson responded approximately one week later, concluding that "we are neither making maximum effort nor achieving results necessary if this country is to reach a position of leadership."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lbjmemo_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-lbjmemo-301">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup> His memo concluded that a manned Moon landing was far enough in the future that it was likely the United States would achieve it first.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lbjmemo_301-1"><a href="#cite_note-lbjmemo-301">[301]</a></sup> Kennedy's advisor Ted Sorensen advised him to support the Moon landing, and on May 25, Kennedy announced the goal in a speech titled "Special Message to the Congress on Urgent National Needs":
</p>
<blockquote><p>...  I believe that this nation should commit itself to achieving the goal, before this decade is out, of landing a man on the Moon and returning him safely to the Earth. No single space project in this period will be more impressive to mankind, or more important for the long-range exploration of space; and none will be so difficult or expensive to accomplish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kennedy_at_Congress_1961_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kennedy_at_Congress_1961-303">[303]</a></sup> <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Special_Message_to_the_Congress_on_Urgent_National_Needs" title="s:Special Message to the Congress on Urgent National Needs">Full text</a> <a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title='Wikisource has information on "Special Message to the Congress on Urgent National Needs"'><img alt='Wikisource has information on "Special Message to the Congress on Urgent National Needs"' data-file-height="430" data-file-width="410" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/11px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/17px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/22px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></p></blockquote>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><div class="PopUpMediaTransform" id="mwe_player_6" style="width:220px;" videopayload='&lt;div class="mediaContainer" style="width:322px"&gt;&lt;video id="mwe_player_7" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv/321px--President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv.jpg" controls="" preload="none" autoplay="" style="width:322px;height:240px" class="kskin" data-durationhint="1067.1994666667" data-startoffset="0" data-mwtitle="President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University,_September_12,_1962.ogv" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons"&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/d0/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv.240p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" data-transcodekey="240p.webm" data-width="322" data-height="240" data-bandwidth="318840" data-framerate="29.97002997003"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/d0/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv.240p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;" data-title="Small VP9 (240P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 240P" data-transcodekey="240p.vp9.webm" data-width="322" data-height="240" data-bandwidth="386480" data-framerate="29.97002997003"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/d0/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv.120p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;" data-title="Lowest bandwidth VP9 (120P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 120P" data-transcodekey="120p.vp9.webm" data-width="160" data-height="120" data-bandwidth="183536" data-framerate="29.97002997003"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/d0/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv.160p.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp8, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Low bandwidth WebM (160P)" data-shorttitle="WebM 160P" data-transcodekey="160p.webm" data-width="214" data-height="160" data-bandwidth="196488" data-framerate="29.97002997003"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/d0/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv.180p.vp9.webm" type="video/webm; codecs=&amp;quot;vp9, opus&amp;quot;" data-title="Low bandwidth VP9 (180P)" data-shorttitle="VP9 180P" data-transcodekey="180p.vp9.webm" data-width="240" data-height="180" data-bandwidth="275232" data-framerate="29.97002997003"/&gt;&lt;source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d0/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv" type="video/ogg; codecs=&amp;quot;theora, vorbis&amp;quot;" data-title="Original Ogg file, 321 × 240 (526 kbps)" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-width="321" data-height="240" data-bandwidth="525845" data-framerate="29.97002997003"/&gt;&lt;/video&gt;&lt;/div&gt;'><img alt="File:President Kennedy speech on the space effort at Rice University, September 12, 1962.ogv" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv/220px-seek%3D1052-President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv.jpg" style="width:220px;height:164px"/><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d0/President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University%2C_September_12%2C_1962.ogv" target="new" title="Play media"><span class="play-btn-large"><span class="mw-tmh-playtext">Play media</span></span></a></div> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_speech_on_the_space_effort_at_Rice_University,_September_12,_1962.ogv" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy speaks at Rice University, September 12, 1962 (duration 17:47)</div></div></div>
<p>After Congress authorized the funding, Webb began reorganizing NASA, increasing its staffing level, and building two new centers: a <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_Space_Center" title="Kennedy Space Center">Launch Operations Center</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Saturn_V" title="Saturn V">large Moon rocket</a> northwest of <a href="/wiki/Cape_Canaveral_Air_Force_Station" title="Cape Canaveral Air Force Station">Cape Canaveral Air Force Station</a>, and a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson_Space_Center" title="Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center">Manned Spacecraft Center</a> on land donated through <a href="/wiki/Rice_University" title="Rice University">Rice University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Houston" title="Houston">Houston</a>, Texas. Kennedy took the latter occasion as an opportunity to deliver another <a href="/wiki/We_choose_to_go_to_the_Moon" title="We choose to go to the Moon">speech</a> at Rice to promote the space effort on September 12, 1962, in which he said:
</p>
<blockquote><p> No nation which expects to be the leader of other nations can expect to stay behind in this race for space. ... We choose to go to the Moon in this decade and do the other things, not because they are easy, but because they are hard.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kennedy_at_Rice_1961_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kennedy_at_Rice_1961-304">[304]</a></sup> <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/We_choose_to_go_to_the_moon" title="s:We choose to go to the moon">Full text</a> <a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title='Wikisource has information on "We choose to go to the moon"'><img alt='Wikisource has information on "We choose to go to the moon"' data-file-height="430" data-file-width="410" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/11px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/17px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/22px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></p></blockquote>
<p>On November 21, 1962, in a cabinet meeting with NASA administrator Webb and other officials, Kennedy explained that the Moon shot was important for reasons of international prestige, and that the expense was justified.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[305]</a></sup> Johnson assured him that lessons learned from the space program had military value as well. Costs for the Apollo program were expected to reach $40 billion (equivalent to $331.31 billion in 2018).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003652–653_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003652–653-306">[306]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a September 1963 speech before the United Nations, Kennedy urged cooperation between the Soviets and Americans in space, specifically recommending that Apollo be switched to "a joint expedition to the Moon".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup> Khrushchev again declined, and the Soviets did not commit to a manned Moon mission until 1964.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003654_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003654-308">[308]</a></sup> On July 20, 1969, almost six years after Kennedy's death, <a href="/wiki/Apollo_11" title="Apollo 11">Apollo 11</a> landed the first manned spacecraft on the Moon.
</p>
<h3><span id="Administration.2C_Cabinet.2C_and_judicial_appointments"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Administration,_Cabinet,_and_judicial_appointments">Administration, Cabinet, and judicial appointments</span></h3>
<table class="infobox" style="width:auto;text-align:left;line-height:1.2em;margin-left:0; margin-right:1em; float:left; clear:left;"><tbody><tr><th colspan="3" style="line-height:1.5em;font-size:110%;background:#DCDCDC;text-align:center">The Kennedy Cabinet</th></tr><tr><th>Office</th><th>Name</th><th>Term</th></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="background:#000"></td></tr><tr><td><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President</a></td><th style="font-weight:bold">John F.
