Gronouski</a></th><td>1963</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="background:#D1D1D1"></td></tr><tr><td><a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Interior" title="United States Secretary of the Interior">Secretary of the Interior</a></td><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Stewart_Udall" title="Stewart Udall">Stewart Udall</a></th><td>1961–1963</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="background:#D1D1D1"></td></tr><tr><td><a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Agriculture" title="United States Secretary of Agriculture">Secretary of Agriculture</a></td><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Orville_Freeman" title="Orville Freeman">Orville Freeman</a></th><td>1961–1963</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="background:#D1D1D1"></td></tr><tr><td><a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Commerce" title="United States Secretary of Commerce">Secretary of Commerce</a></td><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Luther_H._Hodges" title="Luther H. Hodges">Luther H. Ribicoff">Abraham A. Ribicoff</a></th><td>1961–1962</td></tr><tr class="mw-empty-elt"></tr><tr><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Anthony_J._Celebrezze" title="Anthony J. Celebrezze">Anthony J. Celebrezze</a></th><td>1962–1963</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F_Kennedy_Official_Portrait.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2029" decoding="async" height="355" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/John_F_Kennedy_Official_Portrait.jpg/240px-John_F_Kennedy_Official_Portrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/John_F_Kennedy_Official_Portrait.jpg/360px-John_F_Kennedy_Official_Portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/John_F_Kennedy_Official_Portrait.jpg/480px-John_F_Kennedy_Official_Portrait.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_F_Kennedy_Official_Portrait.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The official White House portrait of John F. Kennedy, painted by <a href="/wiki/Aaron_Shikler" title="Aaron Shikler">Aaron Shikler</a></div></div></div>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Judicial_appointments">Judicial appointments</span></h4>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Supreme_Court">Supreme Court</span></h5>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Supreme_Court_candidates" title="John F. Kennedy Supreme Court candidates">John F. Kennedy Supreme Court candidates</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_nominations_to_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="List of nominations to the Supreme Court of the United States">List of nominations to the Supreme Court of the United States</a></div>
<p>Kennedy appointed the following Justices to the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court of the United States</a>:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Byron_White" title="Byron White">Byron White</a> – 1962</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Arthur_Goldberg" title="Arthur Goldberg">Arthur Goldberg</a> – 1962</li></ul>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_courts">Other courts</span></h5>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_federal_judges_appointed_by_John_F._Kennedy" title="List of federal judges appointed by John F. Kennedy">List of federal judges appointed by John F. Kennedy</a></div>
<p>In addition to his two Supreme Court appointments, Kennedy appointed 21 judges to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_Courts_of_Appeals" title="United States Courts of Appeals">United States Courts of Appeals</a>, and 102 judges to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_district_court" title="United States district court">United States district courts</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Assassination">Assassination</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Assassination of John F. Kennedy">Assassination of John F. Kennedy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_motorcade,_Dallas_crop.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2444" data-file-width="3641" decoding="async" height="168" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/John_F._Kennedy_motorcade%2C_Dallas_crop.png/250px-John_F._Kennedy_motorcade%2C_Dallas_crop.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/John_F._Kennedy_motorcade%2C_Dallas_crop.png/375px-John_F._Kennedy_motorcade%2C_Dallas_crop.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/John_F._Kennedy_motorcade%2C_Dallas_crop.png/500px-John_F._Kennedy_motorcade%2C_Dallas_crop.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_F._Kennedy_motorcade,_Dallas_crop.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Kennedys and the Connallys in the presidential limousine moments before the <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Assassination of John F. Kennedy">assassination</a> in Dallas</div></div></div>
<p>President Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas, Texas, at 12:30 pm <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Time_Zone_(Americas)" title="Central Time Zone (Americas)">Central Standard Time</a> on Friday, November 22, 1963. He was in Texas on a political trip to smooth over frictions in the Democratic Party between liberals <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Yarborough" title="Ralph Yarborough">Ralph Yarborough</a> and <a href="/wiki/Don_Yarborough" title="Don Yarborough">Don Yarborough</a> (no relation) and conservative <a href="/wiki/John_Connally" title="John Connally">John Connally</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[309]</a></sup> Traveling in a presidential <a href="/wiki/Motorcade" title="Motorcade">motorcade</a> through downtown Dallas, he was shot once in the back, the bullet exiting via his throat, and once in the head.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy was taken to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parkland_Hospital" title="Parkland Hospital">Parkland Hospital</a> for emergency medical treatment, where he was pronounced dead 30 minutes later. He was 46 years old and had been in office for 1,036 days. <a href="/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald" title="Lee Harvey Oswald">Lee Harvey Oswald</a>, an order filler at the <a href="/wiki/Texas_School_Book_Depository" title="Texas School Book Depository">Texas School Book Depository</a> from which the shots were suspected to have been fired, was arrested for the murder of police officer <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J.D._Tippit" title="J.D. Tippit">J.D. Tippit</a>, and was subsequently charged with Kennedy's assassination. He denied shooting anyone, claiming he was a <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/patsy" title="wikt:patsy">patsy</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup> and was shot by <a href="/wiki/Jack_Ruby" title="Jack Ruby">Jack Ruby</a> on November 24, before he could be prosecuted. Ruby was arrested and convicted for the murder of Oswald. Ruby successfully appealed his conviction and death sentence but became ill and died of cancer on January 3, 1967, while the date for his new trial was being set.
</p><p>President Johnson quickly issued an executive order to create the <a href="/wiki/Warren_Commission" title="Warren Commission">Warren Commission</a>—chaired by Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/Earl_Warren" title="Earl Warren">Earl Warren</a>—to investigate the assassination. The commission concluded that Oswald acted alone in killing Kennedy and that Oswald was not part of any conspiracy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002497_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002497-313">[313]</a></sup> The results of this investigation are disputed by many.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Russo_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-Russo-314">[314]</a></sup> The assassination proved to be a pivotal moment in <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_States" title="History of the United States">U.S. history</a> because of its impact on the nation, and the ensuing political repercussions. A 2004 Fox News poll found that 66% of Americans thought there had been a <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_assassination_conspiracy_theories" title="John F. Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories">conspiracy to kill President Kennedy</a>, while 74% thought that there had been a cover-up.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[315]</a></sup> A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallup_Poll" title="Gallup Poll">Gallup Poll</a> in November 2013 showed 61% believed in a conspiracy, and only 30% thought that Oswald did it alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[316]</a></sup> In 1979, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._House_Select_Committee_on_Assassinations" title="U.S. House Select Committee on Assassinations">U.S. House Select Committee on Assassinations</a> concluded that it believed "that Kennedy was probably assassinated as a result of a <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_assassination_conspiracy_theories" title="John F. Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories">conspiracy</a>. The committee was unable to identify the other gunmen or the extent of the conspiracy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[317]</a></sup> In 2002, historian Carl M. Brauer concluded that the public's "fascination with the assassination may indicate a psychological denial of Kennedy's death, a mass wish ... to undo it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002497_313-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrauer_2002497-313">[313]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Funeral">Funeral</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/State_funeral_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="State funeral of John F. Kennedy">State funeral of John F. Kennedy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFK%27s_family_leaves_Capitol_after_his_funeral,_1963.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2336" data-file-width="2954" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/JFK%27s_family_leaves_Capitol_after_his_funeral%2C_1963.jpg/220px-JFK%27s_family_leaves_Capitol_after_his_funeral%2C_1963.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/JFK%27s_family_leaves_Capitol_after_his_funeral%2C_1963.jpg/330px-JFK%27s_family_leaves_Capitol_after_his_funeral%2C_1963.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/JFK%27s_family_leaves_Capitol_after_his_funeral%2C_1963.jpg/440px-JFK%27s_family_leaves_Capitol_after_his_funeral%2C_1963.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFK%27s_family_leaves_Capitol_after_his_funeral,_1963.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President Kennedy's family leaving his <a href="/wiki/State_funeral_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="State funeral of John F. Kennedy">funeral</a> at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Capitol_Building" title="U.S. Capitol Building">U.S. Capitol Building</a></div></div></div>
<p>A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Requiem_Mass" title="Requiem Mass">Requiem Mass</a> was celebrated for Kennedy at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_St._Matthew_the_Apostle" title="Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle">Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle</a> on November 25, 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBugliosi2007211_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBugliosi2007211-318">[318]</a></sup> Afterwards, Kennedy was interred in a small plot, 20 by 30 ft., in <a href="/wiki/Arlington_National_Cemetery" title="Arlington National Cemetery">Arlington National Cemetery</a>. Over a period of three years (1964–1966), an estimated 16 million people visited his grave. On March 14, 1967, Kennedy's remains were disinterred and moved only a few feet away to a permanent burial plot and memorial. It was from this memorial that the graves of both Robert and Ted Kennedy were modeled.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Honor_guard" title="Honor guard">honor guard</a> at Kennedy's graveside was the 37th Cadet Class of the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Army" title="Irish Army">Irish Army</a>. Kennedy was greatly impressed by the Irish Cadets on his last official visit to Ireland, so much so that Jackie Kennedy requested the Irish Army to be the honor guard at her husband's funeral.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBugliosi2007312_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBugliosi2007312-319">[319]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy's wife Jacqueline and their two deceased minor children were later interred in the same plot. JFK's brother Robert <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_assassination" title="Robert F. Kennedy assassination">was buried nearby</a> in June 1968. In August 2009, Ted was also buried near his two brothers. John F. Kennedy's grave is lit with an "<a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Eternal_Flame" title="John F. Kennedy Eternal Flame">Eternal Flame</a>". Kennedy and <a href="/wiki/William_Howard_Taft" title="William Howard Taft">William Howard Taft</a> are the only two U.S. presidents buried at Arlington.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[321]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Presidential_Library_and_Museum" title="John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum">JFK Library</a>, "I Have a Rendezvous with Death", by <a href="/wiki/Alan_Seeger" title="Alan Seeger">Alan Seeger</a> "was one of John F. Kennedy's favorite poems and he often asked his wife to recite it".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Personal_life.2C_family.2C_and_reputation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life,_family,_and_reputation">Personal life, family, and reputation</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_family" title="Kennedy family">Kennedy family</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kennedy_Family_with_Dogs_During_a_Weekend_at_Hyannisport_1963-crop.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1957" data-file-width="2662" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Kennedy_Family_with_Dogs_During_a_Weekend_at_Hyannisport_1963-crop.png/220px-Kennedy_Family_with_Dogs_During_a_Weekend_at_Hyannisport_1963-crop.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Kennedy_Family_with_Dogs_During_a_Weekend_at_Hyannisport_1963-crop.png/330px-Kennedy_Family_with_Dogs_During_a_Weekend_at_Hyannisport_1963-crop.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Kennedy_Family_with_Dogs_During_a_Weekend_at_Hyannisport_1963-crop.png/440px-Kennedy_Family_with_Dogs_During_a_Weekend_at_Hyannisport_1963-crop.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kennedy_Family_with_Dogs_During_a_Weekend_at_Hyannisport_1963-crop.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_family" title="Kennedy family">Kennedy family</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hyannis_Port,_Massachusetts" title="Hyannis Port, Massachusetts">Hyannis Port</a>, Massachusetts, in 1963</div></div></div>
<p>The Kennedy family is one of the most established political families in the United States, having produced a president, three senators, three ambassadors, and multiple other representatives and politicians, both at the federal and state level. While a Congressman, Kennedy embarked on a seven-week trip to India, Japan, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, and Israel in 1951, at which point he became close with his then 25-year-old brother <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy" title="Robert F. Kennedy">Bobby</a>, as well as his 27-year-old sister Pat. Because they were several years apart in age, the brothers had previously seen little of each other. This 25,000-mile (40,000 km) trip was the first extended time they had spent together and resulted in their becoming best friends.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199329_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199329-323">[323]</a></sup> Bobby would eventually play a major role in his brother's career, serving as his brother's <a href="/wiki/United_States_Attorney_General" title="United States Attorney General">Attorney General</a> and presidential advisor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199329_323-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199329-323">[323]</a></sup> Bobby would later run for president in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1968" title="United States presidential election, 1968">1968</a> before his <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Robert_F._Kennedy" title="Assassination of Robert F. Kennedy">assassination</a>, while another Kennedy brother, Ted, ran for president in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1980" title="United States presidential election, 1980">1980</a>.
</p><p>Kennedy came in third (behind Martin Luther King Jr. and <a href="/wiki/Mother_Teresa" title="Mother Teresa">Mother Teresa</a>) in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gallup%27s_List_of_Widely_Admired_People" title="Gallup's List of Widely Admired People">Gallup's List of Widely Admired People</a> of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[324]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[325]</a></sup> Kennedy was a life member of the <a href="/wiki/National_Rifle_Association" title="National Rifle Association">National Rifle Association</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[326]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[327]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wife_and_children">Wife and children</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFK_and_family_in_Hyannis_Port,_04_August_1962.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="777" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/JFK_and_family_in_Hyannis_Port%2C_04_August_1962.jpg/220px-JFK_and_family_in_Hyannis_Port%2C_04_August_1962.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/JFK_and_family_in_Hyannis_Port%2C_04_August_1962.jpg/330px-JFK_and_family_in_Hyannis_Port%2C_04_August_1962.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/JFK_and_family_in_Hyannis_Port%2C_04_August_1962.jpg/440px-JFK_and_family_in_Hyannis_Port%2C_04_August_1962.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFK_and_family_in_Hyannis_Port,_04_August_1962.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The First Family in 1962</div></div></div>
<p>Kennedy met his future wife, <a href="/wiki/Jacqueline_Kennedy_Onassis" title="Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis">Jacqueline Lee "Jackie" Bouvier</a> (1929–1994), when he was a congressman. <a href="/wiki/Charles_L._Bartlett_(journalist)" title="Charles L. Bartlett (journalist)">Charles L. Bartlett</a>, a journalist, introduced the pair at a dinner party.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[328]</a></sup> They were married a year after he was elected senator, on September 12, 1953.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[329]</a></sup> After suffering a miscarriage in 1955 and a stillbirth in 1956 (their daughter Arabella), their daughter <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Kennedy" title="Caroline Kennedy">Caroline</a> was born in 1957 and is the only surviving member of JFK's immediate family. <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Jr." title="John F. Kennedy Jr.">John Fitzgerald Kennedy Jr.</a>, nicknamed "John-John" by the press as a child, was born in late November 1960, 17 days after his father was elected. John Jr., a graduate of <a href="/wiki/Brown_University" title="Brown University">Brown University</a>, died in 1999 when the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy,_Jr._plane_crash" title="John F. Kennedy, Jr. plane crash">small plane he was piloting crashed</a> en route to <a href="/wiki/Martha%27s_Vineyard" title="Martha's Vineyard">Martha's Vineyard</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[330]</a></sup> In 1963, months before JFK's assassination, Jackie gave birth to a son, Patrick. However, he passed away after 2 days due to complications from birth.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Popular_image">Popular image</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ARC194238-JFK-Robert-Edward.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2673" data-file-width="2665" decoding="async" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/ARC194238-JFK-Robert-Edward.jpg/220px-ARC194238-JFK-Robert-Edward.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/ARC194238-JFK-Robert-Edward.jpg/330px-ARC194238-JFK-Robert-Edward.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/ARC194238-JFK-Robert-Edward.jpg/440px-ARC194238-JFK-Robert-Edward.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ARC194238-JFK-Robert-Edward.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Kennedy brothers: Attorney General <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy" title="Robert F. Kennedy">Robert F. Kennedy</a>, Senator <a href="/wiki/Ted_Kennedy" title="Ted Kennedy">Ted Kennedy</a>, and President John F. Kennedy in 1963</div></div></div>
<p>Kennedy and his wife were younger in comparison to the presidents and first ladies who preceded them, and both were popular in the <a href="/wiki/Media_culture" title="Media culture">media culture</a> in ways more common to pop singers and movie stars than politicians, influencing fashion trends and becoming the subjects of numerous photo spreads in popular magazines. Although Eisenhower had allowed presidential press conferences to be filmed for television, Kennedy was the first president to ask for them to be broadcast <a href="/wiki/Live_television" title="Live television">live</a> and made good use of the medium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-american_chronicle_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-american_chronicle-331">[331]</a></sup> In 1961 the <a href="/wiki/Radio_Television_Digital_News_Association" title="Radio Television Digital News Association">Radio-Television News Directors Association</a> presented Kennedy with its highest honor, the <a href="/wiki/Paul_White_(journalist)" title="Paul White (journalist)">Paul White</a> Award, in recognition of his open relationship with the media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mrs. Kennedy brought new art and furniture to the White House, and directed its restoration. They invited a range of artists, writers and intellectuals to rounds of White House dinners, raising the profile of the arts in America. On the White House lawn, the Kennedys established a swimming pool and tree house, while Caroline attended a preschool along with 10 other children inside the home.
</p><p>The president was closely tied to popular culture, emphasized by songs such as "<a href="/wiki/Twist_(dance)" title="Twist (dance)">Twisting</a> at the White House". <a href="/wiki/Vaughn_Meader" title="Vaughn Meader">Vaughn Meader's</a> <i>First Family</i> comedy album, which parodied the president, the first lady, their family, and the administration, sold about four million copies. On May 19, 1962, <a href="/wiki/Marilyn_Monroe" title="Marilyn Monroe">Marilyn Monroe</a> sang "<a href="/wiki/Happy_Birthday,_Mr._President" title="Happy Birthday, Mr. President">Happy Birthday, Mr. President</a>" at a large party in <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden_(1925)" title="Madison Square Garden (1925)">Madison Square Garden</a>, celebrating Kennedy's upcoming forty-fifth birthday.
</p>
<h3><span id=".22Camelot_Era.22"></span><span class="mw-headline" id='"Camelot_Era"'>"Camelot Era"</span></h3>
<p>The term "Camelot" came to be used retrospectively as iconic of the Kennedy administration, and the charisma of Kennedy and his family. The term was first publicly used by his wife in a post-assassination <a href="/wiki/Life_(magazine)" title="Life (magazine)"><i>Life</i> magazine</a> interview with <a href="/wiki/Theodore_H._White" title="Theodore H. White">Theodore H. White</a>, in which she revealed his affection for the contemporary <a href="/wiki/Camelot_(musical)" title="Camelot (musical)">Broadway musical of the same name</a>, particularly the closing lines of the title song:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_White._Series_11._Camelot_Documents_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_White._Series_11._Camelot_Documents-333">[333]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303468" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Don't let it be forgot, that once there was a spot, for one brief, shining moment that was known as Camelot.<br/>
There'll be great presidents again ... but there will never be another Camelot.</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite>Jacqueline Kennedy<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[334]</a></sup></cite></div>
</blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<p>In 2002 <a href="/wiki/Robert_Dallek" title="Robert Dallek">Robert Dallek</a> wrote an extensive history of Kennedy's health. Dallek was able to consult a collection of Kennedy-associated papers from the years 1955–1963, including X-rays and prescription records from the files of White House physician Dr. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Janet_Travell" title="Janet Travell">Janet Travell</a>. According to Travell's records, during his presidential years Kennedy suffered from high fevers; stomach, colon, and prostate issues; abscesses; high cholesterol; and adrenal problems. Travell kept a "Medicine Administration Record," cataloguing Kennedy's medications: "injected and ingested corticosteroids for his adrenal insufficiency; procaine shots and ultrasound treatments and hot packs for his back; Lomotil, Metamucil, paregoric, phenobarbital, testosterone, and trasentine to control his diarrhea, abdominal discomfort, and weight loss; penicillin and other antibiotics for his urinary-tract infections and an abscess; and <a href="/wiki/Tuinal" title="Tuinal">Tuinal</a> to help him sleep."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dallek_15-2"><a href="#cite_note-Dallek-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>Years after Kennedy's death, it was revealed that in September 1947, while Kennedy was 30 and in his first term in Congress, he was diagnosed by Sir Daniel Davis at <a href="/wiki/The_London_Clinic" title="The London Clinic">The London Clinic</a> with <a href="/wiki/Addison%27s_disease" title="Addison's disease">Addison's disease</a>, a rare endocrine disorder. In 1966 Dr. Travell revealed that Kennedy also had <a href="/wiki/Hypothyroidism" title="Hypothyroidism">hypothyroidism</a>. The presence of two endocrine diseases raises the possibility that Kennedy had <a href="/wiki/Autoimmune_polyendocrine_syndrome_type_2" title="Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 2">autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 2</a> (APS 2).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mandel,_Lee_R._2009_350–354_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mandel,_Lee_R._2009_350–354-335">[335]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy also suffered from chronic and severe back pain, for which he had surgery and was written up in the <a href="/wiki/American_Medical_Association" title="American Medical Association">American Medical Association</a>'s <i>Archives of Surgery</i>. Kennedy's condition may have had diplomatic repercussions, as he appears to have been taking a combination of drugs to treat severe back pain during the 1961 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vienna_Summit" title="Vienna Summit">Vienna Summit</a> with Soviet Premier <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a>. The combination included hormones, animal organ cells, steroids, vitamins, enzymes, and amphetamines, and possible potential side effects included hyperactivity, <a href="/wiki/Hypertension" title="Hypertension">hypertension</a>, impaired judgment, nervousness, and mood swings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKempe2011213_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKempe2011213-336">[336]</a></sup> Kennedy at one time was regularly seen by no fewer than three doctors, one of whom, <a href="/wiki/Max_Jacobson" title="Max Jacobson">Max Jacobson</a>, was unknown to the other two, as his mode of treatment was controversial<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[337]</a></sup> and used for the most severe bouts of back pain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves199342,_158-159_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves199342,_158-159-338">[338]</a></sup>
</p><p>Into late 1961, disagreements existed among Kennedy's doctors concerning his proper balance of medication and exercise. The president preferred the former, because he was short on time and desired immediate relief.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993243_224-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993243-224">[224]</a></sup> During that time, the president's physician, George Burkley, did set up some gym equipment in the White House basement, where Kennedy did stretching exercises for his back three times a week.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993244_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993244-339">[339]</a></sup> Details of these and other medical problems were not publicly disclosed during Kennedy's lifetime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup> The President's primary White House physician, George Burkley, realized that treatments by Jacobson and Travell, including the excessive use of steroids and amphetamines, were medically inappropriate, and took effective action to remove the president from their care.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jfkwhmd_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-jfkwhmd-341">[341]</a></sup> It was later observed that President Kennedy's leadership (e.g. the 1962 Cuban Missile crisis and other events during 1963) improved greatly once the treatments of Jacobson had been discontinued and been replaced by a medically appropriate regimen under Burkley. Dr. Ghaemi, who studied Kennedy's medical records, concluded there was a "correlation; it is not causation; but it may not be coincidence either".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jfkwhmd_341-1"><a href="#cite_note-jfkwhmd-341">[341]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_tragedies">Personal tragedies</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kennedy_curse" title="Kennedy curse">Kennedy curse</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Kennedys_by_Toni_Frissell,_1953.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="851" data-file-width="1241" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/The_Kennedys_by_Toni_Frissell%2C_1953.jpg/220px-The_Kennedys_by_Toni_Frissell%2C_1953.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/The_Kennedys_by_Toni_Frissell%2C_1953.jpg/330px-The_Kennedys_by_Toni_Frissell%2C_1953.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/The_Kennedys_by_Toni_Frissell%2C_1953.jpg/440px-The_Kennedys_by_Toni_Frissell%2C_1953.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Kennedys_by_Toni_Frissell,_1953.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The newlyweds surrounded by Jack's siblings on their wedding day in Newport, Rhode Island in 1953</div></div></div>
<p>Kennedy and his family have experienced a number of personal tragedies. His older brother <a href="/wiki/Joseph_P._Kennedy_Jr." title="Joseph P. Kennedy Jr.">Joseph P. Kennedy Jr.</a> was killed in action in 1944 at age 29, when his plane exploded over the English Channel during a first attack execution of <a href="/wiki/Operation_Aphrodite" title="Operation Aphrodite">Operation Aphrodite</a> during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[342]</a></sup> Kennedy's younger sister <a href="/wiki/Rosemary_Kennedy" title="Rosemary Kennedy">Rose Marie "Rosemary" Kennedy</a> was born in 1918 with intellectual disabilities and underwent a prefrontal <a href="/wiki/Lobotomy" title="Lobotomy">lobotomy</a> at age 23, leaving her  incapacitated for the rest of her life, until her death in 2005. His younger sister <a href="/wiki/Kathleen_Cavendish,_Marchioness_of_Hartington" title="Kathleen Cavendish, Marchioness of Hartington">Kathleen Agnes "Kick" Kennedy</a> died in a plane crash en route to France in 1948. His wife Jacqueline Kennedy suffered a <a href="/wiki/Miscarriage" title="Miscarriage">miscarriage</a> in 1955 and a <a href="/wiki/Stillbirth" title="Stillbirth">stillbirth</a> in 1956: a daughter informally named Arabella.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[343]</a></sup> A son, <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Bouvier_Kennedy" title="Patrick Bouvier Kennedy">Patrick Bouvier Kennedy</a>, died two days after birth in August 1963.
</p>
<h3><span id="Affairs.2C_extramarital_relationships_and_friendships"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Affairs,_extramarital_relationships_and_friendships">Affairs, extramarital relationships and friendships</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFK_and_Marilyn_Monroe_1962.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/JFK_and_Marilyn_Monroe_1962.jpg/220px-JFK_and_Marilyn_Monroe_1962.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/JFK_and_Marilyn_Monroe_1962.jpg/330px-JFK_and_Marilyn_Monroe_1962.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/JFK_and_Marilyn_Monroe_1962.jpg/440px-JFK_and_Marilyn_Monroe_1962.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFK_and_Marilyn_Monroe_1962.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Attorney General <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy" title="Robert F. Kennedy">Robert F. Kennedy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marilyn_Monroe" title="Marilyn Monroe">Marilyn Monroe</a>, President Kennedy (back to camera) in 1962</div></div></div>
<p>Kennedy was single in the 1940s when he had affairs with Danish journalist <a href="/wiki/Inga_Arvad" title="Inga Arvad">Inga Arvad</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek200383-85_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek200383-85-344">[344]</a></sup> and actress <a href="/wiki/Gene_Tierney" title="Gene Tierney">Gene Tierney</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOsborne2006195_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOsborne2006195-345">[345]</a></sup> Before and after he assumed the presidency, Kennedy reportedly had extramarital affairs with a number of women, including <a href="/wiki/Marilyn_Monroe" title="Marilyn Monroe">Marilyn Monroe</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993315–316_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993315–316-346">[346]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gunilla_von_Post" title="Gunilla von Post">Gunilla von Post</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[347]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Judith_Exner" title="Judith Exner">Judith Campbell</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993289_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993289-348">[348]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mary_Pinchot_Meyer" title="Mary Pinchot Meyer">Mary Pinchot Meyer</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003475_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003475-349">[349]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marlene_Dietrich" title="Marlene Dietrich">Marlene Dietrich</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek200358_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek200358-350">[350]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mimi_Alford" title="Mimi Alford">Mimi Alford</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes_garrow_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes_garrow-351">[351]</a></sup> and his wife's <a href="/wiki/Press_secretary" title="Press secretary">press secretary</a>, Pamela Turnure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003475,_476_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003475,_476-352">[352]</a></sup>
</p><p>The extent of Kennedy's relationship with Monroe is not fully known, although it has been reported that they spent a weekend together in March 1962 while he was staying at <a href="/wiki/Bing_Crosby" title="Bing Crosby">Bing Crosby</a>'s house.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeaming2006379-380_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeaming2006379-380-353">[353]</a></sup> Furthermore, people at the White House switchboard noted that Monroe had called Kennedy during 1962.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003581_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003581-354">[354]</a></sup> J. Edgar Hoover, the FBI director, received reports about Kennedy's indiscretions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003376_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003376-355">[355]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy inspired affection and loyalty from the members of his team and his supporters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBarnes2007116_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarnes2007116-356">[356]</a></sup> According to Reeves, this included "the logistics of Kennedy's liaisons ... [which] required secrecy and devotion rare in the annals of the energetic service demanded by successful politicians."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReeves1993291_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReeves1993291-357">[357]</a></sup> Kennedy believed that his friendly relationship with members of the press would help protect him from public revelations about his sex life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003478_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003478-358">[358]</a></sup>
</p><p>Though there has never been any proof of homosexual activity between them, Kennedy would often, and even when married, share a bedroom with his lifelong and close friend <a href="/wiki/Lem_Billings" title="Lem Billings">Lem Billings</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_evaluations_and_legacy">Historical evaluations and legacy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yad_Kennedy_May_2009.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Yad_Kennedy_May_2009.JPG/220px-Yad_Kennedy_May_2009.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Yad_Kennedy_May_2009.JPG/330px-Yad_Kennedy_May_2009.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Yad_Kennedy_May_2009.JPG/440px-Yad_Kennedy_May_2009.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Yad_Kennedy_May_2009.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Yad_Kennedy" title="Yad Kennedy">John F. Kennedy Memorial</a>, near Jerusalem, Israel</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Special_Forces_(United_States_Army)" title="Special Forces (United States Army)">US Special Forces</a> had a special bond with Kennedy. "It was President Kennedy who was responsible for the rebuilding of the Special Forces and giving us back our Green Beret," said Forrest Lindley, a writer for the US military newspaper <i><a href="/wiki/Stars_and_Stripes_(newspaper)" title="Stars and Stripes (newspaper)">Stars and Stripes</a></i> who served with Special Forces in Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Green_Beret_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-Green_Beret-360">[a]</a></sup> This bond was shown at <a href="/wiki/State_funeral_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="State funeral of John F. Kennedy">Kennedy's funeral</a>. At the commemoration of the 25th anniversary of Kennedy's death, General <a href="/wiki/Michael_D._Healy" title="Michael D. Healy">Michael D. Healy</a>, the last commander of Special Forces in Vietnam, spoke at Arlington Cemetery. Later, a wreath in the form of the Green Beret would be placed on the grave, continuing a tradition that began the day of his funeral when a sergeant in charge of a detail of Special Forces men guarding the grave placed his beret on the coffin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[360]</a></sup> Kennedy was the first of six presidents to have served in the U.S. Navy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-2">[2]</a></sup> and one of the enduring legacies of his administration was the creation in 1961 of another <a href="/wiki/Special_forces" title="Special forces">special forces</a> command, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy_SEALs" title="United States Navy SEALs">Navy SEALs</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[361]</a></sup> which Kennedy enthusiastically supported.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Salinger_p97_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-Salinger_p97-363">[362]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F_Kennedy_2017_Dedication-forever.jpg"><img alt="The dedication of a new forever stamp to honor what would be President John F. Kennedy's 100th birthday." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2988" data-file-width="5312" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/John_F_Kennedy_2017_Dedication-forever.jpg/290px-John_F_Kennedy_2017_Dedication-forever.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/John_F_Kennedy_2017_Dedication-forever.jpg/435px-John_F_Kennedy_2017_Dedication-forever.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/John_F_Kennedy_2017_Dedication-forever.jpg/580px-John_F_Kennedy_2017_Dedication-forever.jpg 2x" width="290"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_F_Kennedy_2017_Dedication-forever.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The dedication of a new <a href="/wiki/Non-denominated_postage#Forever_stamps" title="Non-denominated postage">forever stamp</a> to honor what would be President John F. Kennedy's 100th birthday</div></div></div>
<p>Kennedy's civil rights proposals led to the Civil Rights Act of 1964.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003594-606,_644_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003594-606,_644-364">[363]</a></sup> President Lyndon B. Johnson, Kennedy's successor, took up the mantle and pushed the landmark Civil Rights Act through a bitterly divided Congress by invoking the slain president's memory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2003708_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2003708-365">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USA_Today_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-USA_Today-366">[365]</a></sup> President Johnson then signed the Act into law on July 2, 1964. This civil rights law ended what was known as the "<a href="/wiki/Solid_South" title="Solid South">Solid South</a>" and certain provisions were modeled after the <a href="/wiki/Civil_Rights_Act_of_1875" title="Civil Rights Act of 1875">Civil Rights Act of 1875</a>, signed into law by President <a href="/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant" title="Ulysses S. Grant">Ulysses S. Grant</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWalton_Jr.Smith2000205_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWalton_Jr.Smith2000205-367">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p>Kennedy's continuation of Presidents Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower's policies of giving economic and military aid to South Vietnam left the door open for President Johnson's escalation of the conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[367]</a></sup> At the time of Kennedy's death, no final policy decision had been made as to Vietnam, leading historians, cabinet members, and writers to continue to disagree on whether the Vietnam conflict would have escalated to the point it did had he survived.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Douthat_2011-11-26_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-Douthat_2011-11-26-369">[368]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatthews2011393,_394_183-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatthews2011393,_394-183">[183]</a></sup> His agreement to the NSAM 263<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSAM_263_180-1"><a href="#cite_note-NSAM_263-180">[180]</a></sup> action of withdrawing 1,000 troops by the end of 1963, and his earlier 1963 speech at American University,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AmUniv_182-1"><a href="#cite_note-AmUniv-182">[182]</a></sup> suggest that he was ready to end the Vietnam War. The Vietnam War contributed greatly to a decade of national difficulties, amid violent disappointment on the political landscape.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F_Kennedy_1967_Issue-13c.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="612" data-file-width="533" decoding="async" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/John_F_Kennedy_1967_Issue-13c.jpg/170px-John_F_Kennedy_1967_Issue-13c.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/John_F_Kennedy_1967_Issue-13c.jpg/255px-John_F_Kennedy_1967_Issue-13c.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/John_F_Kennedy_1967_Issue-13c.jpg/340px-John_F_Kennedy_1967_Issue-13c.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_F_Kennedy_1967_Issue-13c.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kennedy on a U.S. postage stamp, issue of 1967</div></div></div>
<p>Many of Kennedy's speeches (especially his inaugural address) are considered iconic; and despite his relatively short term in office, and the lack of major legislative changes coming to fruition during his term, Americans regularly vote him as one of the best presidents, in the same league as Abraham Lincoln, <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a>, and Franklin D. Roosevelt. Some excerpts of Kennedy's inaugural address are engraved on a plaque at his grave at Arlington. In 2018, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i> published an audio recreation of the "watchmen on the walls of world freedom" speech he was scheduled to deliver at the <a href="/wiki/Dallas_Market_Center" title="Dallas Market Center">Dallas Trade Mart</a> on November 22, 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[370]</a></sup>
</p><p>He was posthumously awarded the <a href="/wiki/Pacem_in_Terris_Award" title="Pacem in Terris Award"><i>Pacem in Terris</i> Award</a> (<a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>: Peace on Earth). It was named after a 1963 <a href="/wiki/Encyclical" title="Encyclical">encyclical</a> letter by <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_XXIII" title="Pope John XXIII">Pope John XXIII</a> that calls upon all people of goodwill to secure peace among all nations.
</p><p>Kennedy is the only president to have predeceased both his mother and father. He is also the only president to have predeceased a grandparent. His maternal grandmother, Mary Josephine "Josie" Hannon, died in August 1964, nine months after his assassination.
</p><p>Throughout the <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_world" title="English-speaking world">English-speaking world</a>, the given name <i><a href="/wiki/Kennedy_(given_name)" title="Kennedy (given name)">Kennedy</a></i> has sometimes been used in honor of President Kennedy, as well his brother Robert.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hanks-157_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hanks-157-372">[371]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Effect_of_assassination">Effect of assassination</span></h3>
<p>Television became the primary source by which people were kept informed of events surrounding John F. Kennedy's assassination. In fact, television started to come of age before the assassination. On September 2, 1963, Kennedy helped inaugurate network television's first half-hour nightly evening newscast according to an interview with <i><a href="/wiki/CBS_Evening_News" title="CBS Evening News">CBS Evening News</a></i> anchor <a href="/wiki/Walter_Cronkite" title="Walter Cronkite">Walter Cronkite</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[372]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFK_library_Stitch_Crop.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1884" data-file-width="3711" decoding="async" height="122" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/JFK_library_Stitch_Crop.jpg/240px-JFK_library_Stitch_Crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/JFK_library_Stitch_Crop.jpg/360px-JFK_library_Stitch_Crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/JFK_library_Stitch_Crop.jpg/480px-JFK_library_Stitch_Crop.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFK_library_Stitch_Crop.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Presidential_Library_and_Museum" title="John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum">John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum</a> located in Boston, Massachusetts</div></div></div>
<p>Newspapers were kept as souvenirs rather than sources of updated information.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In this sense his assassination was the first major TV news event of its kind. TV coverage united the nation, interpreting what went on, and creating memories of this space in time.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> All three major U.S. television networks suspended their regular schedules and switched to all-news coverage from November 22 through November 26, 1963, being on the air for 70 hours, making it the longest uninterrupted news event on American TV until 9/11.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[373]</a></sup>
</p><p>The assassination had an effect on many people, not only in the U.S. but around the world. Many vividly remember where they were when they first learned the news that Kennedy was assassinated, as with the Japanese <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">attack on Pearl Harbor</a> on December 7, 1941, before it and the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</a> after it. UN Ambassador Adlai Stevenson said of the assassination: "all of us. ... . will bear the grief of his death until the day of ours." Many people have also spoken of the shocking news, compounded by the pall of uncertainty about the identity of the assassin(s), the possible instigators, and the causes of the killing, as an end to innocence, and in retrospect it has been coalesced with other changes of the tumultuous decade of the 1960s, especially the Vietnam War.
</p><p>Ultimately, the death of President Kennedy, and the ensuing confusion surrounding the facts of his assassination, are of political and historical importance insofar as they marked a turning point and decline in the faith of the American people in the political establishment—a point made by commentators from <a href="/wiki/Gore_Vidal" title="Gore Vidal">Gore Vidal</a> to <a href="/wiki/Arthur_M._Schlesinger_Jr." title="Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.">Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.</a> and implied by <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Stone" title="Oliver Stone">Oliver Stone</a> in several of his films, such as his landmark 1991 <a href="/wiki/JFK_(film)" title="JFK (film)"><i>JFK</i></a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Memorials_and_eponyms">Memorials and eponyms</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Memorials_to_John_F._Kennedy" title="Memorials to John F. Kennedy">Memorials to John F. Kennedy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_F_Kennedy_eternal_flame_after_2013_upgrade_-_2013-05-30.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1307" data-file-width="2500" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/John_F_Kennedy_eternal_flame_after_2013_upgrade_-_2013-05-30.jpg/300px-John_F_Kennedy_eternal_flame_after_2013_upgrade_-_2013-05-30.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/John_F_Kennedy_eternal_flame_after_2013_upgrade_-_2013-05-30.jpg/450px-John_F_Kennedy_eternal_flame_after_2013_upgrade_-_2013-05-30.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/John_F_Kennedy_eternal_flame_after_2013_upgrade_-_2013-05-30.jpg/600px-John_F_Kennedy_eternal_flame_after_2013_upgrade_-_2013-05-30.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_F_Kennedy_eternal_flame_after_2013_upgrade_-_2013-05-30.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Eternal_Flame" title="John F. Kennedy Eternal Flame">John F. Kennedy Eternal Flame</a> memorial</div></div></div>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy International Airport</a>, American airport in New York City; nation's busiest international gateway</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_School_of_Government" title="John F. Kennedy School of Government">John F. Kennedy School of Government</a>, part of Harvard University</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_Space_Center" title="John F. Kennedy Space Center">John F. Kennedy Space Center</a>, U.S. government installation that manages and operates America's astronaut launch facilities in <a href="/wiki/Merritt_Island,_Florida" title="Merritt Island, Florida">Merritt Island, Florida</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/USS_John_F._Kennedy_(CV-67)" title="USS John F. Kennedy (CV-67)">USS <i>John F. Kennedy</i> (CV-67)</a>, U.S. Navy aircraft carrier ordered in April 1964, launched May 1967, decommissioned August 2007; nicknamed "Big John"</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/USS_John_F._Kennedy_(CVN-79)" title="USS John F. Kennedy (CVN-79)">USS <i>John F. Kennedy</i> (CVN-79)</a>, U.S. Navy aircraft carrier that began construction in 2011, and is scheduled to be placed in commission in 2020</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kennedy_half_dollar" title="Kennedy half dollar">Kennedy half dollar</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Half_dollar_(United_States_coin)" title="Half dollar (United States coin)">fifty-cent coin</a> first minted in 1964 and discontinued in 2002</li></ul>

<li id="cite_note-sptimes.com-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-sptimes.com_59-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-sptimes.com_59-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160801205613/http://www.sptimes.com/News/111199/JFK/timeline.shtml" rel="nofollow">"JFK: A Timeline of His Life 1917–1963"</a>. <li id="cite_note-329"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-329">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Specious allegations in 1997 by UK journalist Terry O'Hanlon <cite class="citation web">Golden, Andrew (July 27, 1997). <a class="external text" href="http://www.thefreelibrary.com/JFK+THE+BIGAMIST...+THE+TRUTH+AT+LAST%3b+Kennedy+was+already+married...-a061139564" rel="nofollow">"JFK The Bigamist. ... . The Truth At Last; Kennedy was already married when he got wed to Jackie. ..."</a> <i>Sunday Mirror</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">October 31,</span> 2010</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Sunday+Mirror&amp;rft.atitle=JFK+The+Bigamist.+...+.+The+Truth+At+Last%3B+Kennedy+was+already+married+when+he+got+wed+to+Jackie.+...+.&amp;rft.date=1997-07-27&amp;rft.au=Golden%2C+Andrew&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.thefreelibrary.com%2FJFK%2BTHE%2BBIGAMIST...%2BTHE%2BTRUTH%2BAT%2BLAST%253b%2BKennedy%2Bwas%2Balready%2Bmarried...-a061139564&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJohn+F.+Kennedy"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/> and by author Seymour Hersh <cite class="citation web">Reingold, Joyce (March 26, 2008). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110510034800/http://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/blogs/content/shared-blogs/palmbeach/pbupd8/entries/2008/03/26/durie_appleton_spent_a_lifetim.html" rel="nofollow">"JFK 'Secret Marriage' A Story With Legs"</a>. <i>Palm Beach Daily News</i>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/blogs/content/shared-blogs/palmbeach/pbupd8/entries/2008/03/26/durie_appleton_spent_a_lifetim.html" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on May 10, 2011<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">October 31,</span> 2010</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Palm+Beach+Daily+News&amp;rft.atitle=JFK+%27Secret+Marriage%27+A+Story+With+Legs&amp;rft.date=2008-03-26&amp;rft.aulast=Reingold&amp;rft.aufirst=Joyce&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.palmbeachdailynews.com%2Fblogs%2Fcontent%2Fshared-blogs%2Fpalmbeach%2Fpbupd8%2Fentries%2F2008%2F03%2F26%2Fdurie_appleton_spent_a_lifetim.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJohn+F.+Kennedy"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/> that Kennedy had married previously have been soundly disproven. Reeves states that <a href="/wiki/Ben_Bradlee" title="Ben Bradlee">Ben Bradlee</a>, then at <i><a href="/wiki/Newsweek" title="Newsweek">Newsweek</a></i>, inspected FBI files on it, and confirmed the falsehood. <a href="#CITEREFReeves1993">Reeves 1993</a>, p. 348; for further refutation, see <a href="#CITEREFO'Brien2005">O'Brien 2005</a>, p. 706.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-JFKlibrary.org_White._Series_11._Camelot_Documents-333"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-JFKlibrary.org_White._Series_11._Camelot_Documents_333-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060906065903/http://www.jfklibrary.org/Historical%2BResources/Archives/Archives%2Band%2BManuscripts/fa_white_theodore.htm" rel="nofollow">The Personal Papers of Theodore H. Kennedy Presidential Library &amp; Museum</i> quotation:<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303468" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>The 1963 LIFE article represented the first use of the term "Camelot" in print and is attributed with having played a major role in establishing and fixing this image of the Kennedy Administration and period in the popular mind.

<li id="cite_note-Mandel,_Lee_R._2009_350–354-335"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Mandel,_Lee_R._2009_350–354_335-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation journal">Mandel, Lee R. Kennedy"</a>. <i>Annals of Internal Medicine</i>. <b>151</b> (151(5)): 350–354. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.7326%2F0003-4819-151-5-200909010-00011" rel="nofollow">10.7326/0003-4819-151-5-200909010-00011</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PubMed_Identifier" title="PubMed Identifier">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19721023" rel="nofollow">19721023</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Annals+of+Internal+Medicine&amp;rft.atitle=Endocrine+and+Autoimmune+Aspects+of+the+Health+History+of+John+F.+Kennedy&amp;rft.volume=151&amp;rft.issue=151%285%29&amp;rft.pages=350-354&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.7326%2F0003-4819-151-5-200909010-00011&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F19721023&amp;rft.au=Mandel%2C+Lee+R.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.annals.org%2Fcontent%2F151%2F5%2F350.full%23xref-ref-9-1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJohn+F.+Kennedy"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEKempe2011213-336"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKempe2011213_336-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKempe2011">Kempe 2011</a>, p. 213.</span>

<li id="cite_note-371"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-371">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Kennedy, John F. (November 22, 1963). <a class="external text" href="https://www.jfklibrary.org/Research/Research-Aids/JFK-Speeches/Dallas-TX-Trade-Mart-Undelivered_19631122.aspx" rel="nofollow">"Remarks Prepared for Delivery at the Trade Mart in Dallas, TX, November 22, 1963 [Undelivered]"</a>. John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">May 10,</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Remarks+Prepared+for+Delivery+at+the+Trade+Mart+in+Dallas%2C+TX%2C+November+22%2C+1963+%5BUndelivered%5D&amp;rft.pub=John+F.+Kennedy+Presidential+Library+and+Museum&amp;rft.date=1963-11-22&amp;rft.au=Kennedy%2C+John+F.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.jfklibrary.org%2FResearch%2FResearch-Aids%2FJFK-Speeches%2FDallas-TX-Trade-Mart-Undelivered_19631122.aspx&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJohn+F.+Kennedy"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Hanks-157-372"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Hanks-157_372-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book"><a href="/wiki/Patrick_Hanks" title="Patrick Hanks">Hanks, Patrick</a>; Hardcastle, Kate; Hodges, Flavia (2006). <i>A Dictionary of First Names</i>. Addison, Wesley, Longman. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-321-07038-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-321-07038-8">978-0-321-07038-8</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=American+Politics+and+the+African+American+Quest+for+Universal+Freedom&amp;rft.pub=Addison%2C+Wesley%2C+Longman&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-321-07038-8&amp;rft.aulast=Walton+Jr.&amp;rft.aufirst=Hanes&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Robert+C.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJohn+F.+Kennedy"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></li></ul>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historiography_and_memory">Historiography and memory</span></h3>
<ul><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abramson,_Jill" title="Abramson, Jill">Abramson, Jill</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/27/books/review/the-elusive-president.html" rel="nofollow">"Kennedy, the Elusive President"</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Book_Review" title="The New York Times Book Review">The New York Times Book Review</a></i> October 22, 2013, notes that 40,000 books have been published about JFK</li>
<li>Hellmann, John. <i>The Kennedy Obsession: The American Myth of JFK</i> (1997, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0231107983" title="Special:BookSources/978-0231107983">978-0231107983</a>)</li>
<li><cite class="citation journal">Kazin, Michael (December 2017). <a class="external text" href="http://academic.oup.com/jah/article/104/3/707/4655067" rel="nofollow">"An Idol and Once a President: John F. Kennedy at 100"</a>. <i>Journal of American History</i>. <b>104</b> (3): 707–726. <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="//doi.org/10.1093%2Fjahist%2Fjax315" rel="nofollow">10.1093/jahist/jax315</a>. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number" title="International Standard Serial Number">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0021-8723" rel="nofollow">0021-8723</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+American+History&amp;rft.atitle=An+Idol+and+Once+a+President%3A+John+F.+Kennedy+at+100&amp;rft.volume=104&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=707-726&amp;rft.date=2017-12&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1093%2Fjahist%2Fjax315&amp;rft.issn=0021-8723&amp;rft.aulast=Kazin&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Facademic.oup.com%2Fjah%2Farticle%2F104%2F3%2F707%2F4655067&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AJohn+F.+Kennedy"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></li>

Kennedy</i> (Wiley-Blackwell, 2014, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1444350364" title="Special:BookSources/978-1444350364">978-1444350364</a>), Topical essays by scholars focusing on the historiography</li></ul>

</div>
<ul style="border-top:1px solid #aaa; padding-top: 0.75em;">
<li style="min-height: 31px;"><span style="display: inline-block; width: 31px; line-height: 31px; vertical-align: middle; text-align: center;"><img alt="" data-file-height="391" data-file-width="391" decoding="async" height="27" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/06/Wiktionary-logo-v2.svg/27px-Wiktionary-logo-v2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/06/Wiktionary-logo-v2.svg/41px-Wiktionary-logo-v2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/06/Wiktionary-logo-v2.svg/54px-Wiktionary-logo-v2.svg.png 2x" style="vertical-align: middle" width="27"/></span><span style="display: inline-block; margin-left: 4px; width: 182px; vertical-align: middle;"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Kennedy" title="wikt:Kennedy">Definitions</a> from Wiktionary</span>
</li><li style="min-height: 31px;"><span style="display: inline-block; width: 31px; line-height: 31px; vertical-align: middle; text-align: center;"><img alt="" data-file-height="1376" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="27" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/20px-Commons-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/30px-Commons-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/40px-Commons-logo.svg.png 2x" style="vertical-align: middle" width="20"/></span><span style="display: inline-block; margin-left: 4px; width: 182px; vertical-align: middle;"><a class="extiw" href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/John_F._Kennedy" title="c:Special:Search/John F. Kennedy">Media</a> from Wikimedia Commons</span>
</li><li style="min-height: 31px;"><span style="display: inline-block; width: 31px; line-height: 31px; vertical-align: middle; text-align: center;"><img alt="" data-file-height="355" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="27" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikiquote-logo.svg/23px-Wikiquote-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikiquote-logo.svg/35px-Wikiquote-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Wikiquote-logo.svg/46px-Wikiquote-logo.svg.png 2x" style="vertical-align: middle" width="23"/></span><span style="display: inline-block; margin-left: 4px; width: 182px; vertical-align: middle;"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Special:Search/John_F._Kennedy" title="q:Special:Search/John F. Kennedy">Quotations</a> from Wikiquote</span>
</li><li style="min-height: 31px;"><span style="display: inline-block; width: 31px; line-height: 31px; vertical-align: middle; text-align: center;"><img alt="" data-file-height="430" data-file-width="410" decoding="async" height="27" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/26px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/39px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/51px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" style="vertical-align: middle" width="26"/></span><span style="display: inline-block; margin-left: 4px; width: 182px; vertical-align: middle;"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Author:John_F._Kennedy" title="s:Author:John F. Kennedy</a> (1961–63)</div></th></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States" title="Vice President of the United States">Vice President</a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Interior" title="United States Secretary of the Interior">Secretary of the Interior</a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Stewart_Udall" title="Stewart Udall">Stewart Udall</a> (1961–1963)</li></ul>

<div aria-labelledby="Pulitzer_Prize_for_Biography_or_Autobiography_(1951–1975)" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:PulitzerPrize_BiographyorAutobiographyAuthors_1951%E2%80%931975" title="Template:PulitzerPrize BiographyorAutobiographyAuthors 1951–1975"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:PulitzerPrize_BiographyorAutobiographyAuthors_1951%E2%80%931975" title="Template talk:PulitzerPrize BiographyorAutobiographyAuthors 1951–1975"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:PulitzerPrize_BiographyorAutobiographyAuthors_1951%E2%80%931975&amp;action=edit"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Pulitzer_Prize_for_Biography_or_Autobiography_(1951–1975)" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize_for_Biography_or_Autobiography" title="Pulitzer Prize for Biography or Autobiography">Pulitzer Prize for Biography or Autobiography</a> (1951–1975)</div></th></tr><tr><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" colspan="2" style="width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Margaret_Coit" title="Margaret Coit">Margaret Louise Coit</a> (1951)</li>

<div aria-labelledby="Pacem_in_Terris_Peace_and_Freedom_Award_laureates" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks collapsible collapsed navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col" style="background-color:gold"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Pacem_in_Terris_Award_laureates" title="Template:Pacem in Terris Award laureates"><abbr style="background-color:gold;;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Pacem_in_Terris_Award_laureates" title="Template talk:Pacem in Terris Award laureates"><abbr style="background-color:gold;;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Pacem_in_Terris_Award_laureates&amp;action=edit"><abbr style="background-color:gold;;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Pacem_in_Terris_Peace_and_Freedom_Award_laureates" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Pacem_in_Terris_Award" title="Pacem in Terris Award"><i>Pacem in Terris</i> Peace and Freedom Award</a> laureates</div></th></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="background-color:gold;width:1%">1960s</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
